post:
Hi everyone... I don't know what to type...

Some important details: I'm an 18 yo Female living with my Dad and my Step mom and i have 2 brothers 28 and 23 that don't live with us anymore but still hang out with us. I get along just fine with my brothers and Step mom. I'm not an english native, sorry for any mistakes that i'll write.

​

So i just finished high school here in Europe and i was searching for a good university that i'd like to attend and i found one just 30 minutes from where i live where i would study what i want. Let's call that place "MYPlace".

Between all of this my Dad contracted some guys to come wreck our house and build it again because some things were just getting really bad which would need to be rebuilt. That was a couple of months ago and today my step mom fired them because they were incompetent which made my dad angry and stressed because he wants the house fixed. Just picture a man in his mid 50s who wants everything done just how he likes.

Example: when the team told him they were gonna find some things needed for the bathroom (completely remodeling the bathroom so we're talking about things like a sink a toilet that stuff) and my dad told them that HE was gonna take care of that. I'm not saying that's bad, i'm saying that is how he operates, doing things as he wants them to be.

​

So today i told him i would like to go to "MYPlace" because even though it's 30 minutes away from here it has what i would like to study and do as a job in the future. This would require to rent an apartment over there. We aren't rich nor poor but we get along fine, not bad not good just at the middle.

He wants me to go to another location which is 10 minutes away from where we live and we'll call it "HisPlace".

His response was and i quote "You can't go there because yo're dumb and stupid and you can't figure stuff out on your own. You must go to "HisPlace" because it's 5 steps away from university and you are gonna like that much more". I just sat there listening not saying anything... Maybe he's like that because of the incompetent team that my step mom fired? My boyfriend (18M of 4 months) said it's unacceptable to behave like that to his sensitive daughter (me) but deep down i know my dad always thought like that about me.

Also: "you think going from MYPlace to university is a walk in the park are you stupid? You wont make it." he thinks ill be walking from my apartment to university walking and the sun is too strong for me to go outside... I guess buses dont exist? He doesn't trust me to do SHIT.

I swear he called me names and i just don't know what to do. I can figure stuff out on my own i'm not incompetent nor a kid, i admit i'm not an adult but damn im not a child. He just does not trust me and he said he's NOT interfering with my university choices so i wonder what he would be like if he did in fact interfere lol.

​

I just dont wanna go anywhere right now, im anxious and a bit depressed cause i know he won't support me and whatever i do or wherever i go. Honestly i am just sick of this and i want to give up on college and go work on some random shit.

He says i need to go to HisPlace because my cousin went there and he's doing ok in life even though i don't want to do what he does for a job (agronomy) and i what i want is to be a nurse. I spent all my life pleasing this man so in the end he can trust me and now i find out he doesn't even a bit... He thinks that without him by my side i'm gonna end up fucking dead lol.

​

He doesn't deal with half terms so it's his way or i don't know... Please help me i do not know what to do and i need to apply to some university...
reply:
Hey everyone, I hope you're all doing well. I really need some advice right now. So, I recently finished high school and I found a university that I would love to attend, let's call it "MYPlace." It's just 30 minutes away from where I live, which is perfect for me. However, my dad had some guys come in to rebuild our house a few months ago, but my stepmom ended up firing them because they were incompetent. This has made my dad really stressed and angry because he wants everything done his way. 

Today, I mustered up the courage to tell him that I want to go to "MYPlace" and live in an apartment nearby. But his response was hurtful. He called me names and said that I can't figure stuff out on my own, so I should go to "HisPlace" which is just 10 minutes away from where we live. He doesn't trust me to do anything and it's really disheartening.

I feel anxious and a bit depressed about this situation. I don't want to give up on college, but I also don't want to go somewhere where I won't have his support. It's frustrating because I've always tried to please him, but now I realize that he never really trusted me. I just don't know what to do or where to go. I need to apply to universities soon and I feel stuck. Any advice would be greatly appreciated. Thank you. üôèüèº

reply:
Hey there,

I'm really sorry to hear what you're going through with your dad. It can be so disheartening and frustrating when someone you love doesn't support your dreams and goals. It sounds like you have a clear idea of what you want to study and where you want to go, which is fantastic! Pursuing your passion and becoming a nurse is a noble and fulfilling path.

Even though your dad may not understand or trust your choices right now, it's important to remember that this is your life and your future. You have the right to make decisions that align with your own aspirations and interests. It's understandable that his comments have made you feel anxious and depressed, but try not to let his negativity bring you down. You are capable and intelligent, and you can figure things out on your own.

Applying to universities can be overwhelming, but remember that you have the power to take control of this process. Reach out to the universities you're interested in and ask for information about their programs, housing options, and student support services. Many universities also have counseling or guidance offices that can provide advice and assistance.

In terms of your living situation, consider exploring options for renting an apartment near "MYPlace" if that's what will make you happy. Living closer to the university you want to attend can have numerous benefits, including easy access to resources, a sense of independence, and opportunities to connect with fellow students. Don't be discouraged by your dad's doubts about your ability to handle the commute. Buses and other means of transportation exist, and many students successfully navigate their way to and from university every day.

Remember, this is your journey, and it's important to prioritize your own happiness and future. It may take time for your dad to come around and understand your choices, but don't let his negativity deter you from pursuing your dreams. Stay strong, trust in yourself, and reach out for support from friends, other family members, or professionals if needed. Keep believing in yourself and your abilities, because you have so much potential.

Take care and best of luck with your applications.

reply:
Hi there,

I can understand how difficult and stressful this situation must be for you. It seems like there is a lot of tension between you and your dad regarding your university choices. It can be really tough when a parent doesn't support and trust your decisions.

Firstly, it's important to remember that your career path and choice of university should ultimately be up to you. It's your future and you should pursue what you're passionate about. It's understandable that you feel hurt and frustrated by your dad's lack of trust and demeaning comments. However, it's important to focus on your own goals and aspirations.

Even though your dad may not be supportive right now, it doesn't mean that you should give up on college or your dreams. It may be helpful to have an open and honest conversation with him, expressing how you feel and explaining why "MYPlace" is the right choice for you. Sometimes, parents may not fully understand our perspective until we communicate our thoughts and feelings to them.

Additionally, if talking to your dad doesn't lead to a resolution, it might be helpful to seek support from other trusted individuals in your life, such as your stepmom, brothers, or a guidance counselor at school. They may be able to provide guidance, offer a different perspective, or even assist in facilitating a conversation with your dad.

Lastly, please remember that your mental health is crucial. If feelings of anxiety and depression persist, it may be beneficial to reach out to a mental health professional who can provide appropriate support and guidance in managing these emotions.

Stay strong and believe in yourself. You deserve to pursue your dreams and be supported in your decisions.

reply:
Hey there,

I'm sorry to hear about the difficult situation you're going through with your dad. It sounds like his reaction to your university choices has been hurtful and unsupportive, and I can understand how that would make you feel anxious and depressed. It's important to remember that your dad's response does not define your worth or intelligence. You have the right to pursue your own passions and dreams.

It might be helpful to have a calm and open conversation with your dad about your university choices. Share your reasons for wanting to attend "MYPlace" and explain why it's important to you. Let him know that you've considered all aspects, including the distance, and that you're confident in your ability to handle it. Sometimes, parents may have concerns or fears that they express in hurtful ways. By communicating with your dad and showing him that you've thought this through, you might be able to help him understand your perspective.

If talking to your dad doesn't lead to a resolution, consider reaching out to someone you trust for support, such as a relative, teacher, or counselor. They might be able to provide you with advice or mediation in your conversations with your dad. Additionally, the university you're interested in may have resources available for prospective students dealing with family conflicts.

Remember that you are not alone in this. Your boyfriend seems to be understanding and supportive, and having his encouragement can make a difference. It's essential that you prioritize your own dreams and aspirations, even if it feels challenging right now. Don't give up on college or your goal of becoming a nurse just because of this setback. Consider exploring alternative options, such as scholarships or financial aid, to help with any concerns you may have about finances.

Take care of yourself during this difficult time. Seek out opportunities for self-care, such as engaging in activities you enjoy or talking to someone about your feelings. Remember to be kind to yourself and trust in your own abilities. You have the strength to overcome this obstacle and pursue your dreams. Good luck with your university applications!

Hi there,

It sounds like you're going through a tough time with your dad's reaction to your university choices. It can be incredibly frustrating when our parents don't support our decisions. It's important to remember that this is your life and your future, and ultimately the decision should be yours.

It might be helpful to have a calm and open conversation with your dad about why attending "MYPlace" is important to you. Explain to him why this specific university aligns with your goals and aspirations. Sometimes, parents may not fully understand the reasoning behind our decisions until we take the time to explain it to them.

If your dad continues to oppose your choice, it might be worth seeking support from other family members or individuals who can advocate for you. Sometimes having someone else speak to your dad on your behalf can help him see things from a different perspective.

Remember, it's okay to feel anxious and depressed during this situation. It can be challenging when we feel unsupported by our loved ones. Don't give up on your dreams just because of your dad's reaction. Pursuing what you want in life is important, and you deserve to follow your passions.

Consider reaching out to a counselor or therapist who specializes in family dynamics. They can provide guidance and support during this difficult time. Remember, you're not alone, and there are people who care and want to help you navigate through this situation.

Hang in there and best of luck with your university applications!

post: I was 13 when me and my family moved from Hungary to Germany, now im 15. My past 2 years was all about me trying to accept a new lifestyle,trying to get friends and trying to be happy. I've been really struggling to basically just live here, and i still do, I feel like i threw my freedom away for a comfortbale life, and it defenetly didn't worth it. Everytime anyone asked this question : ,,and is it good in germany? " i always lied, and said ,, yeah, everythings fine" ,  i guess i just didn't want nobody to worry about me. My parents never asked me if i like it here, and i always whised that one day they will ask what's my opinion . They still haven't asked me yet. I just can't believe that they haven't noticed why did i change that much , i wish they were more caring. I'm not the people anymore, that i used to be, I often get angry at every little thing , I often forget my manners towards my own mother, and father. I know that some will think that this might be because of my puberty , but i don't think so. I've used to be a talkative, kind person with lot of friends, now i just sit in my room thinking about my old friends , barely talking to anyone in my school , not doing anything , being actually sad . I had to leave my friends , the girl i love and my home behind, all because my parents decided to move, I don't talk to my old friends , not because i don't want to, it's because they already got new friends to be with. and yeah i get only a tiny interrest from them . I also disappointing my family , everytime i do something wrong. I know that these things doesn't matter that much for them , but still i want to prove them that i'm not useless , i'm trying. I think i just failed as a son . I just can't believe that my life really got to this point where i'm having suicidal toughts at this young age... i don't think i deserved this. I told my parents that i don't like this life that we living, this was 2 weeks ago , I don't think that they care. The only people that keeps me alive is my online friend, who actually was my classmate for 3 years , it was a miracle a that we found each other, At least there's a little good among many bad. I finally let it out .
reply: Hey there, I just read your post and I wanted to say that you're incredibly brave for sharing your feelings. Moving to a new country can be really tough, and it's understandable that you're struggling to adjust. Remember, it's okay to feel this way. You're not alone in this. Have you considered talking to a counselor or reaching out to someone at school who can offer support? Sometimes it can help to have someone to talk to who can provide guidance and understanding. Keep hanging on and keep sharing your thoughts. You're stronger than you know. Sending you positive vibes! üí™üåü

post: I was 13 when me and my family moved from Hungary to Germany, now im 15. My past 2 years was all about me trying to accept a new lifestyle,trying to get friends and trying to be happy. I've been really struggling to basically just live here, and i still do, I feel like i threw my freedom away for a comfortbale life, and it defenetly didn't worth it. Everytime anyone asked this question : ,,and is it good in germany? " i always lied, and said ,, yeah, everythings fine" ,  i guess i just didn't want nobody to worry about me. My parents never asked me if i like it here, and i always whised that one day they will ask what's my opinion . They still haven't asked me yet. I just can't believe that they haven't noticed why did i change that much , i wish they were more caring. I'm not the people anymore, that i used to be, I often get angry at every little thing , I often forget my manners towards my own mother, and father. I know that some will think that this might be because of my puberty , but i don't think so. I've used to be a talkative, kind person with lot of friends, now i just sit in my room thinking about my old friends , barely talking to anyone in my school , not doing anything , being actually sad . I had to leave my friends , the girl i love and my home behind, all because my parents decided to move, I don't talk to my old friends , not because i don't want to, it's because they already got new friends to be with. and yeah i get only a tiny interrest from them . I also disappointing my family , everytime i do something wrong. I know that these things doesn't matter that much for them , but still i want to prove them that i'm not useless , i'm trying. I think i just failed as a son . I just can't believe that my life really got to this point where i'm having suicidal toughts at this young age... i don't think i deserved this. I told my parents that i don't like this life that we living, this was 2 weeks ago , I don't think that they care. The only people that keeps me alive is my online friend, who actually was my classmate for 3 years , it was a miracle a that we found each other, At least there's a little good among many bad. I finally let it out .
reply:
I'm sorry to hear that you're going through such a tough time, but know that you're not alone in feeling this way. Moving to a new country can be incredibly challenging, especially when you're trying to adapt to a new lifestyle and make new friends. It's not uncommon to feel like you've lost your freedom and struggle with finding happiness in your new surroundings.

It's unfortunate that your parents haven't asked for your opinion or noticed the changes in you. Sometimes, parents may not be aware of the extent of our struggles unless we explicitly communicate with them. It might be worth having a calm and open conversation with them about how you've been feeling and what you're going through. While it's not guaranteed that they will fully understand, expressing your thoughts and emotions can help alleviate some of the burden you're carrying.

Remember, it's normal to feel angry, sad, and even forget your manners during difficult times. It's a challenging adjustment, and it takes time to find your place and rebuild your life in a new country. Be kind to yourself and give yourself permission to take it one step at a time.

It's great that you have a supportive online friend who understands what you're going through. Connecting with others who have had similar experiences can provide valuable support and comfort. While they may not physically be there with you, having someone to talk to who can relate to your struggles can make a difference.

If your thoughts ever become overwhelming or you find yourself contemplating suicide, please reach out to a mental health professional or a helpline immediately. You deserve support and help during this challenging time, and there are people who care and want to assist you in overcoming these difficulties.

Remember, it's okay to ask for help and to lean on others when you're struggling. You are not alone in this journey, and there is hope for a brighter future.

post: I was 13 when me and my family moved from Hungary to Germany, now im 15. My past 2 years was all about me trying to accept a new lifestyle,trying to get friends and trying to be happy. I've been really struggling to basically just live here, and i still do, I feel like i threw my freedom away for a comfortbale life, and it defenetly didn't worth it. Everytime anyone asked this question : ,,and is it good in germany? " i always lied, and said ,, yeah, everythings fine" ,  i guess i just didn't want nobody to worry about me. My parents never asked me if i like it here, and i always whised that one day they will ask what's my opinion . They still haven't asked me yet. I just can't believe that they haven't noticed why did i change that much , i wish they were more caring. I'm not the people anymore, that i used to be, I often get angry at every little thing , I often forget my manners towards my own mother, and father. I know that some will think that this might be because of my puberty , but i don't think so. I've used to be a talkative, kind person with lot of friends, now i just sit in my room thinking about my old friends , barely talking to anyone in my school , not doing anything , being actually sad . I had to leave my friends , the girl i love and my home behind, all because my parents decided to move, I don't talk to my old friends , not because i don't want to, it's because they already got new friends to be with. and yeah i get only a tiny interrest from them . I also disappointing my family , everytime i do something wrong. I know that these things doesn't matter that much for them , but still i want to prove them that i'm not useless , i'm trying. I think i just failed as a son . I just can't believe that my life really got to this point where i'm having suicidal toughts at this young age... i don't think i deserved this. I told my parents that i don't like this life that we living, this was 2 weeks ago , I don't think that they care. The only people that keeps me alive is my online friend, who actually was my classmate for 3 years , it was a miracle a that we found each other, At least there's a little good among many bad. I finally let it out .
reply:
I want to start by acknowledging the pain and difficulty you have been experiencing since you moved to Germany. Adjusting to a new country, leaving behind friends and loved ones, and feeling disconnected from your old life can be incredibly challenging. It's understandable that you feel a sense of loss and sadness, as well as frustration with your family's lack of understanding.

It's important to remember that adolescence is a time of significant change, and it's not uncommon for individuals to experience a shift in their mood and behavior. However, I hear you when you say that these changes seem more than just typical puberty-related issues. It's important to explore these feelings further.

It might be helpful to find a trusted adult, such as a teacher, school counselor, or even a mental health professional, who can provide you with the support and guidance you need. They can help you navigate your emotions, improve communication with your family, and find healthy ways to cope with your difficulties.

Additionally, it's positive that you have an online friend who understands and supports you. Having a support system, even if it's virtual, can provide much-needed reassurance and companionship. It's important to continue reaching out to this friend and expressing yourself to someone who listens and validates your experiences.

It takes time to adjust to new situations, and it's normal to feel overwhelmed and even have thoughts about not wanting to go on. However, your feelings are valid, and there is help available. Please consider reaching out to a professional who can provide you with the guidance and support you deserve during this challenging time.

I also disappointing my family , everytime i do something wrong. I know that these things doesn't matter that much for them , but still i want to prove them that i'm not useless , i'm trying. I think i just failed as a son . I just can't believe that my life really got to this point where i'm having suicidal toughts at this young age... i don't think i deserved this. I told my parents that i don't like this life that we living, this was 2 weeks ago , I don't think that they care. The only people that keeps me alive is my online friend, who actually was my classmate for 3 years , it was a miracle a that we found each other, At least there's a little good among many bad. reply:
I'm so sorry to hear that you're feeling this way. Adjusting to a new country and lifestyle can be incredibly challenging, especially at such a young age. It's understandable that you feel like you've lost your freedom and struggle with loneliness and sadness.

It's important for you to know that you are not alone in these feelings. Many others have experienced similar difficulties when moving to a new country. It's completely normal to miss your friends, your home, and the life you had in Hungary. It can be especially tough when it feels like your parents don't understand or ask about how you're coping.

Remember, your emotions are valid, and it's essential to express them. It's great that you have your online friend who understands and supports you. Having someone to talk to can make a big difference. Consider reaching out to other support systems as well. Is there a school counselor or social worker you can talk to about what you're going through? They might be able to offer guidance and provide a safe space for you to share your feelings.

Additionally, finding new friends in Germany might feel overwhelming, but give yourself time and patience. Joining clubs or extracurricular activities at school can help you meet people with similar interests. It's okay to take small steps and not rush the process.

Lastly, it's important to prioritize your mental health. If you're experiencing thoughts of suicide, it's crucial to seek help immediately. Consider reaching out to a helpline or a mental health professional who can provide the support you need. Remember, there are people who care about you and want to help.

You've already shown great strength in sharing your feelings here, and that's a significant step forward. Keep reaching out and seeking support, because you deserve to be heard and supported during this difficult time.

post:
Hello fellow redditers. Please bear with this post. 

I need some advice.. I‚Äôm experiencing an existential crisis and the aspect of fleeting time is morbidly ruminating in my head, which is impairing my judgment here.

I‚Äôm a 25 y.o (M) based in Toronto. For context: my parents and I make up a family of 3. We immigrated here a decade back and have been struggling ever since. They are 65 and 60 and live pay cheque to paycheque with absolutely no assets, financial security nor social life. Moreover, my mom has been getting more vocal about how tired she is getting at work and just recently applied for her pension (which is a mere $100). My father is also still working but it‚Äôs hard on him too. They are in menial jobs with no qualifications to move to other seniorial positions. I have no siblings or relatives so it‚Äôs only us 3. We haven‚Äôt moved out of this same first apartment because they don‚Äôt have the credit and they fear not having a rent-stablized home they‚Äôd be able to afford, which makes the quality of life here a bit less than stellar considering the infestations we incur and I have severe allergies, so I‚Äôm highly bothered. Plus we‚Äôve, especially I‚Äôve, outgrown this space. 

My parents have given EVERYTHING their entire lives to provide for me and try to make it out of the Soviet Union and be successful. Once the Union fell, they lost everything. Started again from 0. I‚Äôm VERY close with them. My mom even worked in a factory for a few years when we first immigrated just so we could put food on the table and pay rent. She used to be a CEO before in Russia. Just this past year, they practically starved themselves to give me a year abroad doing my Masters, which mentally and physically destroyed them and I was reminded of it every single month, while I myself struggled abroad because I never had enough to meet needs. You can probably sense how much guilt and helplessness I feel.

Here is my dilemma: During this on-going existential crisis, I kept pondering how I need to live my life, ‚Äútake risks in my 20s,‚Äù but also build up my finances and have a vast array of experiences. I have SO many things I wanna do and see and after all, they brought me here for a better life. But MOST of which involve me living in Europe, that‚Äôs where my heart is. I‚Äôve grown a huge friend group there & have felt more alive than ever. BUT I worry their health will decline and recently read a book entitled 4000 weeks stating that our time is limited and I would be willingly losing months of my time with my parents (essentially whatever you give your time to, you‚Äôre openly giving up the time on something else). G-d knows what happens in a few months to years? And what, visit 3 times a year? That kills me beyond belief. And this is especially difficult because I have debts I have to help them clear, and they get immense joy from having me around to talk about work, go out on the weekends, make them feel less alone and stuck in a rat race they only get depressed about. And my father refuses to do anything with my mother for fun, so she only depends on me to do fun enjoyable things in the city. I know it makes life a bit more bearable. So to leave them completely alone, to thrive and risk losing that time but perhaps have some amazing experiences abroad  myself (as I feel very lonely and out of place here) feels paralyzing. And yes, I have a lot of ruminating anxiety, clearly. 

I should also mention they constantly remind me how much older they‚Äôre getting, their declining health, their fears of not seeing the world or even being able to make a living soon. They also remind me how I will have to take care of them financially and physically and how I should maximize my time with parents. They have attached their identities and purpose to me because as I said they have not succeeded in life, are lonely and have struggled/had very difficult childhoods themselves. Both of them experienced immense losses at an early age and took care of both of their mothers, as they raised me and struggled in my early infancy. When we moved here, they had to leave their mothers abroad in carers and my dad lost his mother from a phone call, after not having seen her for 2 years struggling to build a life in Canada and her dementia and health overtook her, she died alone. And my mom flew back every 3 years while her mother withered away alone in nursing home. This destroyed both of them, especially being away and financially not being able to help their families. 

This is also highly cultural as we are Russian-Jews. So I suppose a good deal of the emotional burden and guilt I feel has quite literally been passed through generations but I also can‚Äôt help but feel they‚Äôre right. They literally have no one but me. And are stating the facts of life currently for them. And I don‚Äôt want them to lie to myself and not tell me their own anxious thoughts and worries, even if it makes me MORE anxious. 

And here I am, I don‚Äôt know what to do from here. 

During COVID, I remote worked from home, and had the same routine, with no social outings, and I‚Äôm about to start another such job and I still have no friends here. The thought of doing that again is SO depressing to me and makes me resent myself for not living my life fully but also happy I can provide for my family and spend time with them. I‚Äôm literally 50/50. I also thought to just move downtown Toronto to live alone (as I‚Äôve never done and have always wanted to live alone esp with the apartment situation) but paying such outrageous prices, when I‚Äôd rather save the money for a trip with them or when I‚Äôd just rather live in Europe seems foolish. I also can‚Äôt help but feel I‚Äôd be abandoning them or willingly again taking time away from seeing them, even if I live 45 minutes down the subway line. I did that in first year of Uni and didn‚Äôt see them that often, maybe 10 times over 9 months. That seems pitiful.

Also, I really really REALLY wanna travel more and being in Europe would make me SO happy. But also when I lived abroad during this Masters year, I felt immense guilt, fleeting time and missed them indescribably bad to the point I wanted to come back at certain points but also was so sad when I came back because I mourned the experiences abroad. 

I‚Äôm SO SO SOOOOO conflicted. 

I don‚Äôt want to sit on my death bed regretting my 20s or the experiences I didn‚Äôt take. Similarly, I don‚Äôt wanna regret taking time away from being with the only people that I truly love and care for me, especially in their later years. 

I don‚Äôt know where the balance is.

Any advice? Please be brutally honest. 

TLDR; just graduated grad school, really close to aging lonely parents, want to move away to Europe where I thrive but harbour immense guilt and reminds of fleeting time leave me unable to take a decision and I don‚Äôt wanna grow resentful with myself.
reply:
Hey fellow Redditors! üåç I need your advice on a tough situation I'm facing. I'm a 25-year-old based in Toronto, alongside my parents who immigrated here years ago. They have sacrificed so much for me and are struggling financially at the moment. I have a deep desire to live in Europe, where I feel alive and have a great support system. However, I worry about leaving my aging parents and potentially missing out on valuable time with them. Their declining health and fear for the future add to my anxiety. Also, they rely on me for companionship and support. On the other hand, I don't want to regret not pursuing experiences and opportunities in my 20s. I feel torn and conflicted.

Any advice would be greatly appreciated! Please share your honest thoughts. Thank you in advance! üôè #FamilyDilemma #LifeChoices #FollowYourHeartOrStayWithFamily

reply:
Dear OP,

Firstly, I want to commend you for opening up and sharing your concerns. It's evident that you have a deep love and care for your parents, and the guilt and conflict you're experiencing are valid emotions.

Balancing personal desires and familial responsibilities can be incredibly challenging, especially when there are cultural factors and deep-rooted expectations involved. It's important to remember that no decision will come without some sacrifice or compromise. However, there are a few steps you can take to navigate this situation:

1. Self-reflection: Take some time to reflect on your own needs and aspirations. Consider what truly brings you joy and fulfillment. Understanding your own desires and finding a sense of purpose will help you make a decision that aligns with your own values.

2. Open communication: Sit down with your parents and have an open and honest conversation about your feelings and ambitions. Explain to them that you have an opportunity to create a life for yourself abroad, but also highlight your concerns about their health and well-being. Encourage them to openly express their desires and concerns as well. Together, you may find a middle ground or potential solutions that can alleviate some of the distress.

3. Exploration of options: Is it possible to spend extended periods of time with your parents while also fulfilling your desire to travel or live in Europe? Consider exploring options like temporary or part-time work arrangements that allow you to be present for your family while still pursuing your dreams. Alternatively, you could plan regular visits or coordinate your travels in a way that allows you to spend quality time with your parents.

4. Seek professional guidance: Speaking with a therapist or counselor can provide you with the necessary support and guidance to navigate this complex emotional landscape. They can help you explore your feelings, challenge any guilt or resentment, and develop coping strategies to manage the conflicting emotions.

Remember, life is rarely black and white, and there are no right or wrong answers. It's essential to find a balance that works for both you and your family. Take your time, be patient with yourself, and seek the support you need to make an informed decision.

Wishing you courage and clarity on your journey.

I don‚Äôt want to sit on my death bed regretting my 20s or the experiences I didn‚Äôt take. Similarly, I don‚Äôt wanna regret taking time away from being with the only people that I truly love and care for me, especially in their later years. 

I don‚Äôt know where the balance is.

Any advice? Please be brutally honest. 

TLDR; just graduated grad school, really close to aging lonely parents, want to move away to Europe where I thrive but harbour immense guilt and reminds of fleeting time leave me unable to take a decision and I don‚Äôt wanna grow resentful with myself.
reply:
I hear how torn you are between wanting to live your life fully, pursue your dreams, and experience the things that bring you joy, while also feeling a deep sense of responsibility and guilt towards your aging parents. It's clear that your parents have sacrificed a lot for you, and you genuinely care about their well-being.

It can be incredibly challenging to strike a balance between meeting your own needs and values, and being there for your loved ones. It's important to consider that finding this balance might not always mean splitting your time evenly between Europe and Toronto. 

Firstly, it might be helpful to have an open and honest conversation with your parents about your desires, fears, and concerns. Communication is crucial in any relationship, and understanding their perspective can give you a clearer picture of how they truly feel and what their expectations are. This conversation can provide you with valuable insights and help you make an informed decision.

Additionally, exploring other possibilities might be beneficial. For instance, are there ways for you to support your parents financially and emotionally while living in Europe? Can you establish a routine of regular communication and visits to ensure that you maintain a strong connection with them?

There might be creative solutions that allow you to pursue your dreams while still honoring your commitment to your parents. For example, you could consider working towards building financial stability before making a move to Europe or finding ways to be present and supportive from a distance.

Ultimately, the decision is yours to make, and it is important to prioritize your own well-being and happiness. It may also be helpful to seek therapy or counseling to navigate the complex emotions and dilemmas you are experiencing. A mental health professional can support you in exploring your values, setting goals, and finding strategies to manage the guilt and anxiety associated with this decision.

Remember, this is a process, and finding the right balance might require time and reflection. Your feelings are valid, and it's okay to be conflicted. Trust that you will make the best decision for yourself and your family, considering all the factors at play.

post:
Hello fellow redditers. Please bear with this post. 

I need some advice.. I‚Äôm experiencing an existential crisis and the aspect of fleeting time is morbidly ruminating in my head, which is impairing my judgment here.

I‚Äôm a 25 y.o (M) based in Toronto. For context: my parents and I make up a family of 3. We immigrated here a decade back and have been struggling ever since. They are 65 and 60 and live pay cheque to paycheque with absolutely no assets, financial security nor social life. Moreover, my mom has been getting more vocal about how tired she is getting at work and just recently applied for her pension (which is a mere $100). My father is also still working but it‚Äôs hard on him too. They are in menial jobs with no qualifications to move to other seniorial positions. I have no siblings or relatives so it‚Äôs only us 3. We haven‚Äôt moved out of this same first apartment because they don‚Äôt have the credit and they fear not having a rent-stablized home they‚Äôd be able to afford, which makes the quality of life here a bit less than stellar considering the infestations we incur and I have severe allergies, so I‚Äôm highly bothered. Plus we‚Äôve, especially I‚Äôve, outgrown this space. 

My parents have given EVERYTHING their entire lives to provide for me and try to make it out of the Soviet Union and be successful. Once the Union fell, they lost everything. Started again from 0. I‚Äôm VERY close with them. My mom even worked in a factory for a few years when we first immigrated just so we could put food on the table and pay rent. She used to be a CEO before in Russia. Just this past year, they practically starved themselves to give me a year abroad doing my Masters, which mentally and physically destroyed them and I was reminded of it every single month, while I myself struggled abroad because I never had enough to meet needs. You can probably sense how much guilt and helplessness I feel.

Here is my dilemma: During this on-going existential crisis, I kept pondering how I need to live my life, ‚Äútake risks in my 20s,‚Äù but also build up my finances and have a vast array of experiences. I have SO many things I wanna do and see and after all, they brought me here for a better life. But MOST of which involve me living in Europe, that‚Äôs where my heart is. I‚Äôve grown a huge friend group there & have felt more alive than ever. BUT I worry their health will decline and recently read a book entitled 4000 weeks stating that our time is limited and I would be willingly losing months of my time with my parents (essentially whatever you give your time to, you‚Äôre openly giving up the time on something else). G-d knows what happens in a few months to years? And what, visit 3 times a year? That kills me beyond belief. And this is especially difficult because I have debts I have to help them clear, and they get immense joy from having me around to talk about work, go out on the weekends, make them feel less alone and stuck in a rat race they only get depressed about. And my father refuses to do anything with my mother for fun, so she only depends on me to do fun enjoyable things in the city. I know it makes life a bit more bearable. So to leave them completely alone, to thrive and risk losing that time but perhaps have some amazing experiences abroad  myself (as I feel very lonely and out of place here) feels paralyzing. And yes, I have a lot of ruminating anxiety, clearly. 

I should also mention they constantly remind me how much older they‚Äôre getting, their declining health, their fears of not seeing the world or even being able to make a living soon. They also remind me how I will have to take care of them financially and physically and how I should maximize my time with parents. They have attached their identities and purpose to me because as I said they have not succeeded in life, are lonely and have struggled/had very difficult childhoods themselves. Both of them experienced immense losses at an early age and took care of both of their mothers, as they raised me and struggled in my early infancy. When we moved here, they had to leave their mothers abroad in carers and my dad lost his mother from a phone call, after not having seen her for 2 years struggling to build a life in Canada and her dementia and health overtook her, she died alone. And my mom flew back every 3 years while her mother withered away alone in nursing home. This destroyed both of them, especially being away and financially not being able to help their families. 

This is also highly cultural as we are Russian-Jews. So I suppose a good deal of the emotional burden and guilt I feel has quite literally been passed through generations but I also can‚Äôt help but feel they‚Äôre right. They literally have no one but me. And are stating the facts of life currently for them. And I don‚Äôt want them to lie to myself and not tell me their own anxious thoughts and worries, even if it makes me MORE anxious. 

And here I am, I don‚Äôt know what to do from here. 

During COVID, I remote worked from home, and had the same routine, with no social outings, and I‚Äôm about to start another such job and I still have no friends here. The thought of doing that again is SO depressing to me and makes me resent myself for not living my life fully but also happy I can provide for my family and spend time with them. I‚Äôm literally 50/50. I also thought to just move downtown Toronto to live alone (as I‚Äôve never done and have always wanted to live alone esp with the apartment situation) but paying such outrageous prices, when I‚Äôd rather save the money for a trip with them or when I‚Äôd just rather live in Europe seems foolish. I also can‚Äôt help but feel I‚Äôd be abandoning them or willingly again taking time away from seeing them, even if I live 45 minutes down the subway line. I did that in first year of Uni and didn‚Äôt see them that often, maybe 10 times over 9 months. That seems pitiful.

Also, I really really REALLY wanna travel more and being in Europe would make me SO happy. But also when I lived abroad during this Masters year, I felt immense guilt, fleeting time and missed them indescribably bad to the point I wanted to come back at certain points but also was so sad when I came back because I mourned the experiences abroad. 

I‚Äôm SO SO SOOOOO conflicted. 

I don‚Äôt want to sit on my death bed regretting my 20s or the experiences I didn‚Äôt take. Similarly, I don‚Äôt wanna regret taking time away from being with the only people that I truly love and care for me, especially in their later years. 

I don‚Äôt know where the balance is.

Any advice? Please be brutally honest. 

TLDR; just graduated grad school, really close to aging lonely parents, want to move away to Europe where I thrive but harbour immense guilt and reminds of fleeting time leave me unable to take a decision and I don‚Äôt wanna grow resentful with myself.
reply:
Hello,

I can understand that you're going through a difficult and conflicting situation. It's clear that you have a deep love and concern for your parents, which is admirable. It's also natural to have aspirations and dreams for your own life.

To find a balance between your desire to explore and your love for your parents, it might be helpful to consider some potential options. First, you could try discussing your thoughts and feelings openly with your parents. This could help you understand their perspective better and allow them to express their own desires, enabling both parties to find common ground.

Another option could be to explore the possibility of spending extended periods of time in Europe, while also maintaining regular contact with your parents through video calls and visits. This way, you can continue building your own experiences while still being there for your parents in important moments.

Additionally, it might be beneficial for you to seek support from a therapist or counselor who can provide guidance and help you navigate your conflicting emotions. They can help you develop coping strategies and assist in making difficult decisions.

Remember to be patient with yourself throughout this process. It's not easy to balance your own desires with your responsibilities towards your loved ones. Take the time to reflect on what truly matters to you and what will bring you the most fulfillment in the long run.

I hope this advice provides some clarity and helps you move forward. Take care of yourself and I wish you all the best in finding the balance that works for you.

reply:
Hello there,

It sounds like you're in a difficult and deeply conflicted situation. I can sense the love and care you have for your parents, as well as your desire to live your own life and pursue your own dreams. It's important to acknowledge the emotional burden that has been passed down through generations and the cultural expectations you may be grappling with.

First of all, it's important to recognize that finding the perfect balance may be challenging and may come with certain sacrifices. However, here are a few points to consider as you navigate this decision-making process:

1. Open and Honest Communication: Sit down with your parents and have a heartfelt conversation about your desires, ambitions, and fears. It's crucial to create an environment where everyone can express their emotions, concerns, and hopes. This way, you can have a better understanding of each other's perspectives and work towards finding a solution that works for everyone.

2. Long-term Planning: Consider creating a long-term plan that addresses your financial responsibilities towards your parents while still allowing you to pursue your dreams. This could involve finding ways to support them financially from abroad or exploring options for them to improve their own financial situation.

3. Quality vs. Quantity: Remember that quality time with your parents can be just as important as the quantity of time spent together. While distance may limit face-to-face interaction, you can still find ways to create meaningful connections through regular video calls, sending cards or care packages, and planning visits during holidays or special occasions.

4. Personal Growth and Well-being: It's crucial to prioritize your own personal growth and well-being. Living in Europe, pursuing your dreams, and cultivating a sense of belonging can greatly impact your own happiness and mental well-being. Remember that taking care of yourself is essential in being able to care for others.

5. Seek Professional Support: Consider reaching out to a mental health professional who can help you explore your thoughts and feelings in a safe and non-judgmental space. They can provide guidance in navigating these complex emotions and assist you in finding clarity and peace of mind.

Lastly, remember that there is no one-size-fits-all solution to this dilemma. What works for one person may not work for another. Take some time for self-reflection, listen to your intuition, and trust that you will find a path forward that aligns with your values and priorities.

Take care of yourself, and I wish you all the best in finding the right balance for both yourself and your parents.

post:
I get a job I try hard I realise I hate everything about it and I‚Äôd rather be depressed incessantly reading and eating a pot noodle once a day. I‚Äôm losing sleep, somehow eating less than I did a week ago, I have the stress lump in my throat and then I quit. 

It‚Äôs not going to click. Like it‚Äôs not all one day going to go away. It‚Äôs a gradual thing it‚Äôs acting before you believe. It‚Äôs accepting help. It‚Äôs trying to be positive, do yoga, read the news less read the news more drink less have more coffee have less. It‚Äôs all the same.

I‚Äôm so weary of this man, I just can‚Äôt take stress and worry. I wish I was a kid again. It feels so long ago but I turned 18 just 5 years ago and here I am. Where did this black dog come from, who let it cloud my days with rain and bites.

Cheers from Scotland üè¥Û†ÅßÛ†Å¢Û†Å≥Û†Å£Û†Å¥Û†Åø

reply:
Hey there, 

I'm sorry to hear that you're feeling so overwhelmed and stuck in a job that you hate. It's tough when we realize that our current situation is not aligning with our happiness and well-being. It sounds like you're experiencing a lot of stress and anxiety, and that can be really challenging to manage on a day-to-day basis.

Remember, you're not alone in feeling this way. Many people go through periods of dissatisfaction with their jobs, and it can be really draining on our mental health. It's important to take a step back and evaluate what changes you might be able to make to improve your situation.

Have you considered seeking support from a mental health professional? They can provide guidance and help you navigate through these difficult emotions. Additionally, talking to friends or loved ones about what you're going through can also be beneficial. Sometimes, simply sharing our feelings out loud can help relieve some of the burden.

It's great that you're open to trying new things like yoga, reading less news, or adjusting your diet. Remember that it takes time for these changes to fully resonate with us and have a positive impact on our mental well-being. So be patient with yourself. Finding what works for you might take some trial and error, and that's completely normal.

Lastly, being nostalgic about being a kid again is something many of us experience. It's important to acknowledge those feelings but also focus on the present and what steps you can take to improve your current situation. Remember, you have the power within you to make changes and create a life that brings you happiness and fulfillment.

Take care of yourself and know that there is support out there for you. Keep reaching out and seeking help. You deserve to find joy in your life. Sending positive thoughts your way from a fellow community member.

post:
I‚Äôve been stressed out from a very young age, because I always had the feeling that I needed to be perfect, so I would stress over anything I did, school, hobbies, how other‚Äôs perceive me, what I say. Up until junior and senior year of high school the stress and anxiety I got from talking to other people was so powerful that I just wouldn‚Äôt do it. If I did I would go home and overthink every single word, it was exhausting and to be honest these are the most vivid parts of my childhood and teenage years, the amount of stress I would feel. I tried to change when I went on to uni, the social anxiety part got better, not solved but better, and yet i found stress in everything else, especially after finding out my uni had rankings and that there would be benefits like better exchange programs etc. Then the pandemic and the war in Ukraine made it even worse (i‚Äôm from eastern europe very close to Ukraine) 

I‚Äôm tired of being stressed all the time, for the past 4 years I‚Äôve seen physical effects of it as well. I had heart palpitations for a while, two years ago I started stress eating, i wake up feeling exhausted, I have episodes of nausea and headaches. I just want it to stop and everytime i think I‚Äôm on the right track it comes back stronger and I genuinely cannot see an end to this. A lot of it comes from self doubt and not feeling good enough. Does anyone have any tips on getting over this? I‚Äôm worried that if I go on like this I‚Äôll see even worse physical effects in the future.
reply:
Hey there, I'm really sorry to hear that you're going through such a tough time. Stress and anxiety can be really overwhelming, but remember that you're not alone in this. It's brave of you to reach out and seek help.

Firstly, it's important to acknowledge that nobody is perfect, and that's absolutely okay. Practicing self-compassion can go a long way in easing your self-doubt. Remember to be kind to yourself and celebrate your achievements, no matter how small they may seem.

When it comes to managing stress, finding healthy coping mechanisms is crucial. Consider trying relaxation techniques like deep breathing exercises, meditation, or even journaling. These activities can provide a sense of calm and help you release some of the tension.

Additionally, seeking support from friends or loved ones can make a big difference. Surround yourself with positive influences who uplift and encourage you. If you feel comfortable, consider discussing your struggles with someone you trust‚Äîthey might have helpful insights or suggestions.

It's also important to prioritize self-care. Engage in activities that bring you joy and help you unwind. Taking breaks from social media or setting boundaries with it can also reduce feelings of stress and comparison.

Remember that changing our mindset and habits takes time, so be patient with yourself. Consider seeking professional help as well, such as therapy or counseling. Qualified professionals can provide guidance and support tailored to your specific needs.

Take small steps towards self-improvement and focus on progress rather than perfection. You deserve to live a fulfilled and happy life, free from excessive stress. Stay strong, and know that there are people out here rooting for you! üí™‚ú®

Therapy can offer a safe space for you to explore and work through these challenging emotions.

Remember, you're not alone in this journey. Take it one step at a time and don't hesitate to seek help from professionals who are trained to support you. You deserve to find relief from the constant stress and anxiety. Stay strong and keep reaching out for the support you need.

I'm sorry to hear that you're going through such a difficult time. It takes a lot of courage to reach out and ask for help. While I can't provide therapy or a diagnosis, I can offer some general suggestions that might be helpful.

Firstly, it's important to remember that you are not alone in feeling this way. Many people struggle with the pressure to be perfect and the anxiety that comes with it. It might be helpful to connect with individuals who can relate to your experiences, either through support groups or online communities.

One suggestion could be seeking professional help. Consider reaching out to a therapist or counselor who specializes in anxiety or stress management. They can provide you with personalized strategies and techniques to manage your stress levels and work through your self-doubt.

Another way to cope with stress is through self-care. Engage in activities that you enjoy and help you relax. Practice mindfulness or meditation to help calm your mind. Make sure you're getting enough rest, eating well, and taking care of your physical health as well.

It might also be beneficial to challenge your negative thoughts and beliefs. Self-doubt often stems from distorted thinking patterns. Consider working with a therapist or using self-help resources, such as books or online courses, that teach cognitive-behavioral techniques to reframe negative thoughts.

Finally, don't hesitate to lean on your support system. Talk to friends or family about what you're going through. They can offer a listening ear and emotional support. Sometimes just being able to vent and express your feelings can be incredibly helpful.

Remember, recovery takes time and setbacks are common. Be patient and kind to yourself throughout the process. Keep seeking support and trying different strategies until you find what works best for you. You deserve to live a life free from constant stress and self-doubt.

reply:
I'm sorry to hear that you've been feeling stressed for such a long time. It can be really tough to constantly feel the need to be perfect and worry about how others perceive you. It's positive that your social anxiety has improved since going to university, but it sounds like stress still affects different areas of your life. The added pressures of rankings and the current situation with the pandemic and war in Ukraine must be making things even more challenging for you.

Firstly, please remember that you are not alone in feeling this way. Many people struggle with self-doubt and not feeling good enough. It's important to be kind to yourself and remember that no one is perfect.

In terms of tips for managing stress, it's important to find healthy coping mechanisms that work for you. Some suggestions include:

1. Seek support: Consider talking to a mental health professional, such as a therapist or counselor. They can help you work through your stress and self-doubt, and provide you with strategies to manage them.

2. Practice self-care: Take time for activities that bring you joy and relaxation, such as taking walks in nature, listening to music, practicing mindfulness or meditation, or engaging in hobbies that you enjoy.

3. Set realistic goals: Instead of striving for perfection, try setting small, achievable goals for yourself. Celebrate your successes, no matter how small they may seem.

4. Challenge negative thoughts: Practice reframing negative thoughts and replacing them with more positive and realistic ones. Remember that you are capable and deserving of success.

5. Prioritize self-compassion: Treat yourself with kindness and understanding. Remember that it's okay to make mistakes and that everyone has their own unique journey.

6. Seek social support: Engage with friends or loved ones who are understanding and supportive. Sharing your thoughts and feelings with someone you trust can provide relief and a sense of connection.

7. Take care of your physical health: Make sure you are getting enough sleep, eating a balanced diet, and engaging in regular exercise. These factors can have a positive impact on your overall well-being.

Remember, overcoming chronic stress takes time and effort. Be patient with yourself and celebrate the progress you make along the way. If you continue to struggle, reach out to a mental health professional who can provide you with more personalized guidance. You deserve a life free from constant stress, and with the right support and strategies, it is possible to find relief.

post:
39M (Sweden), 177 cm, 90 kg

Hey! Ok, I ask you to read below and try to put yourself in my situation.

2021-04-13:
Long story short. Had been suffering from a long-lasting cough (5-6 weeks) and sought care. The doctor heard something on the left lung and sent me for an urgent x-ray the same day.  I was terrified and thought I had lung cancer.  I was nervous and scared to death until I got my test results back.  It showed nothing but I recovered a few days later.

2021-09-14:
My wife found a liver spot/mole on my back that looked weird. This after I had complained of itching in that place 1-2 months earlier. Thought it was skin cancer and was nervous and scared to death for several weeks before I received an answer that there was no danger. The mole didn't look "bad" so they didn't do anything about it.

2021-10-07:
My wife finds a lump on the right shoulder blade, size approx. 1x1 cm. It can be moved but feels strange somehow.  Immediately becomes completely convinced that this is also a cancerous tumor.  Either the skin cancer has spread or it is a sarcoma (soft tissue cancer that can feel exactly like a fatty lump). Once again, I became very nervous, stressed and scared to death. I sought care and was able to see a reputable doctor who informed me that it was a lipoma. When he was about to take it away, he says he can't find it.  I imagined he saw it and it wasn't a lipoma.  He said something to the other doctor and I didn't really understand where.  He you catch me again and the lump is still there.  Instead, he sends me for an urgent MR X-ray and here I am completely destroyed.  I take him as if he has seen something that makes him not dare to cut me.  I lie at home and shake for several days and have such fear of death that it is completely sick. I end up trying to go into that X-ray tunnel but it doesn't work. Tries 3-4 times but I just lie there and cry because I'm afraid of what the x-ray will show.  Here I am completely convinced that it is cancer of some kind.  I had to cancel everything and today the lump is still there.  The doctor called me 3 weeks later and said he was 100% sure it was a lipoma and that it can stay on my body without doing any harm. So, I still have it and I'm alive.

During this course of "diseases" I get hemorrhoids and start having stomach problems.  I still have huge problems with my stomach (heartburn, acid regurgitation, irregular stools, stomach pain, stomach cramps, etc.).

I'm simply wondering if this could be the result of some kind of stress, nervousness, panic disorder, death anxiety over an extended period of time?

Note: I have never before had "problems" with my stomach (that I know of) but after the above events it is in total revolt.

Please write a line or two what you think.

Sorry for a long post, but it's important and nice for me to write a little.

Thanks!
reply: Hey there! I'm really sorry to hear about all the health scares you've been going through. It's completely understandable that you've been feeling nervous and scared. Sometimes, prolonged stress and anxiety can have physical effects on our bodies, including digestive issues like the ones you're experiencing. It might be a good idea to speak to a healthcare professional about these symptoms just to rule out any underlying causes. Hang in there and take care!

post: I'm a guy from Lithuania. I'm 12 years old and I tried suicide and sh. Everything I do I'm just so shit at. I feel empty and drained. I overthink so much I feel like painting the walls red would be good.  But well. 1 month ago I got a girlfriend now she's the only thing I have left. Her name is Rusne. It's a Lithuanian name. If I lose her I'm either gonna kxms or go really insane. I feel like as I'm not good enough. Im trying to show as much love as I can. I can't lose her. I really can't. Middle school love might seem cringe but I swear, she's the only thing I have. She's the best person I've ever met. Let me tell you about my backstory or whatever you'd call it. From last year everything went downhill. I felt like I was gonna end it all. It's been almost a year and I still haven't done it. I'm still trying, but I'm really close. I now see the changes in myself. Behaviour, looks, basically my whole personality changed. I mean I like it but some things are bad. Like I don't even give a shit now. My grades are getting worse and shit. But I finnaly couldnt hold it in. Recently I opened up to my parents. At the start it looked like they're acctually helping me and I'm getting better, until... They used it against me. I couldnt believe it. Shit. Next Time you guys wanna open up do it with a person you REALLY REALLY trust.
reply:
Hey, I just wanted to say that I hear you and I'm really sorry to hear that you're feeling this way. It must be incredibly tough, but I'm glad you reached out. Remember that you're not alone, and there are people who care about you, including your girlfriend Rusne. She sounds really special to you. It's great that you have someone who makes you feel loved and supported.

I understand that things have been difficult for you, and it's brave of you to open up to your parents. It's unfortunate that they didn't handle it the way you expected, but please don't give up on seeking help. Consider talking to a counselor or a trusted adult who can support you and provide the help you need.

You're not defined by your grades or any mistakes you might have made. You deserve love and understanding, especially from yourself. Take small steps towards self-care and focus on the things that bring you joy. Remember, it's okay to ask for help when you need it. Stay strong, and reach out to those who can support you through this.

post:
I‚Äôm from Ireland but am studying in England. I have 2 contact hours a day, 3 days a week. The rest of the week I spend at work. If I‚Äôm not in Uni or at work, I‚Äôm in bed. Not doing course work, not tidying the flat or going for walks or hanging out with friends nor doing any of the things I like. Just in bed.

I can‚Äôt find the motivation to do anything, the only reason I get up for work is because I will literally be homeless if I don‚Äôt. I can‚Äôt even enjoy a few pints with friends or have a nice date with my girlfriend or else I feel an enormous amount of shame and dread that I won‚Äôt be able to cover my rent and bills. I have no financial support other than asking my parents to help me out every so often. But that just makes me feel worse, they shouldn‚Äôt need to bail me out. Even when I spend money on necessary things like groceries or travel fair I feel shame.

And with uni work‚Ä¶ we‚Äôll I‚Äôm a procrastinator. And not in the fun relatable way. I‚Äôm pretty sure what is the equivalent of my dissertation is going to be done in its entirety the night before it is due as well as all of my other assignments. If I fail this course I honestly have no clue what I am going to do with my life. I don‚Äôt think I have any applicable skills at all. I wouldn‚Äôt be too ashamed to move back in with my parents in Ireland for a little while but I‚Äôm getting too old now to not be able to earn any skills that‚Äôll get me a decent job.

That‚Äôs another thing. I‚Äôm 24, most people in my year are about 20. I know this is just an ‚Äúage is just a number‚Äù thing and I don‚Äôt want to make any mature students feel discouraged. But I can‚Äôt help but let it get to me. I feel like that time of my life where I am meant to develop is finished. Now my brain is done absorbing information and it didn‚Äôt even manage to absorb anything fucking useful. There are people who I know, who I went to school with with small businesses and children. I had my chance, and I chose to sleep in.

It‚Äôs not like I haven‚Äôt tried anything. I‚Äôm just bad at keeping up with anything. I tried cognitive behavioural therapy, to get me more in a productive routine so that when leisure time would come around I wouldn‚Äôt feel so bad. Tried that for months to no avail. The only thing to come out of it was my therapist telling me I was depressed. Well at least I know for sure now.

Can‚Äôt afford 1 to 1 therapy so I‚Äôm just living with it right now, and deadlines are charging me down like a parade of bulls. And bills and rent are sucking me dry. The only thing that doesn‚Äôt seem to cost me money or energy is sleeping. It‚Äôs a vicious cycle and I want out but I don‚Äôt know how.
reply:
Hey everyone, I could really use some advice here. I'm currently studying in England but feeling incredibly stuck and unmotivated. I only have a few contact hours a week and spend the rest of my time working just to make ends meet. It's taking a toll on me mentally and emotionally.

I have this constant fear of not being able to cover my rent and bills, so I can't even enjoy socializing or doing things I love without feeling shame and dread. I hate relying on my parents for financial help and even spending money on basic necessities adds to my guilt.

On top of that, I'm a chronic procrastinator and I'm terrified that I'll end up frantically completing my assignments right before the deadline. Failing this course would be devastating, and I feel like I have no applicable skills to secure a decent job.

To make matters worse, I'm 24 and most of my peers are much younger. It's really getting to me and making me feel like I've missed my chance to develop and succeed. I've tried therapy before, even CBT to establish a productive routine, but it hasn't worked for me. And now I can't afford one-on-one therapy, so I'm feeling pretty stuck.

I'm stuck in this vicious cycle and I need to break free. Any suggestions or advice would be greatly appreciated. Thanks in advance! #HelpNeeded #StuckAndLost

reply:
I'm sorry to hear that you're feeling this way. It sounds like you're dealing with a lot of stress and pressure, both academically and financially. It's quite common for the weight of all these responsibilities to become overwhelming and affect our motivation and mental well-being.

Firstly, I want to assure you that age is definitely not a determining factor when it comes to personal growth and development. Each person's journey is different, and it's never too late to acquire new skills or change career paths. Remember, life is a marathon, not a race.

While it's understandable that therapy might not be accessible for you right now, there are still some self-help strategies you can try. One approach you could consider is exploring different forms of therapy that are more affordable or even free. There are often helplines, online forums, and support groups that can provide guidance and lend an understanding ear.

Additionally, small steps can make a big difference in breaking the cycle you feel trapped in. Rather than focusing on the overwhelming nature of deadlines and responsibilities, try breaking them down into small, manageable tasks. Creating a to-do list and prioritizing tasks can give you a sense of accomplishment as you check them off one by one. Remember, progress is progress, no matter how small.

It might also be helpful to incorporate activities you enjoy into your routine. Even if it's just for a short period each day, engaging in activities that bring you pleasure and relaxation can help lift your mood and reduce feelings of shame and dread. Setting aside time for self-care is essential, especially during challenging times.

Lastly, remember that it's okay to ask for help. Reach out to trusted friends, family, or professors who may be able to offer support or guidance. Sometimes sharing your struggles can provide much-needed relief and open up possibilities for assistance you may not have considered.

Take things one step at a time, be patient with yourself, and remember that you are not alone. You have the strength to overcome this difficult period and find a way forward.

Hey there, I'm sorry to hear that you're going through such a tough time right now. It sounds like you're feeling overwhelmed and stuck in a cycle of low motivation and depression. Remember, you're not alone in this.

One thing to keep in mind is that it's completely normal to struggle with motivation and feel lost at times, regardless of age or background. You are capable of making positive changes in your life, and it's never too late to learn new skills or pursue your passions.

Have you considered reaching out to your university's counseling services? They might have resources available to help you manage your depression and provide support during this time. Additionally, talking to someone you trust, like a friend or family member, about what you're going through could provide you with some comfort and perspective.

Although you mentioned that 1-to-1 therapy is currently out of your budget, there are often low-cost or sliding-scale therapy options available. You could explore community mental health centers or online counseling platforms that offer more affordable rates. Remember that seeking professional help is a sign of strength, and it can provide you with the guidance and tools you need to break free from this cycle.

In the meantime, try to set small, achievable goals for yourself. Break down your assignments into smaller tasks and tackle them one at a time. Celebrate even the smallest accomplishments as they can help boost your motivation. Alongside your responsibilities, make time for self-care activities that bring you joy and help you relax.

Remember, it's important to be kind to yourself during this challenging period. Recovery takes time, and setbacks are a natural part of the process. Stay connected with your support system, find healthy coping mechanisms, and remember that you are not defined by your current circumstances. You have the strength to overcome this and create a brighter future for yourself.
