It‚Äôs not like I haven‚Äôt tried anything. I‚Äôm just bad at keeping up with anything. I tried cognitive behavioural therapy, to get me more in a productive routine so that when leisure time would come around I wouldn‚Äôt feel so bad. Tried that for months to no avail. The only thing to come out of it was my therapist telling me I was depressed. Well at least I know for sure now.

Can‚Äôt afford 1 to 1 therapy so I‚Äôm just living with it right now, and deadlines are charging me down like a parade of bulls. And bills and rent are sucking me dry. The only thing that doesn‚Äôt seem to cost me money or energy is sleeping. It‚Äôs a vicious cycle and I want out but I don‚Äôt know how.
reply:
Hey there,

I'm really sorry to hear that you're going through such a challenging time right now. It's great that you reached out for support, as discussing your feelings and experiences can be a helpful step towards finding ways to improve your situation.

Firstly, please know that the way you're feeling is valid, and many people go through similar struggles. It sounds like you're experiencing a lack of motivation, feeling overwhelmed with financial burdens, and a sense of shame and dread. These feelings can definitely take a toll on your mental health.

While I can't provide the specific help you need, I encourage you to explore some options that could potentially support you. Since you mentioned being in the UK, it might be worth looking into mental health resources available to you as a student. Universities often have counseling services that may offer support at reduced or no cost. Additionally, there might be community organizations or helplines that can provide assistance and guidance.

Although it may feel like you're alone, remember that seeking help is a sign of strength, not weakness. You're taking the first courageous steps by reaching out and expressing your concerns. Keep in mind that recovery takes time, and finding the right support system can make a significant difference.

In the meantime, it might also help to explore small changes in your daily routine. Even taking small steps towards self-care, such as going for a short walk or engaging in activities you enjoy, can positively impact your mood and motivation levels. Setting achievable goals and breaking down tasks into smaller, manageable steps can also make them feel less overwhelming.

Finally, try to be kind and patient with yourself as you navigate this difficult period. Remember that age is just a number, and people progress at different rates. Your journey is unique, and it's never too late to learn and develop new skills.

Take care of yourself, and don't hesitate to keep seeking support from professionals who specialize in mental health. You deserve to find a way out of this cycle and live a fulfilling life.

post:
I'm so angry, I've known my parents were homophobic and transphobic from a young age. But I was blind to their racism because my father served a mostly African church (we're white). We lived in a mostly black town, and we live in a mostly Latino area now (but our congregation is yt). But now that I am an adult and especially after 2020 my eyes have been completely open to their behavior. Especially my mom, she says hateful and vile things towards people of other races, she said the N WORD! Just tonight she called my young neice who is half mexican only 'half bad". My parents do not understand how they are racist. Even when I blatently call them out   


I warned my roommate of my parents racism already and they made the decision to call the school to see if they can move dorms becuase they may find it necessary. At first I was upset but like an hour later hearing possibly the most racist jokes thus far I agree. I have spoken to them and told them I'm not really going to invite them or even want them to come up to visit at all, and I'm planning to hopefully cut them off. But that all depends especially if I get this job.   


And now I'm questioning if my roommate will be comfortable with ME if I choose to become a dispatcher for our campus police. But I can't cut my parents off if I don't. I need the money which is the only reason I'd do it.   


They have always made everyone around me (including myself) uncomfortable with their various forms of bigotry. I can not allow them to keep doing this.
reply:
Feeling incredibly frustrated right now. Growing up, I was aware of my parents' homophobic and transphobic views, but I only recently discovered their racism. My mom has been saying some truly hateful things about people of other races, and it's gotten to the point where she used a racial slur. Tonight, she even made a hurtful comment about my young niece who is half Mexican. Despite my attempts to call them out, they just don't understand how they're being racist.

I had warned my roommate about my parents' racism, and they're now considering requesting a room change at school because of it. Initially, I was upset, but after hearing yet another racist joke just an hour ago, I completely understand and agree with their decision. I've already expressed to my parents that I don't want them visiting me or being a part of my life anymore, and I'm seriously thinking about cutting them off completely. However, it all depends on whether or not I get this job that I need for financial reasons.

My parents have always made everyone, including me, uncomfortable with their bigotry. I can't let them continue behaving this way. On a separate note, I'm now worried if my roommate will feel uncomfortable with me if I end up becoming a dispatcher for our campus police. But I can't cut my parents off if I don't take the job, as I really need the money. Tough choices ahead, but I know I can't allow their toxic behavior to continue. #StandingUpAgainstRacism #LifeDecisions

Regarding your roommate, it's great that you already had an open conversation with them about your parents' racism. It shows that you value their comfort and are considerate of their feelings. Take care of yourself and prioritize your own well-being. You deserve to be surrounded by people who respect and support you.

post:
A little preface - what the post is about:
I live in a country that is at war.
I can't find a job despite it is required of me.
I found a calling that I love, but parents don't let me do it.
I can't find a girl.
I am overweight.

Firstly, I graduated from the Ukrainian IT University 3 years ago.
In my third year of college, I realized that I didn't want to be a programmer, even though I had excellent grades.
I hate coding. Absolutely everything related to debugging code causes me uncontrollable anger and frustration. I can no longer spend 3 hours looking for a solution to 5 errors in the code that have nothing to do with the logic of the algorithm and are caused only by the specifics of the programming language. Even the thought that I need to learn a programming language makes my hands tremble and makes me irritable.
After graduating from college, I told my mom that I didn't want to be a programmer and I didn't want to go to an IT university. I want to find what I like in life.
The mother replied: ‚ÄúDo you understand what you are going to live on while you are looking for yourself? Without education, you will not be hired anywhere. Finish university, get a job, and then do whatever you want with your life."
In the end, I did. All the time I was studying, I thought that all the roads were open in front of me and I could do anything in life. I thought only lazy people can't find a job. As a student, I could find any part-time job at gas stations, call centers and ‚ÄúMcDonalds‚Äùs. I thought that when I graduated from university, I would take my diploma, go to the lowest paid job as a programmer, after a couple of years I would plow there, and try new things in my free time. That‚Äôs how I thoght until I graduated from university that I realized how wrong I was.
As soon as I graduated from university, all the "doors" of employers for students were closed. No one read my resume on job sites, my phone never rang. Attempts to look for work not in my specialty were also unsuccessful. Only then did I realize that in fact all the doors closed for me at the age of 15, when I first crossed the threshold of my IT college.
The main problem is that IT colleges and IT universities do not teach the necessary knowledge for work. It doesn't bother anyone at all. In Ukrainian colleges, they will forcefully teach a ton of useless subjects in modern meta-coding - from numerical methods to patent law. When I opened the job requirements, I lost heart. I spent 8 years studying to say that I know object oriented programming, I know 1997 database technologies and I can write code in 5 programming languages. But what else do I need:
- Framework #1 - unstudied
- Framework #2 - unstudied
- Framework #3 - unstudied
- Git technology - unlearned
- Modern wrapper for databases NameA - did not sound.
- I have no real experience with real projects from one year.
- I don't have a portfolio of works.
While I was "looking for a job" after a bad experience as a gas station cashier, I tried my hand at editing videos for YouTube. I have never been so inspired by what I do. The progress in motivation compared to what it was with programming was incredible for me. I worked on videos for 12 hours a day. When I started uploading videos, I saw that I get 100-300 views on the first five videos, while other beginner youtubers could not get more than 10.
It is obvious that it is quite difficult to get money from YouTube without monetization and audience‚Äôs support right away.
After the scandal, the mother said that she would help for some time, but if there were no successes, she would stop. When they donated the first five dollars to me, she seemed to be delighted, but completely stopped taking this idea seriously. She seems to deliberately ignore what I do in general, constantly distracting me and giving useless tasks since I have "a lot of free time."
When the war started in Ukraine, the job industry got f~ed. They began to take all the men from work and send them to the front line. The same goes for any men on the street.
25% of the population in Ukraine is unemployed.
Rewinding time forward to today, after 450 days of the war, they parents began to ‚Äúsoftly‚Äù hint to me that it was time to look for a job.
During the war, my mother does not let me go outside even for shopping. That doesn‚Äôt disturb her to propose me work at a constructions.
Since there is a war now, I cannot work in the office or on the street - that is, it is only remote work. Remote work without work experience is either work in a call center, or work as a dispatcher for transportation in America (this is how it works in Ukraine). Accordingly, I have a very small selection of vacancies and a giant wall of ‚ÄúHR-managers‚Äù with gigantic unrealistic requirements.
At the moment I live in a village where there is not much to talk to, so I can‚Äôt even count on meeting girls, I can‚Äôt even find friends.
Even if suddenly a lonely lady was found in my neighboring house, agreeing to spend some time, she would not be very pleased to communicate with me because im overweight (175 cm, 100 kg). I stopped eating sweets and started to lose a decent amount of weight, but it will take a long time anyway. Btw I'm a virgin at 26.
My question is what to do with all this?
Everything is so bad that I can‚Äôt even ask a good question.

P.S.
Today I was contacted by the HR of a travel company and she offered a job as a dispatcher. I have an interview tomorrow. I doubt that I need it. I understand that I sound now like a manchild but hear me out.
At the moment we have enough money to survive. We do not save money, but so far we have everything. When I asked my mother what they were going to spend my money on (I expected that this money would be safely taken from me), she replied ‚Äúthat it will be your money, if you want, spend it on entertainment or shopping or save it for what you need‚Äù.
As a result, I have many questions.
How will I spend money on entertainment if I can be caught and mobilized to the front? What exactly should I buy if I can't go to the store?
I can‚Äôt even rent an apartment for such a salary, that is, it‚Äôs no luck to move out from my parents. From all this I draw one conclusion. They demand a job from me simply because ‚ÄúWell, why do we work and you don‚Äôt?‚Äù Despite the fact that there is no talk of taking money from me for rent or food.
So that's why I think I don't need a job - because for me at the moment the TIME spent on my channel is more important than money. And if I don't have time, I don't need money. But if I don't find a job, they will pester me every day, accusing me of lazyness. Should I accept a job offer?
reply:
Hey everyone, I could really use some advice right now. I live in a country at war and I'm struggling with a few things. Despite needing a job, I can't seem to find one. I also found a passion in editing videos for YouTube, but my parents don't support it. On top of that, I'm having a hard time finding a girl and I'm overweight. 

I graduated from an IT university a few years ago, but I realized I don't want to be a programmer. The job hunt has been tough, even for non-IT positions. It's frustrating that my education didn't prepare me for other opportunities. 

I tried my hand at editing videos and it felt so amazing. I poured my heart into it, but it's tough to make money without monetization and support. My mother seemed supportive at first, but now she ignores what I do and constantly gives me useless tasks because she thinks I have "a lot of free time." 

Due to the war, it's hard to find remote work without experience, and the available options are limited. Plus, I live in a village where it's tough to meet new people. And even if I did, my weight makes me self-conscious about dating. 

I recently got a job offer as a dispatcher for a travel company, but I'm not sure if I should take it. Right now, my channel is more important to me than money, and I fear getting caught and mobilized to the front if I have a job. But my parents keep pressuring me to work. What should I do? I'm really torn. #NeedAdvice

reply:
I'm really sorry to hear about the difficulties you are facing. It sounds like you're dealing with a lot of stress and pressure from multiple areas of your life. It's understandable that you're feeling overwhelmed and unsure of what to do.

Firstly, it takes a lot of courage to pursue what you love, even when others may not understand or support your choices. It's important to prioritize your own happiness and fulfillment, even if it means deviating from the conventional path. Your passion for video editing is evident, and the progress you've made with your YouTube channel is commendable. It's great that you've found something that inspires you and brings you joy. 

That being said, it's also important to consider your financial stability and independence. While your current situation allows you the time and freedom to focus on your channel, it's worth considering how sustainable this may be in the long run. Finding a job, even if it's not in your desired field, could offer you stability and the means to support yourself. It might be worth exploring options that align with your skills and interests, outside of programming.

Additionally, the restrictions imposed by the war and the pandemic make finding employment even more challenging. Remote work, like the job offer as a dispatcher, could be a potential opportunity for you. It may not be ideal, but it could provide you with income and some sense of purpose while you continue to pursue your passion.

Regarding your weight and concerns about meeting people, it's important to remember that your worth is not solely defined by your appearance. It's great that you've started taking care of your health by making changes to your diet. Losing weight takes time and patience, so be kind to yourself and celebrate the progress you've made. Building confidence and self-esteem starts from within, so focus on self-care, pursue activities that bring you joy, and try to cultivate positive relationships.

In summary, I understand that you feel torn between pursuing your passion and meeting the expectations of your family. It's important to find a balance between pursuing your dreams and taking practical steps towards financial stability. Consider the job offer as a potential opportunity and weigh the benefits it could bring. Remember to take care of yourself emotionally and physically, and know that it's okay to ask for support from trusted friends or seek professional guidance if needed. You deserve happiness and fulfillment in your life.

post:
A little preface - what the post is about:
I live in a country that is at war.
I can't find a job despite it is required of me.
I found a calling that I love, but parents don't let me do it.
I can't find a girl.
I am overweight.

Firstly, I graduated from the Ukrainian IT University 3 years ago.
In my third year of college, I realized that I didn't want to be a programmer, even though I had excellent grades.
I hate coding. Absolutely everything related to debugging code causes me uncontrollable anger and frustration. I can no longer spend 3 hours looking for a solution to 5 errors in the code that have nothing to do with the logic of the algorithm and are caused only by the specifics of the programming language. Even the thought that I need to learn a programming language makes my hands tremble and makes me irritable.
After graduating from college, I told my mom that I didn't want to be a programmer and I didn't want to go to an IT university. I want to find what I like in life.
The mother replied: ‚ÄúDo you understand what you are going to live on while you are looking for yourself? Without education, you will not be hired anywhere. Finish university, get a job, and then do whatever you want with your life."
In the end, I did. All the time I was studying, I thought that all the roads were open in front of me and I could do anything in life. I thought only lazy people can't find a job. As a student, I could find any part-time job at gas stations, call centers and ‚ÄúMcDonalds‚Äùs. I thought that when I graduated from university, I would take my diploma, go to the lowest paid job as a programmer, after a couple of years I would plow there, and try new things in my free time. That‚Äôs how I thoght until I graduated from university that I realized how wrong I was.
As soon as I graduated from university, all the "doors" of employers for students were closed. No one read my resume on job sites, my phone never rang. Attempts to look for work not in my specialty were also unsuccessful. Only then did I realize that in fact all the doors closed for me at the age of 15, when I first crossed the threshold of my IT college.
The main problem is that IT colleges and IT universities do not teach the necessary knowledge for work. It doesn't bother anyone at all. In Ukrainian colleges, they will forcefully teach a ton of useless subjects in modern meta-coding - from numerical methods to patent law. When I opened the job requirements, I lost heart. I spent 8 years studying to say that I know object oriented programming, I know 1997 database technologies and I can write code in 5 programming languages. But what else do I need:
- Framework #1 - unstudied
- Framework #2 - unstudied
- Framework #3 - unstudied
- Git technology - unlearned
- Modern wrapper for databases NameA - did not sound.
- I have no real experience with real projects from one year.
- I don't have a portfolio of works.
While I was "looking for a job" after a bad experience as a gas station cashier, I tried my hand at editing videos for YouTube. I have never been so inspired by what I do. The progress in motivation compared to what it was with programming was incredible for me. I worked on videos for 12 hours a day. When I started uploading videos, I saw that I get 100-300 views on the first five videos, while other beginner youtubers could not get more than 10.
It is obvious that it is quite difficult to get money from YouTube without monetization and audience‚Äôs support right away.
After the scandal, the mother said that she would help for some time, but if there were no successes, she would stop. When they donated the first five dollars to me, she seemed to be delighted, but completely stopped taking this idea seriously. She seems to deliberately ignore what I do in general, constantly distracting me and giving useless tasks since I have "a lot of free time."
When the war started in Ukraine, the job industry got f~ed. They began to take all the men from work and send them to the front line. The same goes for any men on the street.
25% of the population in Ukraine is unemployed.
Rewinding time forward to today, after 450 days of the war, they parents began to ‚Äúsoftly‚Äù hint to me that it was time to look for a job.
During the war, my mother does not let me go outside even for shopping. That doesn‚Äôt disturb her to propose me work at a constructions.
Since there is a war now, I cannot work in the office or on the street - that is, it is only remote work. Remote work without work experience is either work in a call center, or work as a dispatcher for transportation in America (this is how it works in Ukraine). Accordingly, I have a very small selection of vacancies and a giant wall of ‚ÄúHR-managers‚Äù with gigantic unrealistic requirements.
At the moment I live in a village where there is not much to talk to, so I can‚Äôt even count on meeting girls, I can‚Äôt even find friends.
Even if suddenly a lonely lady was found in my neighboring house, agreeing to spend some time, she would not be very pleased to communicate with me because im overweight (175 cm, 100 kg). I stopped eating sweets and started to lose a decent amount of weight, but it will take a long time anyway. Btw I'm a virgin at 26.
My question is what to do with all this?
Everything is so bad that I can‚Äôt even ask a good question.

P.S.
Today I was contacted by the HR of a travel company and she offered a job as a dispatcher. I have an interview tomorrow. I doubt that I need it. I understand that I sound now like a manchild but hear me out.
At the moment we have enough money to survive. We do not save money, but so far we have everything. When I asked my mother what they were going to spend my money on (I expected that this money would be safely taken from me), she replied ‚Äúthat it will be your money, if you want, spend it on entertainment or shopping or save it for what you need‚Äù.
As a result, I have many questions.
How will I spend money on entertainment if I can be caught and mobilized to the front? What exactly should I buy if I can't go to the store?
I can‚Äôt even rent an apartment for such a salary, that is, it‚Äôs no luck to move out from my parents. From all this I draw one conclusion. They demand a job from me simply because ‚ÄúWell, why do we work and you don‚Äôt?‚Äù Despite the fact that there is no talk of taking money from me for rent or food.
So that's why I think I don't need a job - because for me at the moment the TIME spent on my channel is more important than money. And if I don't have time, I don't need money. But if I don't find a job, they will pester me every day, accusing me of lazyness. Should I accept a job offer?
reply:
Dear Reddit user,

I can understand how challenging your situation must be, especially with the added stress of living in a country at war. It seems like you have a passion for creating YouTube videos and that it brings you a sense of fulfillment, motivation, and even some initial success. It's important to prioritize activities that bring you joy and a sense of purpose.

However, it's also crucial to consider the practical aspects of life, such as financial stability and the pressure from your parents to find a job. It sounds like your parents may have concerns about your future and want to ensure that you have some form of income. While it may be difficult, I encourage you to have an open and honest conversation with them about your aspirations and how pursuing your passion aligns with your long-term goals.

Regarding the job offer as a dispatcher in the travel company, it might be worth exploring further. While it may not align directly with your interests, it could provide you with some income while also allowing you to dedicate time to your YouTube channel. Consider assessing the potential benefits and drawbacks, such as the salary, work schedule, and opportunities for growth or networking. Ultimately, the decision is yours, and you have the right to prioritize your time and well-being as you see fit.

I also recommend exploring resources and support systems available to you. Mental health clinics, community organizations, or online communities can provide guidance and assistance in finding job opportunities, navigating personal relationships, and coping with the challenges of living in a country at war.

Remember, it is important to prioritize self-care and seek opportunities that align with your passions and values. Continue pursuing your YouTube channel and consider finding ways to expand your network and connect with others who share similar interests. While the road ahead may be challenging, remember that you have the strength and resilience to overcome these obstacles and find your path to fulfillment.

Take care,
[Your Name]

reply:
I'm sorry to hear that you're going through such a challenging time. It sounds like you've been facing a lot of pressure regarding your career path and employment situation. It can be incredibly frustrating when our interests and passions don't align with societal expectations or the practicalities of finding a job.

It's great that you found something you love in video editing for YouTube. Pursuing your passion and finding fulfillment in your work is important for our mental well-being. It's understandable that you want to prioritize the time spent on your channel right now. It's important to consider what brings you joy and what allows you to feel a sense of purpose.

However, it's also important to navigate the reality of your situation and the circumstances of the war and limited job opportunities in your country. While the travel company dispatcher job may not be exactly what you want, it might be a stepping stone to gain some work experience and financial independence. Additionally, having some form of employment can reduce the pressure from your parents and help you maintain a sense of stability during this challenging time.

Ultimately, the decision is up to you. Consider weighing the pros and cons of accepting the job offer. Think about how it may impact your personal goals and the progress you're making with your YouTube channel. It may also be helpful to have an open and honest conversation with your parents about your feelings, aspirations, and the challenges you face. Communication can help foster understanding, and they may be more supportive once they have a better understanding of your perspective.

Remember, it's okay to prioritize your mental health and well-being. Take care of yourself and make decisions that align with your values and personal circumstances. Seek support from friends, family, or even a mental health professional if you feel overwhelmed. You deserve happiness and fulfillment in your life, and with time and patience, you can find a path that works for you.

reply:
Hey there,

I can understand that you're going through a challenging time right now, and it's great that you reached out for support. It sounds like you're facing multiple issues, from struggling to find a job in your desired field to dealing with the pressures and expectations from your parents.

It can be frustrating when our passions and interests don't align with what others expect of us. It's important to remember that your happiness and well-being should be a priority. It seems like you found joy and motivation in editing videos for YouTube, which is fantastic. Pursuing something you're passionate about can have a positive impact on your mental health.

However, I also understand your concerns about the current situation, such as the war and limited job opportunities. It sounds like finding remote work may be your best option right now. While a dispatcher job may not align with your interests, it's worth considering whether it can provide financial stability and buy you more time to focus on your YouTube channel. Remember that sometimes, taking a job that isn't exactly what we want can enable us to pursue our true passions in the long run.

In terms of your weight and relationships, it's essential to prioritize your health and well-being. It's commendable that you've taken steps towards losing weight, but it's important to have patience and take things at your own pace. Remember that your value as a person goes far beyond your appearance, and focusing on self-improvement can enhance your self-confidence.

Ultimately, the decision about accepting the job offer is yours. Consider the short-term financial stability it could provide and how it aligns with your long-term goals. It might also be helpful to have an open conversation with your parents about your passions and how you see your future. Clear communication can help them understand your perspective better.

Lastly, seeking support from mental health professionals or local community resources could provide additional guidance and tools to navigate these challenges. Remember that you are not alone, and it's crucial to have a support system to lean on.

Take care and best of luck with your decision-making process.

post:
I don't want to keep you guys reading for too long so I'll try and quick.

Okay so I am a Romanian citizen that has moved to the uk 5 years ago( i am now almost 18 as I'm writing this)
I was known for always speaking too much, it didn't matter that you were, a girl or a boy, I always had good conversation with everyone, i always made loads of friends, and whenever i saw a girl i liked i could not stop talking to her even in lessons , this was all in my home country, however me and my loving family moved into the uk.
Over the last 4-5 years ive spent in the uk school (year 9-13) I have never made a single friend or had s conversation longer than 10-15 minutes, it got the point where I was hearing everyone calling me the quiet kid and i could not do anything about it,  i would rather be tortured with lava than talk and say something in the classroom unless i was privately speaking with someone. This gets much worse when I am setting next to any girls no matter who she is , i can't even say a damn word, i miss every single party even the last day of school which was a ball/banquet.

Weirdly this is only happening to people my age, i talk alot at work with my colleges who are older.
reply:
Hey everyone! üëã I hope you're all doing great. üåü

I wanted to reach out and share something personal with you guys. üó£Ô∏è Recently, I've been experiencing some difficulty when it comes to socializing, especially in school. üòî 

Back in my home country, I used to love chatting with everyone and making new friends. üåç But ever since my family and I moved to the UK about five years ago, things have changed. üòï I find it really challenging to strike up conversations or even make friends here. It's gotten to the point where people label me as the "quiet kid," and it's been tough for me. 

It feels like this struggle is only happening with people my age, as I'm able to talk and connect easily with my colleagues at work who are older than me.

I'm sharing this with you because I'm really hoping to find a solution or some advice on how to improve my social interactions. üòä Have any of you experienced this? If so, I would love to hear your thoughts and suggestions on how to overcome this. Your input would mean the world to me. üåçüíô

Thank you so much in advance for taking the time to read this and for any help you can offer. I appreciate it more than you know! üôèüíï

Adjusting to a new environment can be tough, especially when it comes to making friends and feeling comfortable in social settings.

Have you considered reaching out to a trusted adult or a mental health professional? They can provide support, guidance, and strategies to help you navigate these social challenges. Sometimes, it can be helpful to work with a therapist who specializes in anxiety or social skills. They can assist you in building confidence, teaching you techniques to manage anxiety in social situations, and working through any underlying issues that might be contributing to these difficulties.

Remember, you're not alone in this, and seeking help is a brave and important step towards finding solutions. You deserve to feel comfortable and to have fulfilling social connections. Best of luck on your journey, and don't hesitate to lean on the support of those around you.

reply:
I'm sorry to hear that you're experiencing difficulty making friends and engaging in conversations at school. It's understandable that this is causing you distress and frustration. Adjusting to a new country and school environment can be challenging, and it's not uncommon for individuals to feel shy or withdrawn in these situations.

It's important to remember that forming new connections takes time and patience. It might be helpful to focus on building rapport with your classmates gradually, starting with small interactions and common interests. You could try joining clubs or extracurricular activities where you can meet people who share similar hobbies or passions.

If you find that your anxiety around speaking with girls is particularly overwhelming, it could be beneficial to explore this further with a mental health professional. They can provide guidance and strategies to help you navigate these social situations with more ease.

In the meantime, don't forget the positive experiences you have at work with your colleagues who are older. Drawing on these experiences can help increase your confidence and remind you of your ability to engage in conversations.

Remember, making friends takes time, and it's important to be patient with yourself. It's also worth considering seeking support from a school counselor or therapist who can provide additional guidance and support during this transition.

post:
I don't want to keep you guys reading for too long so I'll try and quick.

Okay so I am a Romanian citizen that has moved to the uk 5 years ago( i am now almost 18 as I'm writing this)
I was known for always speaking too much, it didn't matter that you were, a girl or a boy, I always had good conversation with everyone, i always made loads of friends, and whenever i saw a girl i liked i could not stop talking to her even in lessons , this was all in my home country, however me and my loving family moved into the uk.
Over the last 4-5 years ive spent in the uk school (year 9-13) I have never made a single friend or had s conversation longer than 10-15 minutes, it got the point where I was hearing everyone calling me the quiet kid and i could not do anything about it,  i would rather be tortured with lava than talk and say something in the classroom unless i was privately speaking with someone. This gets much worse when I am setting next to any girls no matter who she is , i can't even say a damn word, i miss every single party even the last day of school which was a ball/banquet.

Weirdly this is only happening to people my age, i talk alot at work with my colleges who are older.
reply:
I'm sorry to hear that you're struggling with this issue. It sounds like a difficult transition from your home country to the UK. It's not uncommon for people to feel out of place or struggle with making friends when they move to a new environment. Sometimes the cultural differences and language barriers can make it challenging to connect with others.

It's important to remember that you're not alone in experiencing this. Many others have gone through similar situations and have been able to make friends and adjust to their new surroundings. It might take some time and effort, but there are steps you can take to improve your social interactions.

One suggestion is to try joining clubs, organizations, or groups that align with your interests. This can provide a common ground and give you opportunities to meet people who share similar hobbies or passions. Additionally, participating in social events or activities within your community can help you meet new people and build connections.

Building confidence in your communication skills could also be beneficial. Consider practicing conversation starters or small talk with family members, coworkers, or friends. This can help you feel more comfortable and prepared when engaging in conversations with others.

Lastly, be patient with yourself. Adjusting to a new environment takes time, and it's normal to feel uncomfortable or anxious at first. Remember that everyone has their own unique pace, and you will find your place given time.

If you continue to struggle with these feelings of social anxiety or isolation, it may be helpful to seek support from a mental health professional. They can provide guidance and strategies to help you navigate these challenges.

reply:
Hey there,

I'm really sorry to hear that you've been experiencing difficulties in making friends and engaging in conversations since moving to the UK. It can be tough to feel isolated and unable to connect with others, especially when it feels like you were sociable back in your home country.

It's important to remember that adjusting to a new environment can be challenging, and it's not uncommon for people to struggle with socializing when they move to a different country. Cultural differences, language barriers, and unfamiliar social norms can all contribute to feelings of isolation.

It's great that you feel more comfortable talking to your colleagues at work who are older. Sometimes, we find it easier to engage with people who have more life experience or share common interests. It might be helpful to explore activities or join clubs where you can interact with people who share similar interests, as this can provide a more comfortable setting for building friendships.

If you find it difficult to initiate conversations or feel anxious about talking to others your age, it could be helpful to consider seeking support from a mental health professional or counselor. They can provide guidance and strategies to help you feel more confident and comfortable in social situations.

Remember, it takes time to adjust to a new environment, and it's okay to feel a bit out of place initially. Building friendships and social connections can take time, so be patient with yourself. Keep working on developing your social skills, and don't hesitate to reach out for support if you need it.

Take care!

post:
This turned out to be really long, so thank you for just reading this.

I am not expecting any answers, but I would be happy to hear different opinions.

I am a 31 years old spoilt white male, born to privilege, who is wasting their life.

I feel unhappy with myself, beacuse everything I have ever done was given to me.

​

I have failed two bachelor degrees.

The job I have has been given to me and there is no pressure to do anything meaningful with it, because it is a minute team and it does not force me to engage with people or present any consequences for failure.

I feel no real desire to be good at it.

When that eventually falls through, I have no pressure to get an actual job, because, although I will not live a life of luxury, I will never really have to face any financial hardships (my family owns a bit of property).

​

I feel no reason to seek out connections with people, because I feel it is too much work, without too much reward.

I know, rationally, that the work is worth the reward, because it brings me happiness to connect with people, but not enough to stop myself from actively pushing people away or seeking out connections.

My family is my only real source of meaningful connections with other people, however there are issues there.

My parents are content to never push me to do anything and they let me just exist in the state that I am in.

They do that, because they need me to take care of their emotional needs and serve as an emotional drain for their baggage, while simultaneously refusing to include me in any meaningful conversations which could potentially lead to change.

They also show real support and love, when my problems do not involve them actually changing.

I used to be very close to my sibling, and they show me real support and love, but they have grown distant, since they now have their own family to support and issues to take care of.

Since I have been spoiled from an young age, my safety net is very toxic to me.

​

I have no real desire to improve myself, because I am too scared to change what is essentially a lifestyle that brings no hardships.

More often than not I want to find meaning in life but that requires at least a nominally consistent drive for self-improvement, so that usually fizzles out within days or weeks.

I have been to several therapists, but that ultimately fails, when I just stop engaging, because the desire for change dries up when I fall back to habits that lead to stagnation.

Habits, such as ignoring people, doing nominal self-improvement (i.e. taking the occasional online class or certificate for job-related skills only to do nothing with them and let them expire), consuming media, which makes me feel good about myself, and general laziness.

I have been diagnosed with depression and generalized anxiety disorder, because of my general lack of desire to take basic care of myself, beyond personal hygiene, and actively ignoring the few people from school who still want to be friends.

The only friend I keep in toch with (on and off) tries to make me get off my ass and actually do something, anything, since that is the only way to find something which will make me feel happy and not just content.

​

I often have suicidal ideations, but I know they will not be realized, because that would be an utter waste of all the opportunities that have been given to me as well as any potential I might have.

I also realize the inherent contradiction, between feeling that I have potential worth and feeling bad, because I'm not doing anything about it.

​

I realize that my emotional growth is stunted and I have no real desire to grow, or I would try to do something to change it.

​

All of this makes me a burden to myself, society and family, since I have no desire to give anything of value back, and I do not feel happy with myself, because I want to do something I define as worthwhile.

I have no way of knowing what is worthwhile to me, without trying stuff that I feel might be, but I also have no desire to try things I feel might be.

I do not have any external or much internal pressure to actively change, and it's easy to just ignore myself and by extension people around me.

Ignoring people arond me makes me feel shitty, so I just hate myself more and fall into this spiral of discontent, where I hate myself, but not enough to change.

So I neither hate, nor love myself enough to change.

I just feel I am wasting what was given, which is not enough motivation for me to do anything with my life.

Add to that the fact I should have been going through this when I was 16 (if I'm being generous with myself) and the general understanding that I am wallowing in convenient misery, instead of doing anything about it.

So, being a spoied, whiny, self-hating loser at 31, it's easy for me to distance myself from myself as a way to reconcile with the fact that I don't like myself.

This whole thing also makes me feel very egotistic.

​

The options I see and my questions are:

1. How do I force myself to change, when I don't really want to and have no external pressure to do so?
2. How do I learn to live with myself and not care so much that I have no value to other people?
3. How do I learn to find meaning in what little value I have?

​

Thank you again, for reading this far.
reply:
Hey there! üí¨ I just wanted to say thank you for opening up and sharing your thoughts. It takes a lot of courage to express your feelings like this. While I may not have all the answers, I can offer some suggestions to consider:

1Ô∏è‚É£ Start small: Sometimes, making big changes can feel overwhelming. Start by setting achievable goals that align with your interests. Take one small step at a time towards self-improvement, and celebrate each milestone along the way.

2Ô∏è‚É£ Seek new perspectives: Engage in activities or join communities where you can meet people from different backgrounds and experiences. It might help you gain a fresh perspective and find new meaning in your life.

3Ô∏è‚É£ Explore your passions: What activities or hobbies bring you joy? Take the time to explore your interests and invest in activities that make you genuinely happy. It's okay to start by trying new things without knowing if they'll bring value. The journey itself can be rewarding.

Remember, change takes time and it's okay to not have all the answers right away. You are not alone, and reaching out for support is a significant step forward. Take care! ‚ù§Ô∏è

reply:
I'm sorry to hear that you're feeling this way, and I appreciate you reaching out for support. It takes courage to express your feelings and concerns, and it's important to remember that you're not alone. Here are a few thoughts and suggestions that might be helpful for your situation:

1. Motivation for change: It can be challenging to find the motivation to change when there's no external pressure. One approach is to start small and set achievable goals. Consider what aspects of your life you'd like to improve and break them down into manageable steps. It might also help to identify why change is important to you personally. Reflect on what you hope to gain or achieve by making changes, which can provide you with intrinsic motivation.

2. Self-acceptance: Learning to live with yourself and finding self-worth is a journey that takes time and effort. Start by practicing self-compassion and treating yourself with kindness instead of self-criticism. Focus on your strengths and acknowledge the value you already have as a person. Engage in activities that bring you joy or a sense of accomplishment, even if they seem small. Building a fulfilling life begins with accepting yourself and recognizing your worth.

3. Finding meaning: Discovering meaning in life can be a deeply personal quest. Explore your interests, passions, and values. Engaging in activities that align with those can help bring a sense of purpose and fulfillment. Volunteering or giving back to your community can also be a meaningful way to contribute. Consider seeking out new experiences or learning opportunities that might resonate with you and help you find a sense of purpose.

Remember, seeking support from a mental health professional could be beneficial. They can provide guidance tailored to your specific situation and help you develop strategies for personal growth and well-being. You are deserving of support and care, and reaching out for help is a courageous step. Take care.

reply:
Thank you for reaching out and sharing your thoughts and feelings. It takes courage to acknowledge and express these struggles. While I can't provide direct help here, I can offer some guidance and suggestions that may support you:

1. It sounds like you may be experiencing a lack of motivation for change. It can be helpful to explore the underlying reasons for this. Reflect on what might be holding you back, what fears or beliefs might be influencing your desire for self-improvement. Recognize that change can be difficult, but also consider the potential benefits and the value it could bring to your life.

2. Learning to live with oneself and finding self-acceptance can be a gradual process. You mentioned feeling like a burden to others, but it is important to remember that everyone has unique value, including yourself. Start by practicing self-compassion and self-forgiveness. Challenge negative self-perceptions and focus on your strengths and qualities that you appreciate. Explore self-care activities that bring you joy and purpose.

3. Finding meaning can be a personal journey. Begin by exploring your interests, passions, and values. What activities or causes resonate with you? Engage in activities that align with your values and interests, even if they start small. These experiences might help you discover a sense of purpose and fulfillment.

Remember that seeking professional help, such as therapy, can be beneficial in exploring your concerns further and developing strategies for personal growth. They can provide the guidance and support you need throughout this process. Take care.

reply:
Hey there, thank you for reaching out and sharing your thoughts and feelings. It takes a lot of courage to open up like this. While I may not have all the answers, here are some suggestions that might help:

1. Start small: Change can be overwhelming, especially if you don't have strong motivation. Begin by setting achievable goals and gradually work towards them. Even small steps can make a difference.

2. Explore your interests: Take some time to reflect on what truly interests and excites you. Engaging in activities that align with your passions might bring meaning and satisfaction to your life.

3. Seek support outside therapy: While therapy may not have worked for you in the past, consider exploring different support options. This could include support groups, online forums, or self-help resources. Connecting with others who have had similar experiences might provide a different perspective.

4. Practice self-compassion: It's important to be kind to yourself and acknowledge that everyone has ups and downs. Be patient with yourself as you navigate your journey towards self-improvement.

5. Cultivate gratitude: Focus on the positive aspects of your life, such as the opportunities and privileges you have been given. Expressing gratitude can help shift your mindset and bring more positivity into your daily life.

Remember, it's okay to ask for help from professionals who specialize in mental health. They can provide the guidance and support you need to begin your journey towards self-discovery and finding meaning in your life.

They do that, because they need me to take care of their emotional needs and serve as an emotional drain for their baggage, while simultaneously refusing to include me in any meaningful conversations which could potentially lead to change.

They also show real support and love, when my problems do not involve them actually changing.

I used to be very close to my sibling, and they show me real support and love, but they have grown distant, since they now have their own family to support and issues to take care of.

Since I have been spoiled from an young age, my safety net is very toxic to me.

​

I have no real desire to improve myself, because I am too scared to change what is essentially a lifestyle that brings no hardships.

More often than not I want to find meaning in life but that requires at least a nominally consistent drive for self-improvement, so that usually fizzles out within days or weeks.

I have been to several therapists, but that ultimately fails, when I just stop engaging, because the desire for change dries up when I fall back to habits that lead to stagnation.

Habits, such as ignoring people, doing nominal self-improvement (i.e. taking the occasional online class or certificate for job-related skills only to do nothing with them and let them expire), consuming media, which makes me feel good about myself, and general laziness.

I have been diagnosed with depression and generalized anxiety disorder, because of my general lack of desire to take basic care of myself, beyond personal hygiene, and actively ignoring the few people from school who still want to be friends.

The only friend I keep in toch with (on and off) tries to make me get off my ass and actually do something, anything, since that is the only way to find something which will make me feel happy and not just content.

​

I often have suicidal ideations, but I know they will not be realized, because that would be an utter waste of all the opportunities that have been given to me as well as any potential I might have.

I also realize the inherent contradiction, between feeling that I have potential worth and feeling bad, because I'm not doing anything about it.

​

I realize that my emotional growth is stunted and I have no real desire to grow, or I would try to do something to change it.

​

All of this makes me a burden to myself, society and family, since I have no desire to give anything of value back, and I do not feel happy with myself, because I want to do something I define as worthwhile.

I have no way of knowing what is worthwhile to me, without trying stuff that I feel might be, but I also have no desire to try things I feel might be.

I do not have any external or much internal pressure to actively change, and it's easy to just ignore myself and by extension people around me.

Ignoring people arond me makes me feel shitty, so I just hate myself more and fall into this spiral of discontent, where I hate myself, but not enough to change.

So I neither hate, nor love myself enough to change.

I just feel I am wasting what was given, which is not enough motivation for me to do anything with my life.

Add to that the fact I should have been going through this when I was 16 (if I'm being generous with myself) and the general understanding that I am wallowing in convenient misery, instead of doing anything about it.

So, being a spoied, whiny, self-hating loser at 31, it's easy for me to distance myself from myself as a way to reconcile with the fact that I don't like myself.

This whole thing also makes me feel very egotistic.

​

The options I see and my questions are:

1. How do I force myself to change, when I don't really want to and have no external pressure to do so?
2. How do I learn to live with myself and not care so much that I have no value to other people?
3. How do I learn to find meaning in what little value I have?

​

Thank you again, for reading this far.
reply:
Hello,

Thank you for reaching out and sharing your thoughts and feelings with us. It takes courage to open up about such personal challenges. While I may not be able to provide all the answers you're seeking, I can offer some support and suggestions.

1. Creating a Desire for Change: It's understandable that you may find it difficult to motivate yourself when you don't feel the external pressure to do so. However, motivation often comes from within. Reflect on your current situation and imagine what your life could be like if you made changes that align with your personal values and goals. Visualize a future where you feel fulfilled and purposeful. This exercise might help spark a desire for change.

2. Acceptance and Self-Compassion: It's important to acknowledge and accept where you are in your life without judgment. Self-compassion involves treating yourself with kindness and understanding. Remember that everyone has their own unique path and struggles. Focus on self-care, engaging in activities that bring you joy, and practicing self-compassion when faced with negative self-talk.

3. Finding Meaning and Value: Meaning can be found in various ways, and it's a deeply personal journey. Consider exploring different hobbies, interests, or activities that align with your values. Volunteering or engaging in community work can also provide a sense of purpose and connection. Reflect on your core values and think about how you can incorporate them into your life.

Additionally, seeking guidance from a mental health professional, such as a therapist or counselor, can provide you with valuable support and guidance on your path towards personal growth. They can help you explore your thoughts and emotions more deeply, develop coping strategies, and set achievable goals.

Remember, change takes time, and it's okay to struggle along the way. Be patient and compassionate with yourself throughout this process. You deserve to create a life that brings you fulfillment and happiness.

post:
Hey everyone. I didn't know where to post this, or if I'm asking for advice or venting. That is to say, any kind of response is welcome, both advice and general statements, I don't mind. 

So I'm (M 23) probably the black sheep of the family. Not exactly how you might expect though. I'm in good shape, have a decent job, a house, I recently got married, get along great with my wife(F 21).

I grew up to a family who were and are, extremely poor. Most people don't really believe or fully understand what it means when a person who grew up poor says that. It feels like such an understatement. To be clear, poor as in "I'm shocked CPS didn't take me away" poor, no food sometimes and parents struggling to keep minimum wage jobs or a car poor. Maybe what is commonly called redneck or "white trash". How I am not that way and support my wife at age 23 is a whole other story for a different time. I have a strong mountain man streak still of course ü§†

To make things more complicated I'm a black sheep because I'm probably the only person in the family who is not suffering a severe metal health diagnosis. My brother is schizophrenic, sister and mom severe bi polar, grand parents live in their car due to schizophrenia causing unlivable disillusions. We live in rural Appalachia. More things like drugs and lack of opportunity are at play with them too.

My family rely on me in a way that most people would feel inappropriate, but to me I just can't tell. Maybe the trauma bonding from years of growing up like that, maybe guilt. I give all of them rides to and from their jobs. I know this sound untenable because I don't even live in the same town as them but the guilt of knowing I can, and if I don't they'll have no money and nothing else as a result kills me. This means I wake up early, and go to bed late, I also have to squeeze in 8 hours of work in there too. 

The toilet broke at their house a few months back. I showed them a how-to video and the ordered them the part. I learned that months later it was still broken. I fixed it in 5 minutes after going there. Family holidays happen wherever I live. And I cook them. I recently saw the movie Hillbilly Eligy and cried buckets. I was thinking "man, I lived this, I LIVE this now". My wife had never seen me in such a state, the fact that she didn't see what I saw (how could she of course not her fault) made he feel so alone. It's hard when you can't lean on family for anything, and no one else understands. The pressure of providing for them, and providing for my wife at such a young age is a lot. 

People say "cut them off". Those words hurt me. Most people just can't relate to what it feels like. Imagining holding your mom or dads hand on a cliff side and someone says "let go, it's hurting your arm". It's feels so normal to me in some ways. Maybe you gathered this already but I never had a real childhood. I have been an adult so long as I have had needs you could say. 

Now that I'm married my wife may be the most patient person on this earth. I have no idea how she handles having a husband practically married to his family, she meant my mother the car I got for her to use when hers broke down. This was in the days when I thought my family might be able to get or maintain a car. Eventually it ran out of gas and I went and picked up the gasless car, full of trash and ciggeretes butts from the highway. but I know this is too much for my wife despite her support. She needs space, she needs to see me, she needs a husband. I just don't know how to handle it all.

I'm not the type to really post, it write about my problems. I'm a blue collar man who is used to just swallowing things. Carrying everything as best I can. I find it hard to communicate it to my wife. I can tell she wants me to, but I'm afraid she'll loose confidence in me. 

**td;lr 

My(M 23) family (parents, siblings) rely on me a great deal. They struggle with poverty, drugs and mental health. It puts strain on my relationship with my wife(21 F) of 1 year. Guilt pulls me in every direction trying to navigate this.
reply:
Hey everyone, I hope you're all doing well. I wanted to share something that's been on my mind and see if anyone can offer any advice or just lend an ear.

Growing up in extreme poverty has shaped me in more ways than I can describe. It's been a difficult journey, but I've managed to build a good life for myself. However, being the only one in my family without severe mental health issues has placed a heavy burden on me.

I find myself constantly supporting my family financially and emotionally, which can be overwhelming at times. My days are filled with work, giving them rides, and trying to take care of my own needs and my wife's. It's a lot to juggle, especially at such a young age.

Sometimes, people suggest cutting them off, but it's not that simple. It's hard to explain to others who haven't walked in my shoes, but the bond I have with my family, despite everything, feels normal to me. It's tough to imagine letting go when they've been there for me in their own way.

Now that I'm married, I have an incredibly patient and supportive wife. I'm grateful for her understanding, but I also know that she deserves more attention and time from me. I want to be there for her as a husband should be, and it's a struggle to find the right balance.

I'm not used to opening up about my problems, but I'm realizing that communication is key. I want to be able to express my concerns and fears to my wife without losing her confidence in me. It's a learning process, but I'm determined to figure it out.

If any of you have been through something similar or have any advice on managing these conflicting responsibilities, I would truly appreciate your input. Thanks for taking the time to listen. Take care.

reply:
Hey there, thank you for reaching out to us. It sounds like you're going through a lot and carrying a heavy burden for your family. It's admirable that you've been supporting them through their struggles, but it's also important to take care of yourself and your own mental health.

Caring for loved ones who are dealing with poverty, mental health issues, and addiction is never easy. It's natural to feel guilt and a sense of responsibility, especially when they rely on you as their main support. However, it's crucial to establish healthy boundaries and find a balance between being there for them and prioritizing your own well-being and happiness.

One suggestion would be to start by having an open and honest conversation with your wife about how you're feeling. Communication is key in any relationship, and it's important to share your concerns with her. She seems like a patient and understanding person, so it's likely that she will be supportive and willing to work with you to find a solution that benefits both of you.

Additionally, consider exploring local resources that could provide assistance to your family members. There may be community organizations, churches, or support groups that can offer guidance and support for their specific challenges. It could be helpful to connect them with these resources so they become less reliant solely on you.

Remember, you are not alone in this. Seeking support from a therapist or counselor can give you a safe space to talk about your feelings and explore strategies for coping with the pressures you're facing. They can offer guidance on setting healthy boundaries and managing your own well-being while still supporting your family.

Take small steps towards finding a healthier balance for yourself and your relationships. It's not an easy journey, but with self-care and support, you can navigate through these challenges. Stay strong, and remember that taking care of yourself is just as important as caring for others.

reply:
Hi there,

Thank you for reaching out and sharing your story. It takes a lot of strength to open up about the challenges you're facing. It sounds like you have had a lot on your plate and have been carrying the weight of your family's struggles for a long time. Despite all the responsibilities, you continue to take care of them to the best of your abilities.

It's understandable that you may feel torn between your family and your relationship with your wife. Balancing these responsibilities can be extremely challenging, and it's okay to feel overwhelmed by it all. It's important to acknowledge your own needs and boundaries, as well as those of your wife. Healthy communication is key in any relationship, and sharing your concerns and struggles with her might actually strengthen your bond. Remember, being open and vulnerable does not mean that you are losing confidence in yourself. It shows that you trust her and value her support.

While it's difficult to offer specific advice without knowing your entire situation, it could be helpful to explore available resources in your community that might be able to assist your family. Social services, nonprofit organizations, and support groups could provide guidance and help alleviate some of the burdens you're feeling. Additionally, speaking with a mental health professional could offer you a safe space to process your emotions and explore strategies for setting healthy boundaries.

Remember, you are not alone in this. It's important to prioritize your own well-being too, so you can continue to support your family while nurturing your relationship with your wife. You deserve support and understanding just as much as anyone else.

Take small steps towards finding a healthier balance, and know that seeking professional help can greatly assist you on this journey. You are not alone, and there are people who can help you navigate through this challenging situation.

It sounds like your upbringing has been challenging and has left a lasting impact on you. Dealing with poverty, addiction, and mental health issues within your family can be extremely overwhelming and can affect all aspects of your life.

Firstly, it's important to recognize that you are not responsible for the well-being of your entire family. While it's commendable that you've been supporting them and providing for them, it's crucial to set boundaries and prioritize your own mental health and your relationship with your wife. It's natural to feel guilt in such situations, but remember that you have your own life to live and your own needs that deserve attention and care.

Communication plays a vital role in any relationship, and it's essential to have an open and honest conversation with your wife about your feelings, concerns, and the pressures you're experiencing. Sharing your thoughts and fears with her can help her understand your perspective better and allow both of you to find ways to support each other through these challenging times.

Consider reaching out to a mental health professional or therapist who can provide you with guidance and support in navigating these complex family dynamics. They can help you develop coping strategies, establish boundaries, and find ways to balance your responsibilities.

Remember, taking care of yourself doesn't mean abandoning your family. It simply means recognizing your limitations and finding healthier ways to support them without sacrificing your own well-being.

Hang in there, and don't hesitate to seek further support if needed. You're not alone in this journey, and there are resources available to help you navigate these challenges.

post:
We are together for 2 years and it is a great relationship, we communicate openly about everything, can navigate any fight and I feel overall really good in this relationship. 

I moved to study in his city in Germany (I am from Russia) and we met there. He is finishing medicine degree and wants to find a job in his home city. He has his whole life here, family friends and he does not want to move even to another city in Germany, which I underatand and accept.

I however have lived in 3 countries already and I have a huge curiosity for exploring cultures, languages and just learning about the life abroad. For now I wanna stay in Germany but I do not feel that happy in the city of my boyfriend, it is quite a concervative state, there are not many young people, I feel quite lonely and there is no art scene (I am an illustrator). I am not unhappy here but I wanna try something new. So I want to move to another city in a different state. 

But I know if I move to another city we will break up, we talked about it does not make sense to keep things going if I am not going to settle down in his town. And my concern is, should I really give up my relationship that is very good for something that I am not even sure I will like (living in another city)? 
Maybe I will just never be happy in a place I live long term?

P.s.We also talked about perfect lifestyle that we imagine for us:
His perfect picture is: we will eventually move in together, we will work 9 to 5, spend evenings with friends, sometimes do hikes on the weekend, do holiday couple of times a year, get kids etc
My perfect picture is: we live in a couple of different countries for several years together, explore it, work flexible hours, get a place as a base somewhere, we do campings or travel in a van for some time, even with kids eventually 

And it seemed so drastically different, I dont know if it is just me romanticizing travel, this whole situation makes me feel like I am the weird one who is ready to trade good relationship for novelty and excitement of a new place... 

Tl;dr I want to move around and my boyfriend wants to stay in his hometown forever, should I stay with him in his hometown?
reply:
Hey Reddit fam! üåüNeed some advice on a relationship dilemma. So, I've been with my amazing boyfriend for 2 years now and things are going great. We have awesome communication skills and can handle any argument like pros. Overall, I feel really happy with him. ü•∞

Here's the thing: I moved to Germany (from Russia) to study and met him there. He's finishing up his medicine degree and wants to settle down in his hometown. I totally understand and accept that, but I've lived in 3 countries and have this burning desire to explore different cultures and languages. Right now, I'm not feeling too thrilled in his city. It's a bit conservative, not many young people, and lacks a vibrant art scene (I'm an illustrator). I'm not unhappy, but I crave something new, you know?

I've been thinking about moving to another city in a different state, but we've discussed it and we both agree that it doesn't make sense to continue our relationship if I'm not going to settle down in his town. I'm torn, though. Should I give up this amazing relationship for the uncertainty of a new place? ü§î Will I ever truly be happy in one place long-term?

We even talked about our ideal lifestyles, which seem quite different. He envisions a settled life together, working 9 to 5, chilling with friends, and occasional hikes and vacations. My dream is a bit more adventurous, living in different countries for a few years, exploring, working flexible hours, and even doing camping trips or traveling in a van. It feels like we're on opposite ends and I'm worried I'm being "weird" for sacrificing a great relationship for novelty and excitement.

So, Reddit fam, any thoughts or advice? Should I stay with him in his hometown or take a leap into the unknown? Help a confused soul out! ‚ù§Ô∏èüåç #RelationshipDilemma #ToMoveOrNotToMove

reply:
I can understand that you're facing a difficult decision. It's great that you and your boyfriend have open communication and can navigate conflicts well. Relationships can bring a lot of happiness and fulfillment, but it's also important to consider your own personal growth and fulfillment.

It seems that you have a strong desire for exploration and experiencing new cultures, which is completely valid. Different people have different priorities and dreams, and both your desires and your boyfriend's desires are important. It's not necessarily about one being right or wrong, but rather about finding a balance that can make both of you happy.

Have you considered discussing the possibility of compromise? Perhaps you could consider seeking opportunities that allow you to travel and explore while still maintaining your relationship. It doesn't have to be an all-or-nothing situation.

It may also be helpful for both of you to envision your future together and discuss what compromises you're willing to make. Is there a way you can find a middle ground that satisfies both of your desires? It might involve compromise on both sides, but it's important that both of you feel heard and understood.

Ultimately, the decision is up to you, but it may be worth having a deeper conversation with your boyfriend about your concerns and aspirations. Additionally, you could consider seeking professional help, such as couples counseling or individual therapy, to further explore your feelings and find guidance.

Remember that your happiness is important and it's okay to prioritize your own personal growth. It's not unusual to have different dreams and desires in a relationship, and it's about finding a balance that brings fulfillment to both partners. Take some time to reflect on your priorities and have an open and honest conversation with your boyfriend. Good luck!

It's important to remember that there is no right or wrong decision here, as it ultimately comes down to your personal values, needs, and aspirations.

One approach to finding resolution in this situation is to engage in open and honest communication with your boyfriend. It appears that you have already discussed your expectations and desires for the future, which is a positive step. Building upon this, consider having a deeper conversation about the potential compromises or middle ground that may be possible. Is it possible to find a city in Germany that offers a balance of both your desires, such as a larger city with more cultural opportunities and an active art scene, while still being relatively close to your boyfriend's hometown?

Moreover, consider reflecting on your own long-term goals and what truly matters to you. Are your aspirations for exploring and living in different countries integral to your own personal growth and fulfillment? It can be helpful to work on identifying your values and priorities, as this will guide your decision-making process.

Additionally, it may be beneficial to seek support from a therapist or counselor who can help you explore your feelings, identify any underlying fears or concerns, and provide guidance as you navigate this difficult decision.

Remember to be kind to yourself throughout this process and keep in mind that sometimes, making difficult decisions can be an opportunity for personal growth and self-discovery. I wish you strength and clarity as you navigate this challenging situation.

If exploring different countries, cultures, and having a flexible lifestyle is something that is truly important to you, it's worth considering whether staying in your boyfriend's hometown will truly fulfill you in the long term.

post:
I (23f) think I'm going to finally break up with my bf (32m). We live together. I also  have terrible rsd so this is going to be extremely painful, and my first ever break up where I'm consciously not going to jump straight into another relationship afterwards in order to stop myself from feeling heartbroken. I'm trying to be a better person...

Anyways, I live with him in Scotland, but my whole family and support system is in Ireland. I moved out of Ireland because I could never really see myself living here permanently, but I do of course miss my family and friends. I went to uni in Scotland and just ended up staying afterwards. My dilemma is whether to stay in Scotland after the break up or go back to Ireland.

 I recently got a nice job offer in Scotland, starting next month, for at least 3 years. I still don't know what I want to do on my life, and this job seemed like a good starting block to figuring it out. So if we break up, do I stay there, find a room to rent for a good bit of money (yay Edinburgh) and start my new job in September?

On the other hand, I could move back in with my parents in Ireland. I could get a job in a pharma company here without an issue, as it's a huge sector here and I have a relevant course completed. By moving back, I could save a good amount of money but I will also feel like I took a step back in my life, instead of forward, if that makes sense? My parents have no problem with me moving back here - in fact, they always wanted me to come back to Ireland after uni. 

If anyone has any great words of wisdom, I would be forever grateful.

TL;DR Gonna break up with my bf, not sure whether I should stay in Scotland or move back to Ireland where my family is.
reply: Hey there! It sounds like you're going through a tough time, but you're taking a positive step towards personal growth. It's great that you're consciously avoiding jumping into another relationship right away. As for your dilemma, both options have their pros and cons. Staying in Scotland could give you the opportunity to explore your new job and potentially figure out what you want in life. On the other hand, moving back to Ireland would bring you closer to your family and job opportunities in the pharma sector. Remember, there's no right or wrong choice here. Ultimately, trust your instincts and consider what will bring you the most happiness and fulfillment. Best of luck with your decision! üåü
