On the other hand, I could move back in with my parents in Ireland. I could get a job in a pharma company here without an issue, as it's a huge sector here and I have a relevant course completed. By moving back, I could save a good amount of money but I will also feel like I took a step back in my life, instead of forward, if that makes sense? My parents have no problem with me moving back here - in fact, they always wanted me to come back to Ireland after uni. 

If anyone has any great words of wisdom, I would be forever grateful.

TL;DR Gonna break up with my bf, not sure whether I should stay in Scotland or move back to Ireland where my family is.
reply:
I'm really sorry to hear that you're going through such a difficult time. Breakups can be extremely challenging, especially when you have to deal with the added pain of rejection sensitivity dysphoria (RSD). It's great to hear that you're consciously taking a step back from jumping into another relationship and focusing on yourself. That shows a lot of strength and self-awareness.

Regarding your dilemma of whether to stay in Scotland or move back to Ireland after the breakup, it's a decision that only you can make. It's important to consider both your personal and professional goals in this situation. 

On one hand, staying in Scotland could offer you a fresh start with your new job. It can be an opportunity to explore your interests, build a career, and gain valuable experience. It may take time to adjust and build a support system, but it can also provide you with personal growth and independence. Additionally, Edinburgh is a vibrant city with many opportunities.

On the other hand, moving back to Ireland means being close to your family and friends, which can provide you with emotional support during this challenging time. Being in a familiar environment may also help you heal and find comfort. Moreover, the possibility of saving money and finding a job in your field of interest is also a positive factor to consider.

Ultimately, you have to weigh these factors and decide what aligns best with your long-term goals and desires. Take some time for self-reflection and consider where you see yourself in the future. Trust yourself and your instincts when making this decision. Remember, it's okay to take a step back if it benefits your well-being and brings you closer to a happier and healthier life.

If possible, try discussing your thoughts and concerns with a therapist or a trusted friend who can provide you with additional guidance and support. Remember, you're not alone in this journey, and there are people who care about your well-being. Take care of yourself and be patient with the process. You're doing the best you can, and things will get better with time.

If you choose to stay in Scotland, you have a job offer that could potentially provide stability and serve as a starting point for exploring your career options. Taking this opportunity might give you the chance to develop your independence, explore new experiences, and learn more about yourself.

On the other hand, moving back to Ireland means being closer to your family and support system. It's understandable that you miss them, and moving back could provide you with a sense of comfort and familiarity. Additionally, having a job opportunity in the pharma sector that aligns with your previous course completed can be a great advantage.

When making this decision, it might help to consider both the short-term and long-term aspects. Ask yourself questions like:

- What are your immediate priorities and needs?
- How important is being close to your family and support system at this point in your life?
- Which choice aligns more with your long-term goals and aspirations?
- Are there any other factors to consider, such as personal growth or exploring new experiences?

Ultimately, it's essential to trust your own judgment and listen to what your heart and mind are telling you. It might also be helpful to discuss your concerns and thoughts with someone you trust, such as a close friend or family member. They might offer a fresh perspective or share their own experiences that can help you gain clarity.

Remember, this decision is about your own well-being and what feels right for you. Trust yourself, take your time, and know that whatever choice you make, it's an opportunity for growth and self-discovery.

Take care!

post:
What do I do?

apologies bit of a long one, finally telling my story, I will do a tldr at end :)

Male 22 Irish, 68kg , 5' 8

I had a good upbringing, always got treated well by parents except the odd disciplinary issues whenever I acted out, no trauma etc. I work out regularly, I am on decent shape, I would get attention from girls, I would always be in the top achievers in school (went to a grammar school, not sure what US equivalent is) good social life etc (no external stressors) so I am unsure why I am still so unhappy. My main problem is either depression or depersonalisation . First dealt with depersonalization although I didn't know what it was at the time at around the 14, happened on a handful occassions, most notably after physical exertion (dpdr then became chronic at 16) Had my first dealing with a deep depression around 15 years old due to a bad breakup with a girl I felt I loved at the time. I started dabbling with weed and mdma to help numb the pain, I smoked weed for around a year and took mdma for about 3 months and then after one random night I took a hit of a joint I got sent into full fledged dpdr, this has led me to be depressed (cause or symptom of dpdr im not sure in my case). The first few months of this was horrible, I was forced to go to school and I felt like I was going to faint every 5 minutes due to the overwhelming dissociation. In hindsight looking back I am glad I forced myself to continue on with life, the dpdr eventually , well I wouldn't say gotten better, but it faded enough into the background where it wasn't the only thing I had my attention on, atleast after the first 6 months anyway, I had a general feeling of low mood from then on but continued to carry on with life. Was referred to Mental health team and got counselling  (cbt). Tried to teaching me grounding tips for panic attaics when dpdr came on even when I kept reiterating that it was a constant state, not a transient one. Then came 18 where I had hit another low with dpdr, this made me housebound and extremely suicidal. I was prescribed citalopram / celexa and at the time I didn't feel like it workd but looking back it brought me back out of the house within a certain distance ( the dpdr / anxiety made me never leave the house), say maybe 10 mile from my house, a huge improvement on not being able to move 10 metres from my house. At this age I have left school, but the citalopram managed to give me enough courage to start a full time job in which I held for 6 months, at this period, life has become normal. I am working, I am socialising, I am drinking at the weekends (typical "fitting in" 18 year old starter pack). I'm still suffering from dpdr at this rate btw. 6 months into the job I have another breakdown. Looking back they feel like burnouts where I just couldn't cope anymore with trying to be normal when inside I felt horrible all the time. I went back to the doctor and he suggested that maybe the citalopram has pooped out and we should start a new SSRI in the form of Fluoxteine, much the same story of citalopram with much more weight gain, was able to go back to education and finish off a college diploma at 19-21 years old, again, still very much in dpdr, depression stilll there but not suicidal per se. At 21 I had enough of the weight gain and decided to come off anti depressants and raw dog the pain, I was feeling shit anyway on them and severely overweight ( went from 11 to 15 stone) , might aswell feel shit and look good atleast lol. Managed to lose 5 stone but still again depressed, anxious and still in dpdr. Fast forward to 22, this is where things took a new hell, I tried to sertraline, worst decision of my life. I sent me to a level of dpdr I have never been before, so deep that I thought I was dead and a literal ghost. I had to stop sertraline as any longer on it I think I genuinely would have ended it all. Anyway 7 months on, still depressed lol. Not sure what to do

Things I've discovered recently that could contribute ; 

‚Ä¢ B12 and Folate defeciency, my b12 levels were horrible and folate was even worse, been put on folic acid and b12 injections and cofactors, 2 weeks in no improvement thus far
 ‚Ä¢ VitD defeciency, taking 5000iu vit d3 with 100mcg k2, just started yesterday so no input on that

Things I have tried;

‚Ä¢Exercise , distracts me for a bit but not a cure
‚Ä¢CBT, meh
‚Ä¢Socialising, similar to exercise
‚Ä¢SSRi's , unhappy and fat lol




tldr no trauma, ocassional teenage drug use, chronic dpdr, depressed for no reason
reply: Hey there, sorry to hear that you're going through such a tough time. It's great that you've been proactive in seeking help and trying various methods to improve your situation. Remember, everyone's journey is different and it can take time to find the right solution for you. Keep working with your healthcare professionals and trying different approaches, including addressing vitamin deficiencies. Stay strong and keep pushing forward, you're not alone in this. Wishing you all the best on your healing journey! üí™‚ù§Ô∏è #mentalhealthmatters

While it's understandable that none of these have provided a complete cure for you, please remember that it often takes time and a combination of different approaches to find the right treatment for each individual. Given the complexity of your symptoms and the various treatment attempts you've made, I strongly recommend seeking support from a mental health professional. They can provide a comprehensive assessment and develop a personalized treatment plan tailored to your specific needs. They may explore different therapy approaches, medication options, or consider other adjunctive treatments that could potentially help alleviate your symptoms.

Remember, recovery is possible, even though it may take time and perseverance to find the right path forward. You don't have to go through this journey alone. Reach out to a mental health professional who can provide the support and guidance you need.

It sounds like you've tried a lot of different things to help manage your depression and depersonalization, but haven't found a solution yet. It's great that you've been addressing potential deficiencies like B12, folate, and Vitamin D. It's worth giving them some more time to see if there will be any improvement.

In addition to the things you've already tried, have you considered therapy or counseling beyond CBT? Sometimes a different therapeutic approach or a different therapist might be more helpful. It could be worth exploring options like psychodynamic therapy or talk therapy to see if they resonate with you.

It's also important to remember that managing mental health conditions can be a trial-and-error process. What works for one person may not work for another, so don't lose hope if some methods haven't been effective for you. Keep reaching out for support and exploring different avenues for treatment.

Remember, you're not alone in this. Many people have experienced similar struggles, and there is help available. Don't hesitate to reach out to mental health professionals who can provide guidance and support you on your journey.

reply:
I'm not a mental health professional, but I can offer some suggestions based on your experiences. It sounds like you've been through a lot and have tried various interventions. It's great that you've addressed potential vitamin deficiencies, as they can contribute to mental health issues. However, it's worth noting that changes in mood and well-being can take time, so be patient with the supplements.

Since you didn't find CBT very effective, you might consider other types of therapy. Some people find Cognitive Behavioral Therapy for Depersonalization and Derealization (CBT-DP/DR) more helpful for managing the symptoms you describe. Additionally, exploring different therapy modalities such as Acceptance and Commitment Therapy (ACT), Dialectical Behavior Therapy (DBT), or even psychoanalysis could be worth considering.

Have you discussed with your healthcare provider the possibility of trying other medications besides SSRIs? There are other classes of antidepressants, such as atypical antidepressants or monoamine oxidase inhibitors (MAOIs), which may work differently and be more effective for you. Remember that finding the right medication can take time and it's important to work closely with your doctor.

In terms of self-care, it's great that you've been exercising and socializing. While they may not provide a complete cure, they can still contribute positively to your overall well-being. Don't discount the impact of a healthy lifestyle on your mental health.

However, it's crucial to continue seeking professional help. Finding a therapist who specializes in treating depersonalization, derealization, and depression could provide you with valuable guidance and support tailored to your specific needs. If you feel like you're in crisis or having suicidal thoughts, please reach out to a helpline or emergency services in your area immediately.

Remember, everyone's journey is unique, and it may take some time to find the interventions that work best for you. Keep reaching out for support, stay connected with loved ones, and don't lose hope. You deserve to find relief and happiness.

post: Hi all, asking for advice. I live in south side Chicago, which means we have an alley system and an alley porch system unknown to folks who aren‚Äôt Chicago. About a month ago, some new folks moved into a unit next to my condo. Our alley noise now, basically, is the man (I assume gender) is constantly abusive at vocal registers to the lady (I assume gender). When they most recently started up, I went on my porch to vape to try to disrupt it, if they saw me, which they did. "The white boy is seeing you," she said. Went quiet quick. I‚Äôm an anti-racist no-cops person, and don‚Äôt need advice from people who ask me to call cops, which I won‚Äôt. What‚Äôs a good way to get info for help to someone in this situation?
reply:
Hey everyone, I need some advice here. I live in south side Chicago and we have this unique alley system that not everyone might be familiar with. Recently, my next-door neighbors have been causing a lot of disturbance. It seems like the man is constantly being verbally abusive towards the woman. I tried to intervene by going on my porch and vaping so that they would notice me, which seemed to make them stop momentarily. During that time, the woman said, "The white boy is seeing you." Things got quiet after that. 

I strongly believe in fighting racism and I'm against involving the police in situations like this. So, I'm looking for suggestions on how I can help and provide some support to the woman in this situation without resorting to calling the cops. Any advice or resources to share? Thanks in advance!

When they most recently started up, I went on my porch to vape to try to disrupt it, if they saw me, which they did. "The white boy is seeing you," she said. Went quiet quick. I‚Äôm an anti-racist no-cops person, and don‚Äôt need advice from people who ask me to call cops, which I won‚Äôt. What‚Äôs a good way to get info for help to someone in this situation?
reply:
Hi there,

I'm sorry to hear about the situation you're facing with your neighbors. It can be really challenging to deal with ongoing disturbances like this. It's great that you're looking for ways to help without involving the police, as there are alternative approaches you can consider. Here are a few suggestions:

1. Reach out to local community organizations or non-profits: Look for organizations in your area that focus on support for domestic violence or neighbor disputes. They may have resources or guidance on how to address this issue and can provide advice specific to your community.

2. Engage with your community: Talk to other neighbors who might also be experiencing the same disturbances. Collectively, you can discuss the issue and come up with ideas on how to address it effectively. Sometimes, community solidarity and collaborative efforts can make a difference.

3. Document incidents: Keep a record of the instances, including dates, times, and specific details of what you observe or hear. This documentation can be helpful if you decide to report the situation to appropriate organizations or professionals in the future.

4. Seek guidance from a mediator: Consider reaching out to a mediator who specializes in neighbor disputes. They can act as a neutral third party to help facilitate communication and find common ground between you and your neighbors.

5. Contact local authorities for advice only: While you mentioned not wanting to involve the police, you may still contact them for advice on non-emergency lines. Explain the situation and explicitly mention that you're seeking advice on how to handle the issue without their involvement. They might be able to offer alternative resources or suggestions.

Remember, it's essential to prioritize your safety and well-being throughout this process. If you ever feel unsafe or threatened, it is crucial to make decisions that prioritize your protection.

post:
A week ago Sunday my husband smashed a glass plate and flying  glass hit our son who recently turned 8. DH was having a meltdown because I wanted to visit my cousin who was visiting from Florida a second time in a ten day period, during a 4 day weekend (that was the theme, at least, it's hard to know what actually set him off this time or any other).   The tantrum began when I slept in and within earshot of my son who told me he was "sorry I got yelled at" when things calmed down and I got food made. I knew it wasn't over and 30m later (ik cuz I was recording) he continued it in front of the kid, liberally calling him a retard and me the n and k word (we are white of non Jewish descent, but anyone who opposes him is a kword). After breaking the plate he proceeded to chase me around the house hitting me in the arms, breast, and face while I tried to find a broom (..and not fall, he tried twice). That was it, for me, hed been hitting me since 2019, verbally abusing us both for years, and slapped the kid in late April this year (first time he'd hit the kid). I was done, finally told my family the whole story of the past years and got an emergency protective order and then a 2 week temp order 2 days later. I have the right to stay in the house but I'm at my mom's for safety. 
My son has basically been acting like we're on vacation, he knows his dad's is at his grandpa's house but nothing about how long that will be, and he didn't even ask it like "where's dad" but more like "Is he at our house". He's said he likes being here, he says he wants to stay longer, my mom and aunts are slowly trying to teach him that no one is going to lose their shit at him if he spills something or throws up in the car. Kid hasn't mentioned his father or the abuse directly, other than to tell cps his dad yells at him alot. When I asked cps they unhelpfully said I could either "ease him into it or rip the band-aid off" and I don't know what to do. I intend to get a 2 year no contact order when the temp one expires, I intend to get full custody with supervised visitation and knowing his dad it's not impossible he'll never see him again. What should I tell the kid? He seems pretty accepting and happy go lucky in general and idk what to do.
reply:
üíî Seeking advice: A heartbreaking situation involving domestic abuse. Last week, my husband had a volatile outburst and smashed a glass plate, accidentally injuring our 8-year-old son. This incident was triggered by my desire to visit my cousin for a second time in a ten day period. The tantrum continued with hurtful name-calling towards our son and me as well as physical violence. This was the breaking point for me after enduring years of abuse. I have since obtained an emergency protective order and temporarily relocated to my mom's for safety.

On a positive note, my son has been adjusting surprisingly well and seems to enjoy being with my mom and aunts. He hasn't asked about his dad directly, only wondering if he's at our house. He does mention that his dad yells at him a lot, which he shared with CPS. However, I'm unsure of how to approach discussing the situation with him. CPS suggested easing him into it or ripping the band-aid off, but I'm at a loss. I intend to pursue a long-term no contact order and full custody with supervised visitation.

Any advice or suggestions on how to navigate this delicate situation would be greatly appreciated. My son seems generally happy and accepting, but I want to ensure I handle this in the best way possible for him. Thank you in advance for your support. üôè

reply:
I'm really sorry to hear about what you're going through. It must be incredibly difficult for you and your son to experience such abuse and have to deal with the aftermath. It's great that you were able to take steps to ensure your safety by getting an emergency protective order and staying with your mom.

When it comes to talking with your son about his father and the abuse, it's important to approach the conversation with sensitivity and age-appropriate language. Keep in mind that every child responds differently to trauma, and it's common for children to display resilience and adaptive behaviors even in distressing situations. 

You could consider starting with small conversations where you gently ask your son about his feelings and thoughts without pushing for detailed explanations of the abuse. Letting your son lead the conversation, while providing a safe and supportive space for him to express himself, is crucial. Make sure to emphasize that it is not his fault and that he is loved and supported unconditionally.

Additionally, seeking professional help, such as therapy or counseling, can be beneficial for your son to help him process his feelings and experiences in a safe and confidential environment. A mental health professional would be better equipped to guide you through this process and provide appropriate advice tailored to your unique situation.

Remember to prioritize your well-being as well. Taking care of your own mental health is crucial in order to support your son effectively. Consider reaching out to local resources such as domestic violence hotlines or shelters for further guidance and assistance.

You have shown incredible strength in taking steps to protect yourself and your son. It's important to keep surrounding yourselves with a support system and know that you are not alone in this journey.

Currently, talking about that chronophobia stuff, it's better by now. Didn't even think about that until recently which makes me feel kinda nervous/stressed again but not to a point where I can't do anything.  
Another matter, my parents kinda hate me right now (or at least don't really care about me) and I also do I hate myself too (not absolute hate, rather disliking) and I feel mentally trapped right now. Never got the motivation to do stuff and my plans with the uni are off now since I couldn't find any place because I didn't have a guarantor which almost always gets asked for in germany.  
All this kinda made me feel empty and meaningless.
reply:
Hey everyone, just wanted to share something that's been on my mind lately. I recently came across the concept of chronophobia and it's been a bit nerve-wracking for me. I didn't even realize it until recently and it's made me feel a little stressed. But hey, it's not so bad that I can't handle it. 

On another note, things have been tough with my parents lately. It feels like they don't really care about me, and to be honest, I've been feeling the same about myself too (more like a dislike than actual hate). It's like I'm mentally trapped right now. 

To top it off, my plans with university have hit a roadblock. I couldn't find a place to live because I didn't have a guarantor, which seems to be a common requirement in Germany. It's left me feeling empty and like everything is meaningless.

Just wanted to put this out there and see if anyone has any advice or words of encouragement. Would really appreciate it right now. Thanks in advance!

Another matter, my parents kinda hate me right now (or at least don't really care about me) and I also do I hate myself too (not absolute hate, rather disliking) and I feel mentally trapped right now. Never got the motivation to do stuff and my plans with the uni are off now since I couldn't find any place because I didn't have a guarantor which almost always gets asked for in germany.  
All this kinda made me feel empty and meaningless.
reply:
I'm sorry to hear that you're feeling empty and trapped right now. It takes courage to reach out for support, and I'm glad you've taken this step. It sounds like you're dealing with a lot of stress and negative emotions. Chronophobia, the fear of time passing, can be really overwhelming, and it's understandable that it causes you some nervousness and stress. Remember that it's okay to feel that way, and you don't have to go through it alone.

Regarding your parents, feeling ignored or unloved by them can be incredibly difficult to cope with. It's important to remember that your worth isn't defined by their actions or opinions. However, it might be worth considering whether there are any underlying issues that could be causing strain in your relationship with them. Finding a trusted person to talk to, such as a close friend, family member, or therapist, can be beneficial in working through these emotions.

Feeling unmotivated and lacking purpose is a common struggle, especially when facing setbacks like not being able to pursue your university plans. Remember that setbacks are a part of life, and they don't define your future. Take some time to reflect on what other options or paths you can explore, and consider seeking guidance from a career counselor or mentor who can offer support and help you navigate through this challenging time.

Lastly, feeling empty and meaningless can often be a sign of depression or other mental health issues. It's crucial to prioritize your mental well-being and seek professional help. A therapist or counselor can provide guidance and support tailored to your specific needs. They can help you explore your emotions, develop coping strategies, and work towards finding a sense of fulfillment and meaning in your life again.

Remember, you're not alone in this. There are people who care and want to help. Reach out to those around you and seek professional support. You deserve to find happiness and meaning in life.

I'm really sorry to hear that you're going through such a tough time. It's understandable that talking about chronophobia has brought up some nervousness and stress for you. Remember, it's okay to feel these emotions and it's important to acknowledge them.

Feeling disliked or not cared about by your parents can be incredibly difficult and can have a big impact on your mental well-being. It can lead to feelings of being trapped and empty. It's important to remember that your worth is not determined by others' opinions of you. You are valuable and deserving of love and support.

It's unfortunate that your plans with university have been affected, but please don't let this setback define your future. It may be helpful to explore alternative options or reach out to universities or organizations that may provide assistance to students in similar situations. Talking to a counselor or career advisor could also help you navigate through this challenging time and find a way forward.

In the meantime, try to focus on small achievable goals that can bring a sense of accomplishment and motivation. Surround yourself with supportive friends or seek out online communities where you can find encouragement and understanding. It's important to take care of your mental and emotional well-being during this challenging period.

Remember that you're not alone. Reach out for help if you need it, whether it's from a mental health professional, friends, or support hotlines specifically designed to assist individuals in crisis. There are people who care and want to help you through this difficult time.

post:
It's not even their fault either. I finished my gymnasium degree just a few months ago, which is very bad, but finally at 26 I am done. The reason being was that I was struggling a lot with school as a kid, and then I isolated myself for a few years as I was older. The last 2-3 years I have been working so hard to finally complete my gymnasium degree. There were so many days where I just wanted to die, mainly because of how my entire life had turned out. 

Through all the hardships I managed to do it nontheless. It's just gymnasium, so nothing special at all in Sweden. Everyone has done it. I am now preparing for university next year, with the goal of studying computer science. 

Since coming out of isolation for all those years and talking to people again, has been very difficult. I feel like I am at a point where I would borderline feel infantilized talking to an 18 year old, being a 26 year old guy. There are so many life experiences which I lack, that everyone else my age and younger has.

I am constantly on edge when talking to people, because I am so afraid that they will bring up questions about my past that I would never be able to answer because of how ashamed I am over it. 

I feel like crying when I am talking to people and they speak about all their experiences, countries they visited, love, so on and so forth. I have missed out on all of this and I can not convince myself that I deserve any of it, because I don't have anything to offer as a person. 

My main motivation that I used to get through gymnasium was that once I am done, then I will no longer be ashamed. With gymnasium being the bare minimum, it should put me on an equal playing field with everyone else, so that I wont stand out too much. After finally finishing gymnasium I was crying tears of joy. Then those tears turned to sadness because I realized that it wasn't enough and until I am done with my university degree, that I shouldn't try to make friends or maybe even more.

I truly hate the way my life has turned out. I am trying to do the best out of this terrible situation. I will never be able to catch up on all of life experiences which I missed out on. It almost feels like people my age and sometimes even younger, feel way older when I talk to them, because of how pretty much sheltered I was for a large part of my adulthood.
reply:
Hey Reddit fam, I could really use some support right now. I recently finished my gymnasium degree and even though it's not a big deal in Sweden, it's a huge accomplishment for me. You see, I've had a tough time with school since I was a kid and ended up isolating myself for a few years as I got older. It was a dark period, but I worked my butt off to complete my degree.

Now, I'm gearing up for university and studying computer science, which excites me but also brings up some insecurities. Reconnecting with people after being isolated has been challenging. Sometimes, I feel like I'm way behind in terms of life experiences compared to others my age. It's tough when people discuss things like travel, love, and adventures, and I haven't had those experiences.

I often become anxious during conversations, fearing that I'll be asked questions about my past that I'm ashamed of and can't answer. It's disheartening and I even find myself on the verge of tears. I struggle to convince myself that I deserve happiness and all the things others have experienced.

Finishing gymnasium was supposed to mark the end of my shame, but now I realize it's only the first step. I sometimes question if I should even try to make new friends or pursue relationships until I finish my university degree. I hate how my life has turned out, but I'm doing my best to make the most of this difficult situation. Catching up on all the life experiences I missed feels impossible, and it's disheartening when people my age seem so much more mature due to their diverse experiences.

Any advice or support you can offer would mean the world to me. Thanks, guys. üôè

reply:
I'm sorry to hear that you're feeling this way, but please remember that you are not alone in your struggles. It takes a lot of courage to open up about your feelings, and I commend you for reaching out for support.

First of all, it's important to recognize that your past does not define your worth as a person. Each individual's life path is unique, and comparing yourself to others will only contribute to feelings of inadequacy. Instead, focus on your personal growth and the steps you are taking to improve your situation. Completing your gymnasium degree is a significant accomplishment, regardless of how common it may be in your country.

As you prepare for university, it's understandable to have anxieties about socializing and connecting with others. Remember that everyone has their own insecurities and struggles, even if they may not be obvious. It's okay to not have all the same life experiences as your peers. You are embarking on a new chapter in your life, and this is an opportunity for personal growth and creating new memories.

It can be helpful to find supportive communities or groups related to your interests, such as computer science. Surrounding yourself with people who share similar passions can provide a sense of belonging and understanding. Additionally, consider seeking professional help or counseling to work through any deep-seated feelings of shame or inadequacy. A mental health professional can help you develop coping strategies and guide you on your journey towards self-acceptance.

Remember, it's never too late to start anew and pursue your dreams. Your past does not define your future. Embrace the courage and resilience within you, and know that there are people who are willing to support you on your journey to a happier and more fulfilling life.

I hear how difficult it has been for you to navigate through these challenges and feelings of isolation. It takes a lot of courage to share your experiences and emotions. It's important to remember that everyone's journey is unique, and comparing ourselves to others can often lead to feelings of inadequacy.

You've already shown great resilience and determination by completing your gymnasium degree, despite the hardships you faced. Remember to acknowledge and celebrate your accomplishments along the way, as they are a testament to your strength.

Starting university next year is a significant step towards your goals, and it presents an opportunity to connect with new people and experiences. It is natural to feel anxious or afraid about conversations and questions pertaining to your past. It may be helpful to practice self-compassion and remind yourself that your worth as a person is not defined solely by your past experiences.

Consider seeking support from a mental health professional who can provide guidance and strategies to help you navigate these social interactions. Therapy can be a safe space for processing your emotions and building self-confidence. Additionally, gradually exposing yourself to social situations and engaging in gradual challenges can help build your resilience.

Remember, it is never too late to create fulfilling experiences and connections with others. Focus on your personal growth and the journey ahead, rather than dwelling on the past. You deserve to have happiness and fulfilling relationships in your life, regardless of your previous experiences.

I'm really sorry to hear that you're feeling this way. It can be incredibly challenging when we compare ourselves to others and feel like we've missed out on important life experiences. It's important to remember that everyone's journey is unique and there is no set timeline for personal growth and development.

It's great to hear that you have completed your gymnasium degree and are preparing for university. This shows a great deal of resilience and dedication. Remember, there is no expiration date on education and it's never too late to pursue your passions and goals.

When it comes to socializing and meeting new people, try to focus on the present moment rather than dwelling on the past. You are not defined solely by your past experiences, but also by who you are becoming and what you have to offer. People appreciate authenticity and genuine connections, so don't be afraid to share your thoughts and experiences with others.

Instead of feeling ashamed, try to reframe your mindset and see your unique life journey as something that has shaped you into the person you are today. Your experiences, no matter how different they may be from others, have contributed to your resilience and strength.

Consider seeking support from a mental health professional who can help you work through these feelings of shame and low self-worth. They can provide guidance and strategies for building self-confidence and finding acceptance within yourself.

Remember to be kind to yourself throughout this process. You've already come a long way, and there are still many opportunities for personal growth and connection ahead. You deserve happiness and fulfillment, just like anyone else.

It sounds like you've been through a difficult journey, but please know that your experiences, no matter how different they may be, still hold value. It's important to remember that everyone's path is unique, and comparison can be an unfair measure of self-worth.

Starting university is an exciting opportunity for growth and exploration, both academically and personally. It can also be a chance to connect with others who have similar interests. Remember, age or past experiences don't define your ability to make genuine connections with new people.

Feeling isolated and anxious about discussing your past is understandable, but it might be helpful to remind yourself that everyone has their own struggles and insecurities. Being honest about your journey can actually be a way to foster deeper connections with others who may have faced their own challenges.

If you find yourself overwhelmed with emotions, consider seeking support from a therapist or counselor who can provide guidance during this transition period. They can help you explore your thoughts and emotions, and develop coping strategies to navigate social interactions.

Remember, it's never too late to create new memories and experiences. Focus on the present and future, and embrace the opportunities that come your way. You deserve happiness and personal growth, just like anyone else.

Take it one step at a time, be kind to yourself, and remember that your worth as a person goes beyond any specific life experiences. You are capable of building a fulfilling life, and I believe in your ability to overcome these challenges.

reply:
I'm really sorry to hear that you're feeling this way, and I want you to know that you're not alone in this struggle. It sounds like you're currently in a challenging situation, being away from your usual support system. First and foremost, it's important to prioritize your safety. If you feel like your life is in immediate danger, please reach out to emergency services in Poland or any other support hotlines available in your area right away.

Although you may not have physical access to your usual coping mechanisms, there might still be some things you can do to help alleviate these overwhelming feelings. Try to find a quiet space where you can engage in some self-care activities that bring you comfort. Deep breathing exercises, meditation, or journaling can be helpful in grounding yourself during difficult moments. Consider distracting yourself with activities you enjoy, such as reading a book, watching a show, or listening to music that makes you feel relaxed.

While it's tough that the people you've reached out to haven't responded yet, remember that communication can sometimes be delayed or there might be reasons beyond their control preventing them from responding immediately. In the meantime, it might be helpful to explore online mental health resources. There are many supportive communities, helplines, and mental health forums where you can find understanding and compassionate individuals who can offer advice or simply lend a listening ear.

Whenever you feel ready and comfortable, it could be beneficial to open up to your grandparents about your struggles. They may not have the same level of understanding, but you never know - they might surprise you with their support and love. Sharing your experiences with others can help lighten your emotional burden and allow you to receive the care and understanding that you need.

Remember, you don't have to face this alone. Reaching out for professional help, such as a therapist or counselor, can provide you with the guidance and support you deserve. They can help you develop coping strategies specific to your situation and offer a safe space to express your feelings.

Please take care of yourself. Your life matters, and there is hope for brighter days ahead.

post:
Hi guys, 
I Just feel that I need to tell someone about my doubts. Basically, I am 20, full time employeed in a quite high-earning job (especially considering my age), studying part-time petroleum engineering at the top ranked STEM university in my country, I work out every second day, I keep my diet clean, I never do drugs/smoking/alcohol, I'm 6,6 feet tall and I think that I'm quite mature for my age. The problem is, that I basically don't have "Access" to girls my age. At my job I work only with men, and I study also with only men (let's be honest, petroleum engineering isn't so popular amongst women). I've tried tinder, organised group trips to the mountains, science clubs at my university, even approaching women directly at festivals. None of these methods worked. I've never been in a relationship before, and until I was 19 years old (when I finally went to see a doc and got meds) I struggeled with extreme OCD and social anxiety, so I didn't made any female-friends in the secondary school or earlier in my education (I lived in Norway before secondary school, where, originating from Poland, I got bullied for my ethnicity, and it didn't help me making friends, especially considering my struggle with OCD and social anxiety back them). That's basically it, I try to not think too much about it and rather focus on self-development, however back in my head there is allways this crippling fear that I've missed my shot, and that it is too late for me to ever find a partner that would be attractive and compatible to me. I can especially feel it, when I see couples walking down the streets, or riding in a car together. It's an extremely awful feeling, that stays with me, althought I try to mute it by focusing on my career and gym. However this feeling never quite goes totally away. So, what should I try to do? How should I accept my past? 
Thank you for reading my story guys, I Just really needed to share it with someone.
reply: Hey everyone, I just needed to vent about something that's been bothering me. I'm a 20-year-old guy with a good job and I'm studying petroleum engineering at a top STEM university. I take care of myself, don't drink or smoke, and try to stay active. But here's the thing - because of my job and field of study, I don't really have the opportunity to meet girls my age. I've tried Tinder, group trips, science clubs, and even approaching women directly at festivals, but nothing has worked so far. I struggled with extreme OCD and social anxiety until I was 19, so I didn't make many friends, especially with females, during my earlier years. Sometimes I worry that I missed my chance and won't find someone compatible. Seeing couples together makes me feel pretty awful, even though I try to focus on my career and fitness. So, any advice on what I can do to change this? How can I come to terms with my past? Thanks for taking the time to read and listen, it means a lot to me. #SeekingAdvice #FeelingLost

That's basically it, I try to not think too much about it and rather focus on self-development, however back in my head there is allways this crippling fear that I've missed my shot, and that it is too late for me to ever find a partner that would be attractive and compatible to me. I can especially feel it, when I see couples walking down the streets, or riding in a car together. It's an extremely awful feeling, that stays with me, althought I try to mute it by focusing on my career and gym. However this feeling never quite goes totally away. So, what should I try to do? How should I accept my past? 
Thank you for reading my story guys, I Just really needed to share it with someone.
reply:
Hey there, 

First off, thank you for reaching out and sharing your story. It takes courage to open up about your doubts and concerns. It's great to hear that you've been focusing on self-development and working towards your goals. 

Regarding your struggles in meeting girls your age, it can definitely be challenging when you're surrounded by a predominantly male environment. You've already tried various methods like Tinder, group trips, and science clubs, which is commendable. Remember that finding a partner is not a race, and it's important to be patient and keep an open mind. 

In the meantime, continue to focus on yourself and your personal growth. Building confidence and engaging in activities you enjoy can attract like-minded individuals. Consider exploring new hobbies or joining social groups outside of your current circles. Volunteering or joining community organizations can also be a great way to meet new people, including potential partners. 

Try not to dwell on missed opportunities or compare yourself to others. Each person's journey is unique, and your experiences and past struggles have shaped you into the person you are today. Accepting your past can come through acknowledging your growth and being kind to yourself. It's important to remember that it's never too late to find a partner who appreciates and connects with you.

If you find the fear of missing out or the feeling of inadequacy overwhelming, it might be helpful to seek support from a therapist or counselor. They can provide strategies to manage these emotions and help you navigate your personal journey with more clarity.

Remember, you're not alone, and there are people who understand and support you. Keep focusing on your personal growth, meeting new people, and being open to new opportunities. Stay positive, and don't lose hope. Good luck on your journey towards finding a partner who will be attractive and compatible with you.

It's completely understandable that you feel frustrated and concerned about not having access to potential partners your age due to the nature of your work and study environment.

It's important to remember that finding a compatible partner takes time and can be a process for anyone, regardless of their circumstances. It's also important to acknowledge the progress you have made in managing your OCD and social anxiety, as this can have an impact on forming connections with others.

One suggestion I have is to consider expanding your social circle outside of your work and study environments. This could involve exploring new hobbies or joining social groups that align with your interests. This way, you increase your chances of meeting new people, including potential romantic partners.

Additionally, it might be helpful to work on building your confidence in social situations through therapy or support groups. By addressing any remaining fears or insecurities, you can be better equipped to establish meaningful connections with others.

Remember, it's never too late to find a partner who is attractive and compatible with you. It's important to be patient and kind to yourself during this process. Accepting your past and focusing on self-development are positive steps forward, and with time and persistence, you may find the connection you are seeking.

If you feel that you would benefit from further support, I encourage you to reach out to a mental health professional who can provide guidance and assistance tailored to your specific needs.

Take care and best of luck on your journey towards finding a partner.

Hey there,

I hear you and understand that you're feeling frustrated and lonely in your current situation. It's not easy when your circumstances limit your exposure to potential partners. It's great to hear that you're focusing on self-development and taking care of your physical and mental health.

It's important to remember that finding a partner is not solely dependent on your age or past experiences. It's never too late to meet someone special. Instead of fixating on missed opportunities, try shifting your focus toward the future and the possibilities that lie ahead.

Here are a few suggestions to help you navigate this situation:

1. Expand your social circle: Look for opportunities to meet new people outside of your work and academic environments. Consider joining clubs or organizations that align with your interests or volunteering for causes you care about. This way, you may meet people who share similar interests and values.

2. Utilize online platforms: Besides Tinder, explore other online platforms, such as dating apps or websites, that cater to specific interests or communities. This could potentially broaden your pool of potential partners.

3. Attend social events: Keep an eye out for events in your area, such as parties, networking events, or social gatherings, where you may have the chance to meet new people. These events often provide a more relaxed and casual atmosphere to connect with others.

4. Seek professional support: If you're still struggling with lingering feelings of fear and anxiety, consider reaching out to a therapist or counselor who can help you process your experiences and build strategies to cope with these emotions.

Remember, everyone's journey is unique, and there's no timeline for finding love or a compatible partner. Focus on your personal growth, build meaningful connections, and have faith that the right person will come along when the time is right.

Take care of yourself, and don't hesitate to reach out if you need further support. You're not alone in this.

post: Hello, I am an Italian boy. Since I was little, I have experienced one problem after another. As a child I was often in the hospital because I couldn't balance, I would fall, and I was always bumping around. Once I even hit my head against a chimney, fortunately turned off. Besides that, when I was 3 years old my parents separated. I remember little of my life before that, I only have a vague memory of my father yelling at me and another of the whole family sitting together at the table. My two older brothers grew up in a happy family, and I constantly had to choose between being with my mother or my father. Then at school I was always excluded, always the one in the corner by myself, the last one, ostracized. And it's still like that. I'm tired of it all. I'm tired of making fake smiles at home. I'm tired of making fake smiles school and everywhere. The only friend I had hasn't spoken to me in a few years, I'm completely alone. And sad.
reply: Hey there, I just read your post and my heart goes out to you. It takes a lot of courage to open up and share your struggles. Remember, you are not alone in this journey. It's tough when we have difficult childhood experiences, but remember that those moments don't define who you are. Keep pushing through, be kind to yourself, and reach out for support when you need it. You deserve to be happy and surrounded by people who appreciate you. Stay strong, things will get better! üí™üåü

post:
alt account for this one, im 15M and i have black curly/wavy hair, i love having a small curly fringe sit on my forehead. its been getting kind of long and me and my dad and my mom were out, and we went to a turkish barber, (i went to him last time and it was decent) i told him to do it exactly like last time but a bit *LONGER*. Now it looks like i have a big lump of shit on my head, i told him to keep it curly, he brought it all back. There is nothing i can do now since i can only just wait. 

im not exaggerating when i say i have to mentally prepare myself to look in the mirror, ive had a breakdown 3 times already (im not that sensible, its the first time i cried in months)
and i got this yesterday, saturday and i have a match on monday, and im going out with my girlfriend on tuesday. she says it looks good
from snaps, but im afraid shes going to change her mind when she sees it in real life.

to give you an idea of how lobotomised this haircut is: imagine a facebook post of a pakistani kid, on his first day of school, with his uniform on, a forced smile and a forced haircut. I cant stand my face in the reflection of my phone. 
it completely killed my self confidence, im feeling suicidal, depressed and cant be bothered to do anything. and its going to stay like this for another month, even when it marinates its going to look terrible. 

thank you for reading
reply:
Hey everyone! I really need some hair advice. I recently went to a Turkish barber to get a trim, but unfortunately, it didn't turn out as I expected. My curly/wavy hair was supposed to have a small fringe on my forehead, but now it looks like a big mess on my head. I've tried to mentally prepare myself to look in the mirror, but it's been really tough. I even had a breakdown over it.

To make matters worse, I have a match on Monday and a date with my girlfriend on Tuesday. She says it looks good from snaps, but I'm worried she might change her mind when she sees it in person. It's really killing my self-confidence, and I'm feeling pretty down about it. I'm even tempted to just stay indoors until my hair grows out again.

If anyone has any hair tips or advice on how to deal with a bad haircut, I would be incredibly grateful. Thanks for reading and for any help you can give!

In the meantime, focus on self-care and engaging in activities that make you feel good. Surround yourself with supportive people who value you for who you are, rather than solely on your appearance. Lastly, remember that hair grows back, and in time, you'll be able to try different styles that better suit your preferences.

Take care and remember that you are not alone in this.

post:
alt account for this one, im 15M and i have black curly/wavy hair, i love having a small curly fringe sit on my forehead. its been getting kind of long and me and my dad and my mom were out, and we went to a turkish barber, (i went to him last time and it was decent) i told him to do it exactly like last time but a bit *LONGER*. Now it looks like i have a big lump of shit on my head, i told him to keep it curly, he brought it all back. There is nothing i can do now since i can only just wait. 

im not exaggerating when i say i have to mentally prepare myself to look in the mirror, ive had a breakdown 3 times already (im not that sensible, its the first time i cried in months)
and i got this yesterday, saturday and i have a match on monday, and im going out with my girlfriend on tuesday. she says it looks good
from snaps, but im afraid shes going to change her mind when she sees it in real life.

to give you an idea of how lobotomised this haircut is: imagine a facebook post of a pakistani kid, on his first day of school, with his uniform on, a forced smile and a forced haircut. I cant stand my face in the reflection of my phone. 
it completely killed my self confidence, im feeling suicidal, depressed and cant be bothered to do anything. and its going to stay like this for another month, even when it marinates its going to look terrible. 

thank you for reading
reply:
Hey there, I'm really sorry to hear that you're feeling so down about your haircut. It can be really tough when something like this affects our self-confidence. Remember that how we feel about our appearance is subjective, and what's most important is how you feel about yourself.

It's completely understandable that you're feeling upset and disappointed right now. It's okay to have those emotions and to express them. However, it's important to keep in mind that appearances aren't everything and that beauty truly comes from within.

As for your upcoming match and plans with your girlfriend, try to focus on enjoying those moments and putting your energy into the things that make you happy. Remember, your girlfriend says it looks good from the snaps, and she's likely seen you in different hairstyles before, so she knows you beyond just your physical appearance.

In the meantime, you might want to consider finding ways to boost your self-confidence in other areas of your life. Engaging in activities that you enjoy, spending time with loved ones, and practicing self-care can all help improve your overall well-being.

If these feelings of depression and suicidal thoughts persist or intensify, it's important to seek professional help. Speaking with a mental health professional, such as a therapist or counselor, can provide you with the support and guidance you might need during this difficult time.

Remember, you are not alone, and reaching out for support is a sign of strength. Hang in there, and take care of yourself.

post:
When the year started my young brother of the age of 8 at the time got diagnosed with some sort of cell dysfunction and he spent around 3 months in and out of the hospital.Considering that we are on a pretty underdeveloped country in EU then the doctor didn't know what to do.We had thought of a plan to go to Turkey to get him well some sort of cute but then he fell into a coma.After around 2 weeks in the coma he passed away.
The two things I regret the most are about how I treated him his whole life and that I didn't visit him nearly enough while he was going on and of the hospital.
reply:
üíî Heartbroken üíî My little brother was diagnosed with a rare cell dysfunction earlier this year and had to endure months in and out of the hospital. The doctors in our underdeveloped EU country were at a loss, so we decided to seek treatment in Turkey. But tragedy struck when he unexpectedly slipped into a coma and, devastatingly, he passed away after two long weeks. üò≠

It's been incredibly tough for me, and there are two things that weigh heavily on my heart. Firstly, I deeply regret how I treated him throughout his short life. I wish I had been more understanding, patient, and loving. Secondly, I didn't visit him nearly enough when he was in and out of the hospital, and now I'm filled with immense guilt. üòî

Please, if you have younger siblings or loved ones, cherish every moment with them. Show them love, patience, and kindness. Life can be unpredictable, and we never know when we might lose someone dear to us. Let this be a reminder to treasure and appreciate those we hold close. üôè

#Heartbroken #CherishYourLovedOnes #TreasureEveryMoment

reply:
I'm really sorry to hear about what you've been through. Dealing with the loss of a loved one is never easy, especially when you have regrets and feelings of guilt attached to it. It's important to remember that it's natural to have these thoughts and emotions during such a difficult time.

When it comes to regrets about how you treated your brother, it's important to acknowledge that we all make mistakes and may have moments where we wish we had acted differently. However, it's essential to focus on forgiving yourself. Remember that you were only human and couldn't have predicted what was going to happen. Try to focus on the positive moments you shared with your brother and the love you had for each other.

Regarding not visiting him enough while he was in the hospital, it's understandable that you might feel guilty. However, it's important to recognize that you were probably doing the best you could under the circumstances. Coping with your own emotions and managing the situation might have made things challenging for you.

Moving forward, it might be helpful for you to find a support system. Consider talking to a therapist or joining a grief support group. These environments can provide a safe space for you to express your feelings and gain support from others who have gone through similar experiences.

Remember to be patient and allow yourself time to heal. Grieving is a process, and it's different for everyone. Take it one day at a time and be gentle with yourself. Your brother would want you to find comfort and healing, even amidst the pain.

It might be helpful for you to find ways to process your feelings of guilt and regret, such as talking to a close friend or family member who can offer support or seeking professional help from a therapist. It's also important to remember that you were not solely responsible for your brother's illness or his treatment. post:
Tl:dr my gf was sent to a mental hospital over nothing and i feel broken.

I (y14,t.f) have a gf (y16,f),2 weeks ago she tryied to commit suicide due to one of her "firends" who made up some things,its a long rabbithole but basicly her neighbour sexually assulted her multiple times and she just found out that her neighbours are her bestie's aunt and uncle,her friend try to take revenge by putting her dad in prison. warning!this is where the story starts to be a bit redecilous but bare with me here,we are in romania,its a corupt and broken country.
To save her dad she tryied to commit suicide by sliceing her wrists,she failed and she wound up in the hospital,she luckly wasent sent to the ward,in romania mental hospitals are pretty below avrage,its more of an open prison so they can feel safe knowing a punk that they dont care about wont die. My gf had to go to counceling and had to take anti-depresents,i told her to not take them and she didnt want to either,her mother is a addict for those pills and she doesnt want to end up like her,i dont want her to change since there is nothing wrong with her. At counceling,yesterday to be exact,she felt uncomftrable with some of the questions and didnt answer them,i am the only person she has full trust in,i help her a lot with her mental health as much as i can,becose she refused to answer she was put in a psych ward,i am devistated,she needs certain things that most people dont, for example shes a really picky eater and she needs to take pills becose she is vegan,i support her on being vegan but its hard to take care of,its a long distance relationship and im really scared,she has no phone,we useually feel eachothers feelings,i feel when shes sad and when she cryies,she does too for me,it feels weird,its almost like youre sad for something that you dont know what it is. Shes alone,scared and misses me,i hope she will get out on good behaviour and a bribe,tommorow il get to talk to her,on of our friends is going to visit her tommorow,he promiced he will call me and hand the phone to ada so i can talk to her. I feel lost,our friendgrup is kinda dead now since everyone is with theyr own plans,my bestfriend randomly stopped texting us for no reason,we did nothing out of the ordinary,i really need someone to take care of me and tell me good night,my best friend used to do that but he stopped texting in the worst moment.
reply: Heartbreaking. My girlfriend is in a mental hospital after a traumatic incident. It all started with a false accusation, and things spiraled out of control. We're in Romania, where mental hospitals aren't great. She didn't want to take antidepressants because of her mom's addiction, and now she's in a psych ward after feeling uncomfortable during counseling. I'm devastated and scared. Long distance relationships are tough, and now she has no phone. We usually feel each other's emotions, and it's hard not knowing what she's going through. She's alone and scared, but I hope she gets out soon. Tomorrow, I'll finally get to talk to her when a friend visits her. I feel lost and could really use some support right now. My best friend stopped texting us out of the blue, and it couldn't have happened at a worse time. #supportneeded #feelingbroken

I'm so sorry to hear about everything you and your girlfriend are going through. It's understandable that you feel broken and lost right now. It sounds like your girlfriend has been through a lot of traumatic experiences, and it's important that she receives the help she needs.

I know it can be difficult to see the value in counseling and medication, especially if her mother's addiction has caused negative associations. However, therapy and medication can be very beneficial for many people, and it might be worth considering their potential benefits for her mental health.

In the meantime, it's great that you are supporting her as much as you can. Being there for her and listening to her thoughts and feelings can make a big difference. Even though you can't physically be with her, your emotional support means a lot.

Remember to also take care of yourself during this challenging time. Reach out to other friends or family members who can provide comfort and support. It's important to have a support system in place for times when your best friend isn't available.

I hope that your girlfriend gets the help she needs and that things start to improve soon. Stay strong, and remember that it's okay to reach out for support when you need it.

I'm so sorry to hear that you and your girlfriend are going through such a difficult time. It's understandable that you feel broken given the challenging circumstances. It's important to remember that mental health issues can be complex and require professional help. While it's difficult to provide the specific help that your girlfriend needs, there are some things you can do to support her.

Firstly, it's essential to encourage her to continue with counseling and taking her prescribed medications, as her mental health professionals likely have her best interests in mind. If she has concerns about the medication, encourage her to discuss them openly with her healthcare provider.

You mentioned that you support her in being vegan, which is wonderful. However, it may be beneficial to explore ways to ensure she receives necessary nutrients and medication while following her dietary preferences. Consulting with a healthcare professional or dietitian might provide valuable guidance in this regard.

Maintaining open communication with your girlfriend is crucial during this time. Even though you can't physically be together, try to find ways to stay connected emotionally. Utilize alternative means of communication, such as video calls or letter writing, to offer support and reassurance. It's essential to let her know that you are there for her and empathize with what she's going through.

Additionally, it's understandable that you may be feeling lost and in need of support yourself. Consider reaching out to others in your life, such as other friends or family members, who may be able to provide the comfort and encouragement that you need during this challenging period. Alternatively, you may benefit from seeking support from a mental health professional or counselor who can offer guidance and coping strategies.

Remember, it's important to take care of your own mental well-being too. Prioritize self-care activities that bring you comfort and solace during this difficult time. It can be helpful to engage in hobbies, exercise, practice mindfulness techniques, or reach out to supportive individuals in your life.

Take things one step at a time, and try to remain hopeful in the face of adversity. It's understandable that you may feel scared and uncertain about the future, but remember that there is help available. Encourage your girlfriend to continue seeking the support she needs, and reach out to others in your life to support yourself as well.

post:
Why does quietness or social awkwardness make people so uncomfortable? 

I feel like a leper or pariah. 

Everyone eventually ends up disliking me or thinking I‚Äôm weird. 

Even if they are super nice and friendly to begin with. They always pick up on my anxiety and alien behavior. Il

I‚Äôve managed to alienate all my coworkers in a matter of weeks. I don‚Äôt know how one person can be so unlikeable. 

People (especially other girls) get so uncomfortable around me and they think I‚Äôm naive or mentally delayed. People are afraid to swear around me and think I‚Äôm devoutly religious for some reason. 

I also have a British accent and grew up attending sheltered religious private schools. So this likely impacted my social development and made me overly formal, deferential, and reserved.
reply:
Feeling misunderstood and isolated can be tough, but remember that you are unique and have your own valuable qualities. Being quiet or socially awkward doesn't make you any less likable or deserving of connection. It's important to give yourself credit for the progress you've made.

Remember, not everyone will connect with you, and that's okay. True friendships and relationships are built on understanding and acceptance. Keep being yourself, and you'll find the right people who appreciate you for who you are. Don't let others' discomfort define your self-worth.

Having a British accent and attending religious schools may have influenced your social development, but it doesn't define your entire personality. Embrace your uniqueness and use it as a conversation starter or a way to share your experiences with others. Authenticity is key in building meaningful connections.

Keep learning and growing, but don't feel pressured to change who you are fundamentally. Embrace your own journey and take it one step at a time. You are worthy of love, acceptance, and genuine connections. Keep being true to yourself, and the right people will come into your life. üíô

I‚Äôve managed to alienate all my coworkers in a matter of weeks. I don‚Äôt know how one person can be so unlikeable. 

People (especially other girls) get so uncomfortable around me and they think I‚Äôm naive or mentally delayed. People are afraid to swear around me and think I‚Äôm devoutly religious for some reason. 

I also have a British accent and grew up attending sheltered religious private schools. So this likely impacted my social development and made me overly formal, deferential, and reserved.
reply:
I'm really sorry to hear that you're feeling this way. It can be incredibly challenging when we feel like our social interactions are causing discomfort and misunderstandings. It's important to remember that feelings of social awkwardness and discomfort are a lot more common than you might think.

Many people have their own insecurities and uncertainties when it comes to socializing, and sometimes it can manifest as discomfort around others who are quieter or seem reserved. It's important to remind yourself that this discomfort is not a reflection of your worth or likability as a person.

It's also worth noting that people may make assumptions or judgments based on external factors like your British accent or your background attending religious private schools. While these assumptions can be frustrating, it's crucial to remember that they don't define who you are as an individual.

It might be helpful to try and focus on self-acceptance and building your confidence. Embrace your unique qualities and interests, and surround yourself with people who appreciate and respect you for who you are. Therapy or counseling can also provide a safe space to explore these feelings and work on building social skills and self-esteem.

While change can take time, please remember that you are not alone in feeling this way. With patience, self-compassion, and support, it is possible to navigate social situations with more ease and find acceptance among others.

post:
Today I was coming back to hotel I took an elevator I was alone but then some girl came to elevator too I was scared I didnt looked at her but she started a conversation about do I enjoy my stay at hotel and is it my first time in Austria. I said Yes and thats its very nice here she then asked me where i was from i said I was from poland and stuff she asked about weather. When elevator finally stopped at my floor I thanked her and got off as fast as I can and go to my room.
I felt happy I could actually talk without stutters or weird mumbling im kinda happy even tho this conversation was kinda one sided cause most of things I said was "yes" "no" but im still happy and the elevator ride felt like it was going up forever
reply: Had a little victory today! Took an elevator at my hotel and ended up having a conversation with a girl who got in. Initially scared, I managed to talk about my stay in Austria and she even asked about the weather. Although I mostly responded with "yes" and "no," I felt so happy that I could talk without any speech issues. The elevator ride felt like it was going on forever, but it was a small win for me. üòä

post:
As a 16 year old in high school, I do relatively well grades-wise. However, when it comes to socializing, I'm a failure. I don't really talk unless I'm talked to, which is close to never. I get that it's kind of on me that I don't have many friends, but that's aside from the point. Besides, I'm sure my RBF is probably to blame as well.

Due to me being quiet, it seems that everybody around me makes up terrible and untrue things about me. Some that I hear a lot are "school shooter", "kidnapper", and (my personal favorite) "The Riddler from The Batman". I have never really understood why. Isn't being called a school shooter what can cause one? It's not like I would even want to hurt anybody around me.

This has completely demotivated me from making friends at all. I fear that I'll be seen as a creep even if I try to socialize. It's not even that I look bad or something, I just have a bad rep for no reason. If I'm called to talk in class, I always hear the reaction of "he can talk??????". It's as if I'm not even seen as another person by them.

When it comes to the rare few I have talked to, they don't even know my name. They refer to me as "Tyrone", "Lebron", or some other random name. Sometimes I'm just reduced to "white boy". I get that it's all light hearted, but it's pretty damn demeaning. I'd like to speak up about it, but I fear I'll just be shut down instantly with how kids my age are.

There are a few kind people who have taken the time to actually understand who I am. The majority of them are women. However, any time I am speaking with them, somebody always has to say something like "W Rizz" (even though I'm talking to them completely platonically) and it just makes things awkward. It seems like I'm seen as a joke everywhere around school. I wish people around me would understand that I'm a human being with feelings.

At some point last year, we were to do group projects in an English class. The teacher assigned groups based off who was friends with each other, and, seeing as I had no friends in the class, I got paired up with people who had special needs. This wouldn't have been a problem if it weren't for the fact that not only was the entire workload up to me for the quarter, but I was beginning to be seen as special needs myself. I haven't even been diagnosed for any neurodivergence. This only made people make fun of me even more.

As much as I want to get through high school, the people around me make it a living hell. What should I do? I would love to ignore them, but it's pretty hard when it's everywhere I go. I just want to be seen as an actual human being.
reply: Hey there! It sounds like you're going through a tough time in high school. Remember that you are not alone and there are people out there who understand how you feel. It's unfortunate that some people resort to making up hurtful things, but try not to let their words define you. Focus on building relationships with those who appreciate and respect you for who you are. It's great to hear that there are a few kind people who understand you - cherish those connections. If the negativity becomes overwhelming, consider talking to a trusted adult or counselor who can offer guidance. Keep being yourself, and remember that you are worthy of being seen and heard. Stay strong! üí™

I'm sorry to hear that you're going through such a challenging time in high school. It sounds like you're feeling isolated, misunderstood, and demeaned by your peers. It's important to remember that you are not alone in feeling this way, and there are steps you can take to address these issues.

Firstly, know that you are not defined by the negative perceptions others may have of you. It's important to focus on your own self-worth and not let these hurtful comments define your identity. Building self-esteem and confidence can help you navigate these situations more effectively.

Consider seeking support from a trusted adult, such as a school counselor or teacher, who can provide guidance and advocate for your needs. They may be able to help implement strategies to address the mistreatment you're experiencing and promote a more inclusive and respectful environment.

Lastly, taking care of your mental and emotional well-being is crucial. Consider engaging in activities that bring you joy and help you relax, such as hobbies, exercise, or spending time in nature. If your feelings of sadness or anxiety persist, consider seeking support from a mental health professional who can assist you in navigating and coping with these challenges.

You deserve to be seen and treated with respect and compassion. It may take time, but with the right support and strategies, you can create a more positive high school experience.
