Due to me being quiet, it seems that everybody around me makes up terrible and untrue things about me. Some that I hear a lot are "school shooter", "kidnapper", and (my personal favorite) "The Riddler from The Batman". I have never really understood why. Isn't being called a school shooter what can cause one? It's not like I would even want to hurt anybody around me.

This has completely demotivated me from making friends at all. I fear that I'll be seen as a creep even if I try to socialize. It's not even that I look bad or something, I just have a bad rep for no reason. If I'm called to talk in class, I always hear the reaction of "he can talk??????". It's as if I'm not even seen as another person by them.

When it comes to the rare few I have talked to, they don't even know my name. They refer to me as "Tyrone", "Lebron", or some other random name. Sometimes I'm just reduced to "white boy". I get that it's all light hearted, but it's pretty damn demeaning. I'd like to speak up about it, but I fear I'll just be shut down instantly with how kids my age are.

There are a few kind people who have taken the time to actually understand who I am. The majority of them are women. However, any time I am speaking with them, somebody always has to say something like "W Rizz" (even though I'm talking to them completely platonically) and it just makes things awkward. It seems like I'm seen as a joke everywhere around school. I wish people around me would understand that I'm a human being with feelings.

At some point last year, we were to do group projects in an English class. The teacher assigned groups based off who was friends with each other, and, seeing as I had no friends in the class, I got paired up with people who had special needs. This wouldn't have been a problem if it weren't for the fact that not only was the entire workload up to me for the quarter, but I was beginning to be seen as special needs myself. I haven't even been diagnosed for any neurodivergence. This only made people make fun of me even more.

As much as I want to get through high school, the people around me make it a living hell. What should I do? I would love to ignore them, but it's pretty hard when it's everywhere I go. I just want to be seen as an actual human being.
reply:
Hey there, I'm really sorry to hear that you're going through such a tough time at school. It's clear that you're feeling isolated and mistreated because of how others perceive you. It can be incredibly challenging to deal with such negative stereotypes and hurtful comments, especially when you're just trying to navigate your way through high school.

First off, it's important to remember that you are not defined by the hurtful things others say about you. You are a unique individual with your own thoughts, feelings, and potential. It's completely normal to feel demotivated and afraid to socialize when you're constantly surrounded by negativity, but try not to let it discourage you from seeking connections with others. 

Have you considered talking to a school counselor or a trusted adult about what you're going through? They may be able to offer you guidance, support, and resources to help navigate this challenging situation. It might also be worth trying to engage in activities or groups that align with your interests outside of school. This could provide an opportunity to meet new people who share similar passions and have a different perspective on your worth as a person.

Remember, building meaningful connections takes time and effort. Try to focus on nurturing the few kind relationships you've mentioned, as they can be invaluable in providing support and understanding. Lastly, it's important to prioritize your own mental well-being. Engaging in self-care activities, such as hobbies, exercise, or creative outlets, can help you maintain a healthier mindset amidst the negativity.

Always remember that you are deserving of respect and kindness. It may be difficult right now, but there are people out there who will see you for who you truly are. Stay strong and hang in there.

post:
(M30). Have had OCD, anxiety, health anxiety since I was little.

A year ago I was lying in bed to sleep, it was the middle of the night. Suddenly out of nowhere I find it hard to breathe, I get palpitations and a burning sensation in my chest. I get out of bed thinking I'm having a heart attack. I go to the emergency room and after EKG (ECG), tests, blood test and blood pressure measurement, they send me home.

I contact the local health center as after that episode I started to have irregular heartbeats. The doctors take my blood test, urine test, they do an EKG on me, and all values look good. My doctor concludes that it is anxiety and panic, so I see a psychologist. I have trauma from childhood and the year before (2021) my grandmother passed away suddenly, my grandmother who raised me (basically).

I continued to contact the local practitioner as I could wake up in the middle of the night completely out of breath and a racing heart. I am constantly worried about having heart disease, such as a stroke or heart attack, but the doctors say my heart is normal.

I continued to have heart palpitations several days a week, had constant chest pressure and chest pain and finally got a referral to a heart specialist clinic. There they connected me to machines, did an echocardiogram, ultrasound and I had to perform a test where I cycled while connected to machines. According to the results, my heart is normal.

I keep waking up at night with my breath in my throat, the feeling of someone strangling me, pain in my stomach and pressure on my chest and a constant worry and fear of death. I go back to university in 2 weeks, looking forward to that, but really don‚Äôt want this shit to affect my studies and social interactions too much. 

I don‚Äôt know what to do. Really. I‚Äôm on the edge my family members have had it, they don‚Äôt want to hear it and they think I‚Äôm crazy. I‚Äôve always been an anxious kid, I‚Äôm afraid of dying constantly and I think about that a lot, but since I had that one ‚Äúmajor‚Äù panic attack, my life has changed completely and I haven‚Äôt felt well for over a year now. 

I see a therapist, but not that often, once a month maybe (your typical underfunded Scandinavian free health care office). But I‚Äôll have more appointments in the autumn. But i think about trying CBT.

Also, one thing that gets me to relax is meditation, East Asian calming music and Tibetan bowls. I‚Äôm thinking about learning Transcendental Meditation.
reply: Hey there! I'm really sorry to hear that you've been going through such a tough time with your anxiety and health concerns. It's great that you've been proactive in seeking medical help and seeing a therapist. Taking care of your mental health is so important. Have you ever tried incorporating mindfulness techniques into your everyday routine? It sounds like meditation and calming music have been helpful for you, so perhaps exploring more mindfulness practices like CBT or Transcendental Meditation could be worth a try. Hang in there, and remember that you're not alone. Sending positive vibes your way! üåü

reply:
I'm sorry to hear that you're going through such a difficult time, but please know that you're not alone in your struggles. Many people with OCD, anxiety, and health anxiety can relate to what you're experiencing. It's important to remember that anxiety can often manifest in physical symptoms, such as difficulty breathing, palpitations, and chest pain, even when there isn't a physical cause.

It sounds like you've taken the right steps by visiting doctors and specialists to rule out any underlying physical health issues. Their reassurance that your heart is normal is a positive sign. However, I understand that it can be challenging to accept these findings when anxiety is strong.

Continuing therapy is a great idea, and it's good to hear that you'll have more frequent appointments in the near future. Therapy, especially cognitive-behavioral therapy (CBT), can be very helpful for managing anxiety and intrusive thoughts. It can provide you with tools and techniques to challenge and change negative thought patterns.

In addition to therapy, it's great that you've found some relaxation techniques that work for you, such as meditation and listening to calming music. Consider incorporating these practices into your daily routine to help manage your anxiety. Learning Transcendental Meditation could be a positive step, as it has been shown to have benefits for stress reduction and overall well-being. Just remember to give yourself time and patience as you explore different coping mechanisms.

Lastly, it may be helpful to seek support from a mental health forum or support group where you can connect with others who understand what you're going through. Sharing experiences, hearing different perspectives, and receiving validation can be comforting and empowering.

Remember, recovery is a journey, and it takes time and effort. Be kind to yourself and celebrate small victories along the way. You may also want to consider talking to your therapist about any concerns you have about your studies and social interactions, as they can offer guidance and support in managing those areas of your life.

Hang in there, and know that you have the strength to overcome this. Keep reaching out for help and utilizing the resources available to you. You're not alone, and there is hope for a brighter future.

reply:
I'm really sorry to hear that you've been experiencing these symptoms and feelings for such a long time. It sounds like you've taken the important step of seeking medical help and ruling out any physical health concerns.

Given your history of OCD, anxiety, and health anxiety, it's possible that what you're experiencing could be related to anxiety and panic. Anxiety can cause a wide range of physical symptoms, including difficulty breathing, palpitations, chest discomfort, and stomach pain. It's not uncommon for anxiety to worsen during periods of stress or after traumatic events, such as the loss of your grandmother.

I'm glad to hear that you're seeing a therapist, even though it's not as frequent as you would like. Cognitive-behavioral therapy (CBT) can be very effective in helping individuals manage anxiety and related symptoms. It focuses on identifying and challenging unhelpful thoughts and behaviors, and developing more adaptive coping strategies.

In addition to CBT, meditation, and listening to calming music can be great self-care tools to help you relax and manage anxiety. Learning Transcendental Meditation could be a valuable addition to your coping toolbox.

It's essential to continue prioritizing your mental health and seeking support. If possible, consider discussing with your therapist the possibility of increasing the frequency of your sessions or exploring other treatment options that may be available. You deserve ongoing care and support for your well-being.

Remember, you're not alone in this journey, and help is available. Keep taking steps towards self-care and reaching out for support when needed.

I'm really sorry to hear that you're struggling with these symptoms and anxiety. It sounds like you've been through a lot, both in terms of your childhood trauma and the loss of your grandmother. It's common for traumatic events and losses to impact our mental and physical well-being.

It can be reassuring to know that your heart is healthy, but I understand that the symptoms and worries persist. Anxiety can be incredibly overwhelming, and it can manifest in physical symptoms like palpitations and chest pain.

Continuing therapy is a good step, even if it's not as frequent as you would like. CBT (cognitive-behavioral therapy) is often recommended for anxiety disorders, including health anxiety. post:
24M

Hi all, first of all i‚Äôm NOT asking for a diagnosis. Been to the GP several times. Just searching for some insights and opinions..

So there‚Äôs some things I‚Äôve been struggling with for years. Father died in 2013 of cancer, had very difficult years after in which I didn‚Äôt grieve his death. Also had a very manipulative girlfriend from 2013 tot 2018. Been also having OCD since I were a kid.

When that relationship ended I started to develop a cough and bowel issues. I saw that my stools were thin and weird. Saw my GP for both issues, but she assured me it would be nothing. Health anxiety started to get worse and I started getting panic attacks. Years passed and the symptoms didn‚Äôt go away. Went to my GP so many times to get reassurance about my health..

Last year in april I moved to a new place with my new girlfriend who is my fianc√©e today! Around that time I felt a very hard immovable lump in my neck that freaked me out. Started worrying about cancer and convinced myself I had it. Went to my GP who referred me for an echo, but nothing weird. Could be an extra rib they said in the hospital. Anyhow, that lump freaked me out to the MAX and I developed an one sided headache at that time. It‚Äôs more of like a head pressure around my right temple that sometimes radiates to the neck. It‚Äôs literally always there from waking up to going to sleep. Doesn‚Äôt wake me up tho. Developed (in my imagination) one sided weakness on the left side, which suddenly went away. The cough I had for years disappeared out of nothing but now I‚Äôm left with this one sided head pressure that‚Äôs constantly there for 14 months now. Also since a couple of months occasionally a weird smell. For some hours my smell gets distorted and then out of nothing (usually after sleeping) it resets. Bloods are perfect and did some neuro tests (reflexes, pupils etc) and everything is OK. GP doesn‚Äôt see a need for an MRI because if it were a brain tumor she‚Äôd likely see something in the tests and the symptoms would‚Äôve gotten waayy worse over the course of a year. Also still left with bowel issues. Never a solid stool, always gassy and stools smell bad. Thought I had blood in my stool but my GP said it was undigested foods. Also a constant pressure in my lower left abdomen. Don‚Äôt know what to do now, doc says it‚Äôs all because of high amounts of stress I put my body to.

Is it really possible that I have this one sided constant pressure because of something psychomatic for so long? It didn‚Äôt get worse over time. Also the bowel movements, could this really be stress for so many years? Doc also said bowel cancer usually gives anemia, which i don‚Äôt have. Also have strong depersonalization issues for some years which worsened A LOT the last couple of weeks.. no one notices anything. 

I sometimes think I developed bowel cancer some years ago and last year it metastized to my brain and have it there also since. Is this something realistic or am I not being sober in this? Is my heavy derealization from a tumor or more likely the anxiety and trauma‚Äôs. Last weeks everything feels very fake.

I would think.. if it were something so serious, something would‚Äôve happened by now right? The phantosmia, the head pressure (that sometimes gets really mild almost not noticable), (perceived) weakness and pulsating tingling in left side of the body would‚Äôve developed significantly if it were really something right? This derealization is not cool.. want to feel normal again..

Sorry for my english btw, I‚Äôm dutch.
reply:
Hey there! I'm really sorry to hear that you've been struggling with these symptoms for so long. It sounds like you've been through a lot, especially with the loss of your father and the difficult relationship you mentioned. It's great that you've been to the GP several times to seek help and get reassurance. While I can't provide a diagnosis, I would like to offer some support and insights.

It's important to remember that stress can have a significant impact on our bodies, and it can manifest in various ways, including bowel issues, headaches, and other physical symptoms. Our emotions and mental state can definitely affect our overall well-being. It's great that your blood tests and neuro tests came back normal, as that's a positive sign.

If you're feeling concerned about your symptoms, it might be helpful to speak with your GP about exploring different approaches to managing stress and anxiety. They may be able to suggest some coping strategies or refer you to a mental health professional who can provide additional support.

Remember, you're not alone in this. Many people struggle with similar experiences, and reaching out for help is a courageous step. Keep taking care of yourself and seeking the support you need. Wishing you all the best on your journey to feeling better!

It's understandable that you're worried about serious medical conditions, but it's important to trust the medical professionals you've seen. They've conducted tests and reassured you that there doesn't seem to be anything concerning. Usually, symptoms wouldn't persist for such a long period without any significant changes if there were a serious underlying condition. Trusting your doctor's expertise can help alleviate some anxiety.

Regarding the depersonalization and derealization you've been experiencing, they can often relate to anxiety and trauma. These symptoms can feel very overwhelming, but they are likely a result of the emotional distress you've been through. It might be helpful to seek support from a mental health professional who can provide guidance and help you process these experiences.

Remember that you're not alone in this, and seeking support from loved ones or a support group can also be beneficial. They can offer understanding and empathy, and share their own experiences which might help you feel less alone.

Lastly, I would encourage you to continue seeing your doctor for routine check-ups and discussing any concerns you may have. They can monitor your physical health and provide appropriate guidance based on their expertise.

Take care, and remember that seeking support is a brave and important step towards taking care of your mental health.

Hi all, first of all i‚Äôm NOT asking for a diagnosis. Been to the GP several times. Just searching for some insights and opinions..

So there‚Äôs some things I‚Äôve been struggling with for years. Father died in 2013 of cancer, had very difficult years after in which I didn‚Äôt grieve his death. Also had a very manipulative girlfriend from 2013 tot 2018. Been also having OCD since I were a kid.

When that relationship ended I started to develop a cough and bowel issues. I saw that my stools were thin and weird. Saw my GP for both issues, but she assured me it would be nothing. Health anxiety started to get worse and I started getting panic attacks. Years passed and the symptoms didn‚Äôt go away. Went to my GP so many times to get reassurance about my health..

Last year in april I moved to a new place with my new girlfriend who is my fianc√©e today! Around that time I felt a very hard immovable lump in my neck that freaked me out. Started worrying about cancer and convinced myself I had it. Went to my GP who referred me for an echo, but nothing weird. Could be an extra rib they said in the hospital. Anyhow, that lump freaked me out to the MAX and I developed an one sided headache at that time. It‚Äôs more of like a head pressure around my right temple that sometimes radiates to the neck. It‚Äôs literally always there from waking up to going to sleep. Doesn‚Äôt wake me up tho. Developed (in my imagination) one sided weakness on the left side, which suddenly went away. The cough I had for years disappeared out of nothing but now I‚Äôm left with this one sided head pressure that‚Äôs constantly there for 14 months now. Also since a couple of months occasionally a weird smell. For some hours my smell gets distorted and then out of nothing (usually after sleeping) it resets. Bloods are perfect and did some neuro tests (reflexes, pupils etc) and everything is OK. GP doesn‚Äôt see a need for an MRI because if it were a brain tumor she‚Äôd likely see something in the tests and the symptoms would‚Äôve gotten waayy worse over the course of a year. Also still left with bowel issues. Never a solid stool, always gassy and stools smell bad. Thought I had blood in my stool but my GP said it was undigested foods. Also a constant pressure in my lower left abdomen. Don‚Äôt know what to do now, doc says it‚Äôs all because of high amounts of stress I put my body to.

Is it really possible that I have this one sided constant pressure because of something psychomatic for so long? It didn‚Äôt get worse over time. Also the bowel movements, could this really be stress for so many years? Doc also said bowel cancer usually gives anemia, which i don‚Äôt have. Also have strong depersonalization issues for some years which worsened A LOT the last couple of weeks.. no one notices anything. 

I sometimes think I developed bowel cancer some years ago and last year it metastized to my brain and have it there also since. Is this something realistic or am I not being sober in this? Is my heavy derealization from a tumor or more likely the anxiety and trauma‚Äôs. Last weeks everything feels very fake.

I would think.. if it were something so serious, something would‚Äôve happened by now right? The phantosmia, the head pressure (that sometimes gets really mild almost not noticable), (perceived) weakness and pulsating tingling in left side of the body would‚Äôve developed significantly if it were really something right? This derealization is not cool.. want to feel normal again..

Sorry for my english btw, I‚Äôm dutch.
reply:
Hello,

Thank you for reaching out and sharing your experiences. It sounds like you have been through a lot of challenging situations and have been dealing with various physical and emotional symptoms. It's important to remember that I cannot provide a diagnosis or medical advice, but I can offer some insights and opinions based on what you've described. 

Regarding the physical symptoms you mentioned, it's possible for stress and anxiety to manifest in physical ways, such as the constant one-sided head pressure and bowel issues. When our body is under stress, it can affect different systems and lead to various symptoms. It's important to continue working closely with your GP to rule out any potential medical causes.

Your experiences with derealization and depersonalization can also be linked to anxiety and trauma. These dissociative experiences are part of the body's way of coping with overwhelming stress. Trauma can have a significant impact on our mental and emotional well-being, and it may be helpful to explore these experiences with a mental health professional who can provide support and guidance.

While it's natural to have worries and doubts about your health, it's important to also consider that anxiety can sometimes amplify perceived symptoms or make them seem more severe than they actually are. However, it's essential to work with your GP to monitor your symptoms and address any concerns you may have.

Consider reaching out to a mental health clinician who can support you in managing stress, anxiety, and any underlying trauma. They can help you explore coping strategies, provide a safe space for processing emotions, and offer additional insights and support tailored to your specific needs. Remember, you don't have to face these challenges alone, and seeking professional help can be a valuable step towards finding relief and feeling like yourself again.

Take care.

*(Note: This response is for illustrative purposes only and should not be used as a substitute for professional mental health advice.)*

post: Hi, I am a physician leading a highly effective hyperbaric oxygen therapy program for PTSD, currently supported by the Israeli MOD for treatment-resistant veterans. I seek to make this treatment available to US veterans who may need it. How can I contact veteran associations and hyperbaric centers to explore knowledge sharing?
reply:
Hello,

Thank you for reaching out and for your dedication to helping veterans with PTSD. It's great to hear about your hyperbaric oxygen therapy program and your efforts to make it available to US veterans.

To connect with veteran associations and hyperbaric centers for knowledge sharing, here are a few steps you can consider:

1. Research Veteran Associations: Look for reputable veteran associations in the US that focus on PTSD and mental health support for veterans. Some well-known organizations include the Veterans of Foreign Wars (VFW), Disabled American Veterans (DAV), and the American Legion. Explore their websites to learn more about their resources and contact details.

2. Send Inquiries: Once you have identified the relevant veteran associations, reach out to them by email or phone. Introduce yourself, explain the purpose of your inquiry, and outline your interest in sharing knowledge about your hyperbaric oxygen therapy program. Be specific about what you want to accomplish and how it can benefit US veterans. Request their guidance or any potential avenues for collaboration.

3. Connect with Hyperbaric Centers: In addition to reaching out to veteran associations, it would be beneficial to establish connections with hyperbaric centers in the US as well. Research well-known hyperbaric centers in the country, and contact them with a similar introductory message as you did with the veteran associations. Inquire about their expertise in treating PTSD and discuss the possibility of knowledge sharing or potential collaboration.

4. Attend Conferences and Workshops: Consider attending conferences, workshops, or seminars that focus on mental health, PTSD, and hyperbaric oxygen therapy. These events often bring together professionals and organizations working in the field. By participating, you can network, gain insights, and potentially connect with relevant experts and associations.

Remember to be persistent in your efforts, as it may take time to establish connections and find the right partners. The valuable knowledge and experience you have gained through your program could greatly benefit US veterans, so keep pursuing opportunities for sharing your expertise.

Best of luck in your endeavors, and thank you again for your commitment to helping veterans with PTSD.

Take care.

post:
Hello.

Normally i don't write depressing shit about myself but i just can't take it anymore seriously.                     
 I have always been a happy person and had lot of well (Friends) i thought but it all went downhill...

First of all im 18 years old with a child, How you ask? my girl lied about using contraceptives and decided to keep the child and afterwards cheated on me. I love the child to death but thinking he grows up with parents seperated so early and seeing him not much breaks my heart in pieces. I keep trying to hold all that weight and keep going forward to do the best for my child but then i realised my friends hated me and used me for my car and money. So all the childhood friends with good memories just didn't give a f about me. I tried to tell my parents but they didn't take me seriously and just said i need to be a man and be there for my child, All easy said when you've been dealing with depression almost all your life and when you finally build yourself up in position that you're happy... you get shot with multiple arrows at once and fall all the way back down, when this time you have no one to help you. I also lost my job recently due a miscommunication and im in a big financial problem now. I feel like no girls like me or even find me attractive when im literally behaving as myself and still take care of myself.

All my life it's been a journey of dragging myself up and get shot down every... single... time...              
 Say what you want about me that it's partly my fault, because yes it is. But making mistakes is a part of life but honestly i just can't bear the weight anymore.

The message is long but i just need to express myself somewhere.

Sorry if the message is written poorly it's because im Dutch

Thank you for the people that care to read this lol.

​

​
reply:
Hey there,

I just read your message and wanted to let you know that you're not alone. Life can be tough sometimes, especially when it feels like everything is falling apart. It's important to remember that you don't have to face it all by yourself. There are people out there who care and want to help.

Being a young parent is definitely a challenging situation, but you're doing your best for your child, and that's truly admirable. It's understandable that you're going through a mixture of emotions right now. Take it one day at a time and remember that your love and dedication to your child is what matters the most.

It's unfortunate to hear about the friends who let you down. It can be tough when the people we trust end up hurting us. But remember, true friends are those who stand by you through thick and thin. Surround yourself with people who genuinely care about your well-being.

Regarding your job and financial situation, try not to lose hope. Life has its ups and downs, and setbacks happen to everyone. Keep searching for new opportunities and stay positive. Remember, your value isn't tied to your employment status.

Lastly, please don't doubt your self-worth based on how you think others perceive you. Attractiveness isn't just about physical appearance, it's about being genuine and true to yourself. Focus on taking care of yourself and finding happiness within. The right people will appreciate you for who you are.

Remember, it's okay to reach out for support. There are helplines, support groups, and online communities that can provide you with guidance and solace during difficult times. Hang in there, friend. You matter, and there are brighter days ahead. Sending you good vibes. ‚ú®

I keep trying to hold all that weight and keep going forward to do the best for my child but then i realised my friends hated me and used me for my car and money. So all the childhood friends with good memories just didn't give a f about me. I tried to tell my parents but they didn't take me seriously and just said i need to be a man and be there for my child, All easy said when you've been dealing with depression almost all your life and when you finally build yourself up in position that you're happy... you get shot with multiple arrows at once and fall all the way back down, when this time you have no one to help you. I also lost my job recently due a miscommunication and im in a big financial problem now. I feel like no girls like me or even find me attractive when im literally behaving as myself and still take care of myself.

All my life it's been a journey of dragging myself up and get shot down every... single... time...              
 Say what you want about me that it's partly my fault, because yes it is. But making mistakes is a part of life but honestly i just can't bear the weight anymore.

The message is long but i just need to express myself somewhere.

Sorry if the message is written poorly it's because im Dutch

Thank you for the people that care to read this lol.

​

​
reply:

It sounds like you're dealing with a lot of different issues all at once, including the strain of being a young parent, experiencing betrayal from your partner, feeling used by friends, and facing financial difficulties. These stressors can definitely take a toll on your mental well-being and make it difficult to see a way forward.

It's important to know that you don't have to go through this alone. While I may not be able to provide the specific help that you need, I encourage you to seek support from professionals who can. Remember that it's okay to ask for help, whether it's from friends, family, or professionals. Taking care of your mental health is a crucial step in navigating these challenges and finding a way to move forward. You deserve understanding and support during this difficult time.

Take care of yourself, and please reach out if you need further assistance.

reply:
I'm really sorry to hear that you're going through such a tough time right now. It sounds like you've been dealt with some difficult circumstances and it's completely understandable that you're feeling overwhelmed. It's important to remember that you're not alone, even though it may feel that way at times.

It's great that you're trying to do your best for your child, despite all the challenges you're facing. Being a parent is incredibly tough, and navigating a separation at such a young age is definitely not easy. Try to give yourself some credit for the effort you're putting in.

Building a support network can take time, but there are people out there who will appreciate you for who you are and support you through thick and thin. Consider joining local parenting groups or seeking out counseling or therapy, as they can provide a safe space to share your feelings and connect with others who may be going through similar experiences.

Losing a job and facing financial difficulties only adds to the stress and pressure you're already experiencing. It might be helpful to reach out to local support services that can provide guidance and resources for finding employment or managing your finances. Remember, there is no shame in asking for help when you need it.

Lastly, it's important to take care of your own well-being during this challenging time. Self-care is crucial, even if it feels like a small step. Whether it's engaging in activities you enjoy, seeking professional help, or finding healthy ways to cope with your emotions, prioritize your own mental health. Remember to be patient and kind to yourself through this process. You deserve support and understanding.

Take care.

reply:
Hi there,

I'm sorry to hear that you're going through such a difficult time right now. It sounds like you're dealing with a lot of challenges all at once, and it's understandable that it feels overwhelming.

First of all, it's important to acknowledge that you didn't deserve to be lied to and cheated on. It's unfortunate that your relationship ended this way, especially considering the impact it has on your child and your own emotional well-being. It's completely normal to feel heartbroken and worried about the future when facing such a situation.

It must be really tough to realize that some of your friends weren't genuine and were only interested in what they could get from you. Betrayal like that can leave deep wounds, and it's important to surround yourself with people who genuinely care about you and your well-being.

Regarding your parents' response, it can be disappointing when the support we hope for doesn't materialize. Sometimes, others may not fully understand the complexity of our emotions or the challenges we're facing. That doesn't mean your feelings are invalid or that you should just "be a man." It's important to find a support system that will truly listen and provide the empathy and understanding you need.

Losing your job and facing financial struggles on top of everything else can be incredibly stressful. It's normal to feel anxious and worried about the future. Remember that this setback doesn't define your entire life and career. This is an opportunity for growth and finding new possibilities, even if it seems difficult right now.

It's important to remember that you are worthy of love and connection. Attractiveness is not solely determined by external factors, but rather by how a person carries themselves and treats others. Focus on being true to yourself and taking care of your own well-being. Eventually, the right people will be drawn to your genuine self.

I encourage you to reach out to mental health resources available in your community. Seeking professional help from a counselor or therapist can provide you with the support and guidance you need during this challenging time. They can help you navigate your emotions, develop healthy coping strategies, and create a plan to move forward.

Remember, expressing yourself and seeking support is an important step toward healing. You're not alone in this journey, and there are people who care. Take one step at a time, and be gentle with yourself along the way.

Take care.

post:
At 23 years old I moved from Rome to the Netherlands to study for my Master, and I had the time of my life. I made a lot of friends from every possible country, I had been in love, I have discovered a lot about myself. 
Moving from the center of Rome, one of the biggest cities in the world, to such a small country like The Netherlands. What I found there was open-mindedness and obviously a very international and different social setting, which has led me indeed to bond with many different people with different backgrounds and thus likely habits.
Then though, I had to move back to Rome at the end of the experience, but after one year staying here I feel like my life has no purpose here. I was used to a life of new discoveries everyday, I was challenged to change my habits in order to experiment new cultures, but now it all disappeared. How do you manage to go back to the usual routine and the usual neighborhood life? Everybody told me to try and change it, but how can you really, in such an environment? Should I go alone to places and introduce myself?
reply: "üåç‚ú® Missing the adventure and international connections! üöÄ After an incredible experience studying abroad in the Netherlands, I moved back to Rome and something feels off. üòî I got used to the excitement of discovering new cultures and making friends from all over the world. Now, it feels like my life lacks purpose. üè†üîÅ How do you adjust to going back to your old routine and neighborhood life? Any suggestions on blending the best of both worlds? ‚ú®üí´ Should I take the plunge and explore new places solo? ü§î Share your thoughts and tips! üåü #CultureShock #NewBeginnings #InternationalConnections"

Moving from the center of Rome, one of the biggest cities in the world, to such a small country like The Netherlands. What I found there was open-mindedness and obviously a very international and different social setting, which has led me indeed to bond with many different people with different backgrounds and thus likely habits.
Then though, I had to move back to Rome at the end of the experience, but after one year staying here I feel like my life has no purpose here. I was used to a life of new discoveries everyday, I was challenged to change my habits in order to experiment new cultures, but now it all disappeared. How do you manage to go back to the usual routine and the usual neighborhood life? Everybody told me to try and change it, but how can you really, in such an environment? Should I go alone to places and introduce myself?
reply:
I'm sorry to hear that you're feeling this way after moving back to Rome. It can be quite difficult to readjust to a different routine and social setting after experiencing such a vibrant international community in the Netherlands. 

One approach you might consider is trying to bring some of the openness and diversity from your time in the Netherlands into your life in Rome. Although it may not be exactly the same, there are likely opportunities to meet people from different backgrounds within your city. 

You mentioned going alone to places and introducing yourself, and that can be a great way to start. Consider exploring different social or cultural events that interest you, such as language exchanges, meetup groups, or cultural festivals in Rome. This can introduce you to new people and potentially create opportunities for new friendships.

Additionally, connecting with expat communities in Rome could be helpful. They often have social events or support groups where you can meet others who may have gone through similar experiences and can understand what you're going through. Online forums or social media groups specifically for expats in Rome can be a great resource for finding these communities.

Remember that change takes time and it may not happen overnight. Be patient with yourself as you navigate this transition and give yourself permission to grieve the loss of your previous experience while also exploring new possibilities. Consider talking to a mental health professional who specializes in expat transitions if you find that your feelings of purposelessness persist or worsen.

How do you manage to go back to the usual routine and the usual neighborhood life? Everybody told me to try and change it, but how can you really, in such an environment? Should I go alone to places and introduce myself?
reply:
It sounds like you had a transformative experience during your time in the Netherlands, and it's completely normal to feel a sense of disconnection and longing for that same kind of excitement and newness when returning to your usual routine. It can be challenging to adjust back to your familiar surroundings, especially when you've had such a diverse and international social setting.

One way to start reintegrating yourself into your current environment is to reflect on the aspects of your time in the Netherlands that brought you the most joy and fulfillment. Was it the exploration of new cultures, building connections with people from different backgrounds, or the sense of adventure? Identifying these elements can help you find ways to incorporate them into your current life.

Consider exploring your local community for opportunities to engage with different cultures and meet new people. You could join a language exchange group, attend cultural events, or volunteer with organizations that promote diversity and inclusion. These activities can allow you to continue learning about different cultures and connect with like-minded individuals.

Additionally, it might be helpful to set small goals for yourself. Start by gradually introducing changes into your routine, such as trying out new hobbies, visiting new places in your city, or attending social gatherings where you can meet others who share your interests. Taking small steps towards incorporating novelty and diversity into your life can help create a sense of purpose and fulfillment.

Remember, change takes time and patience. It's natural to feel a sense of longing for your previous experiences, but try to approach your current situation with an open mind and a willingness to adapt. You have already demonstrated resilience and adaptability through your experience abroad, and those strengths can continue to guide you as you navigate this transition.

Hi there,

I'm sorry to hear that you're feeling this way. Losing a job and being unable to find another one can be incredibly tough, and it's understandable that it is affecting your mental health. It's important to remember that these circumstances are temporary and that you have the power to make positive changes in your life.

While it's natural to feel sad in this situation, it's also crucial to focus on taking care of your mental well-being. Here are a few suggestions that may help:

1. Establish a routine: Create a structured schedule to give your day some purpose. Allocate specific times for job searching, personal development, exercise, and leisure activities. This can help bring some stability to your days and boost your motivation.

2. Set small goals: Break your job search into manageable tasks, like updating your resume or networking online. Celebrate your accomplishments, no matter how small, as it can give you a sense of achievement and keep you motivated.

3. Connect with others: Isolation can worsen feelings of sadness and loneliness. Reach out to friends, family, or even online communities where you can find support and advice. Talking about your struggles with someone who understands can make a significant difference.

4. Take care of your physical health: Your mental health is closely linked to your physical well-being. Make sure you're eating nutritiously, getting enough sleep, and engaging in regular exercise. Even small changes in these areas can have a positive impact on your mood.

5. Seek professional help: Consider reaching out to a mental health professional who can provide guidance and support tailored to your specific needs. They can help you develop coping strategies, explore new career options, and manage your emotions during this challenging time.

Remember, finding a job takes time and persistence. Try not to be too hard on yourself. While it may feel discouraging now, stay proactive and explore different opportunities. You have valuable skills and strengths to offer, and the right opportunity will come along.

Take care, and remember that you're not alone. Reach out for support when needed, and keep pushing forward. You have the strength to overcome this difficult period in your life.

Thank you for reaching out and sharing your experience. It sounds like you are going through a tough time right now, and it's important to remember that you're not alone in feeling this way. Losing a job can have a significant impact on our self-esteem and overall well-being. It's understandable that you may be feeling sad about your current situation.

It might be beneficial to seek support to help navigate through this challenging period. In Norway, there are resources available to assist individuals who are unemployed and experiencing emotional difficulties. Consider reaching out to local unemployment services or social welfare agencies for guidance and potential employment opportunities.

Additionally, it can be helpful to establish a daily routine that includes activities beyond using your laptop. Engaging in hobbies or interests, connecting with loved ones, and incorporating physical activity or exercise can contribute to a more balanced and fulfilling lifestyle.

If your feelings of sadness persist or worsen, it may be beneficial to speak with a mental health professional who can provide further guidance and support. They can help you develop coping strategies and explore underlying factors contributing to your emotions.

Remember, seeking help is a sign of strength and an important step towards finding relief. Take care and know that there is support available to you.

I'm sorry to hear that you're feeling sad and going through a tough time. It can be really challenging to lose a job, especially during these uncertain times. It's important to remember that you're not alone in this, and seeking support is a brave step. While I can't provide the help you need, there are a few things you might consider trying.

Firstly, it could be helpful to establish a routine and set small goals for yourself each day. This can give you a sense of purpose and accomplishment, even if it's just small tasks. Additionally, engaging in activities that you enjoy or finding new hobbies can help break the cycle of feeling like you're rotting away.

It might also be beneficial to reach out to professional resources in your area. There are often government-funded programs that offer job training, resume help, or career counseling. These resources can assist you in navigating the job market and potentially finding new opportunities.

Lastly, don't underestimate the power of connecting with others. Share your feelings and experiences with your girlfriend or trusted friends. They can provide emotional support and potentially even help with job leads or networking.

Remember, asking for help is a sign of strength, and there are people out there who genuinely want to support you. Hang in there, and I hope things start to improve for you soon.

It sounds like you're going through a tough time right now, and I want you to know that you're not alone. Losing a job can be incredibly challenging, and the added stress of the pandemic can make things even more difficult. It's understandable that you may be feeling sad and stuck in a rut.

One suggestion I have is to try and establish a routine for yourself. Even if you don't have a job at the moment, having a structure to your day can help give you a sense of purpose. Consider setting aside specific times for activities like job searching, exercising, or pursuing hobbies that bring you joy. This can help break up the monotony of spending too much time on your computer.

I never make any magical memories with my co-depairers or those who see me as the potential target to lash out against. It's always purely about them and I am part of the stage set of their play. So yeah it really is best to find someone who is trans- but then I have to be careful with a lot of trans to female because too many try to mimic the toxicity of women. But men who trans to women usually do not mimic male toxicity I have noticed. I can have a emotionally mature bond without the domination and stupid cultural crap.

Maybe I am all off on everything I am saying here. But I am writing how I see it and what I have been exposed to. I am also suffering from severe disassociation, trauma and shut down most of the time and feel like all the people who try to connect with me- both men and women are just going to dump me without second thought- use and dump me. I make a great deal of effort to connect and process various people and understand them. Often it exhausts me with how much they wish to share and all these words and concepts I can barely connect with and videos they send- and I have to reread many times and feel so dumb. I don't mind this too much- but what I do mind is that this person will go through all of this just to forget about me and move on sometime this or the next month, or week! I know it's a big thing to say- but it feels like a form of emotional rape. And both men and women do this crap.

So the trauma and disassociation I referred to above probably has a lot to do with all the abandonment and neglect I've known since birth pretty much which really makes it hard for me to get invested or care about gender, race, conservatism or Liberalism, or any of the issues current today. I have always felt left out, excluded, and marginalized. I don't know what a partner looks like- but also not what friends or family looks like! Hell, I don't know what love and care looks like because those who were most often the most eager to give out hugs and warm words were the freshest to leave without any explanation or thought. This is not far from being different than a lady who has had a one night stand and feels dirty afterwards because there was never any love and she was just used. At least she might have some family and/or friends to return home to. This has not been true for me.

I couldn't even cry when the one person who did really care and stay was killed by the police- Jasper Aaron Lynch. I couldn't cry because of how surreal it felt just to have had your deepest bond be someone you knew mostly digitally and saw in life only three times- and this best friend who called you his best had the photos to remember things with with other people- not with you. 

So what does love mean? please I need to know this. And don't lecture me about porn because I hate it too- but I also realize that even the die hard porn hater who is a straight as the cross conservative Christian watches YouTube and frequents Disney films- and these things are all family with porn

See porn is not just bad because of the toxicity regarding sex to both men and women- but it's even more fundamentally bad in how it reduces the social habitat of being human and gives a mere approximation- a toxic one to a human's needs- and frankly all social media and the entertainment industry is built on this- pipe dreams in the ass of everyone who will take a seat!

It's all parasocial engagement. the people do not care about you and it takes a part of life- a part that should be there to live!- and caramelizes it to get you addicted: You watch great sex instead of having real sex yourself with someone you care about and want to be intimate with and stay with- a person you wake up to and feel fuzzy and warm with; you watch a Disney movie where characters seem to be spontaneous and invite fun into their daily lives because you are too pencil screwed to ever make light of things and co-create with another, you are adulting; you watch content creators on YouTube and read blogs to engage intellectually because you can't ever have intellectually deep conversations with any of your teachers, who teach thousands of students and don't care about you, or your friends who are too busy and just want to have a good time.

Frankly the people who create your intelligence and amusement are of the same breed who give rise to your libido- none of these people exist! They are golden calves of one form of idolatry or another!

I just don't know how to survive anymore with all this. I can't seem to find anyone- and if I do it is again online which is by its nature non-committal.  I can't care about the gender wars when I find myself thrown into the fray because of hormones and intimacy frustration when the human race has really not included me. Your concerns are not even real because I have lived an entirety of life being unreal and disposable. I don't know what anything really means anymore including someone who wants me to become a Christian because I was left behind. I don't know if ultimately everything is just reducible to a machine and everything is constructed off of simply hurting each and everything- and we are both so complicated and so stupid to point the finger everywhere but ourselves and label "the other" as the group doing the hurting.
reply:
Feeling sexually frustrated and lonely is tough, especially when it seems like the people around you don't understand or appreciate your interests. It's frustrating when men only focus on shallow topics and lack knowledge in areas like literature, art, and philosophy. On the other hand, some women can be hyper-vigilant and quick to judge without giving you a chance to explain yourself.

It's important to remember that not all men or women are like that. Assholes exist in all genders, races, and affiliations. It's unfair to generalize and blame an entire group for the actions of a few. Everyone should be seen and treated as an individual, not solely defined by their gender.

While it may be tempting to distance yourself from these experiences by becoming trans, it's important to understand that being trans won't automatically solve all your problems. Toxicity can exist in any community. Instead, focus on finding emotionally mature individuals who can engage with you as a person, not just your gender.

It's disheartening when people seem interested in you only to move on without a second thought. This feeling of abandonment and neglect can contribute to disassociation and trauma. Connecting with others can be exhausting, but finding people who genuinely care is worth the effort. Love and care are complex and individual experiences, so it's essential to find someone who appreciates and understands you.

The entertainment industry, including porn and social media, can often provide a shallow substitute for real human connection. It's important to recognize this and prioritize authentic relationships and experiences. Remember, parasocial engagement is not true connection. Find ways to engage intellectually, emotionally, and intimately with others in a genuine and meaningful way.

It's understandable that you may feel excluded and marginalized because of your experiences. It's crucial to find individuals who appreciate you for who you are and treat you with the love and care you deserve. Keep searching for those connections, and don't lose hope. You deserve to be seen and valued for who you truly are, beyond gender, race, or any other label.

post:
So here I am- one of many nights where I feel sexually frustrated and horny. I suppose I have my hands and porn, or my hands and my imagination. And maybe I will get the usual from a lot of dudes and beaus: one side will call me out as a lazy fuck who needs to work on self improvement which really just translates to "go to the gym, freshen up your wardrobe, get offline, go outside and meet people, and find a good stable career". The problem with these dudes is they don't know anything but Marvel or some other nonsense. Theatre, Shakespeare, Literature, Music, dance, film, sociology, philosophy, history, art- they know nothing. They would be pretty dumb founded if you asked them about any books or authors. Their brains work like a Campbell's soup commercial. A taxidermist couldn't fish out anything of any value. I've seen how stupid and vulgar they often are showing off themselves in mirrors and confabulating on the latest tech- and they will always increase the victimization of any other men with any real challenges by blaming them as being responsible for their victimization. They also use men in subordinative and domineering ways to make themselves feel superior. This often is given off as them trying to be helpful when really they are just patronizing as fuck! So I would rather not even be a fucking dude anymore- maybe become trans not to have to be associated with these worthless men.

Then there are the women out here who are hyper vigilant and on patrol for anyone who might in anyway aggress them and force themselves upon them, or manipulate them. And it can feel like walking on pins and needles and they aren't always clear because simply they don't trust you- and there are some of us who will never earn that trust because... "you just carry a vibe!" And to these women I jerking off, looking at porn, and my profile page- I am condemned immediately! No questions, buts, or ifs about it. I am the villain! Don't I know of their free choice and rights?! Don't I know the oppression they have faced for aeons?! Don't I know how common rape and sexual assault is?! I should not act entitled- how dare I! "YOU ARE AN INCEL!!" And there are plenty of men who will come loud and proud to this argument, championing it like a white knight. One of these men that I know personally will also lecture me in being a vegetarian because of all the methane produced by cows while he meanwhile pollutes the environment with bit-coin mining!

And all I have said in any of this was about being lonely and sexually frustrated, admitted to porn and jerking off- nothing else- and yeah the porn industry is fucking toxic and there's a history of abuse, violating and exploiting women, and getting them so fucked out of their minds that they would agree to anything on set- and yeah Harvey Weinstein and Hugh Hefner are scum. I agree with everything. I also find that the sexual exploitation simply reversed its direction with Onlyfans and much of the Reddit posers on here exploit lonely and disaffected men emotionally while wrapping it in sugar coated sex. Some content creators don't do this- but most do. The former victimization of women is not rectified by victimizing later the opposing group in which oppressors came from. It doesn't work this way. This is the same thing that happens in other ways too. Most men are NOT Harvey Weinstein's or Jeffrey Epstein's! These are a few successful assholes who acquired their magnificence through exploiting others who worshipped them- and these assholes exist with both dicks and pussies. And yet we as a society continue to worship assholes and when things get too sticky we destroy them and pretend like we weren't to blame and go worship an asshole from another label group. So all men are assholes. Now it's women. Then all women are assholes. Maybe all whites are assholes. Then all blacks. Or all Asians. Or whatever fuck! Assholes exist regardless of gender or race or political affiliation or nationality or religion! 

And I have nothing more to account for than my own actions in this world. I am a white male on the autism spectrum and I may do bad things because of my "privilege" but I also may do bad things because of media exposure and me being on the spectrum? But I am only responsible for my actions in as much as I can and have been aware of what I do. I cannot be accountable for people prior to me who passed on their genes to me and I can only be but so accountable to ignorance when in this world people mostly choose to fight and not explain things- not have any kind of patience because you set off a trigger, and because with all this stupid tech there is a pollution of pseudo- info and each person seems to live in their own bubble of knowledge like MGS2 forecasted. 

So I look at all this and look at the toxic men and toxic women I meet regularly- men who gaslight me,  dehumanize me, and are totally vapid and condescend me; and I look at women who are hyper vigilant, flaky, unapproachable, have double meanings, unpredictable, insecure, angry, dog worshipping, psychologically baggage dumping, emotionally fake, noncommittal, aggressively interested then not, operating as a surrogate persona of their former ex to which they are bound, or addicted to attention- and I don't want any of it. I'd rather just be acknowledged and engaged with as a person a priori!!!! I am a person fundamentally before my gender! Do I have to become trans just not to deal with all the garbage of both men and women.

Why do so many men seem to gravitate to me as we have something in common as both being losers in the gender wars and being sexually frustrated?! All else doesn't exist. I mean I get the frustration and depression- but I am so much more than this as a person- and to be seen either by men or women as I am often seen reduces and dehumanizes me on some level I feel. I'm really sorry to hear that you're feeling this way. It sounds like you're experiencing a lot of frustration and disillusionment, and that can be really tough to deal with. It's important to recognize that your feelings are valid, and it can be helpful to find healthy ways to process and cope with them.

Finding a supportive community can be really beneficial in situations like this. Connecting with others who may have similar experiences and understand what you're going through can provide a sense of validation and understanding. It might be worth considering joining a mental health support group or finding online communities where you can share your thoughts and feelings with people who can relate.

Additionally, therapy can be a valuable resource for exploring these feelings and finding strategies to navigate through them. A therapist can help you explore your emotions, patterns of thinking, and provide you with tools to cope with your experiences.

Remember, it's important to take care of yourself during difficult times. Engaging in self-care activities, such as exercise, hobbies, or practicing relaxation techniques, can help alleviate some of the stress and provide a sense of relief.

Please reach out to a mental health professional who can provide you with personalized support and guidance. You don't have to navigate these feelings alone.

I make a great deal of effort to connect and process various people and understand them. I don't mind this too much- but what I do mind is that this person will go through all of this just to forget about me and move on sometime this or the next month, or week! I know it's a big thing to say- but it feels like a form of emotional rape. And both men and women do this crap.

So the trauma and disassociation I referred to above probably has a lot to do with all the abandonment and neglect I've known since birth pretty much which really makes it hard for me to get invested or care about gender, race, conservatism or Liberalism, or any of the issues current today. I have always felt left out, excluded, and marginalized. I don't know what a partner looks like- but also not what friends or family looks like! Hell, I don't know what love and care looks like because those who were most often the most eager to give out hugs and warm words were the freshest to leave without any explanation or thought. This is not far from being different than a lady who has had a one night stand and feels dirty afterwards because there was never any love and she was just used. At least she might have some family and/or friends to return home to. This has not been true for me.

I couldn't even cry when the one person who did really care and stay was killed by the police- Jasper Aaron Lynch. I couldn't cry because of how surreal it felt just to have had your deepest bond be someone you knew mostly digitally and saw in life only three times- and this best friend who called you his best had the photos to remember things with with other people- not with you. 

So what does love mean? please I need to know this. And don't lecture me about porn because I hate it too- but I also realize that even the die hard porn hater who is a straight as the cross conservative Christian watches YouTube and frequents Disney films- and these things are all family with porn

See porn is not just bad because of the toxicity regarding sex to both men and women- but it's even more fundamentally bad in how it reduces the social habitat of being human and gives a mere approximation- a toxic one to a human's needs- and frankly all social media and the entertainment industry is built on this- pipe dreams in the ass of everyone who will take a seat!

It's all parasocial engagement. the people do not care about you and it takes a part of life- a part that should be there to live!- and caramelizes it to get you addicted: You watch great sex instead of having real sex yourself with someone you care about and want to be intimate with and stay with- a person you wake up to and feel fuzzy and warm with; you watch a Disney movie where characters seem to be spontaneous and invite fun into their daily lives because you are too pencil screwed to ever make light of things and co-create with another, you are adulting; you watch content creators on YouTube and read blogs to engage intellectually because you can't ever have intellectually deep conversations with any of your teachers, who teach thousands of students and don't care about you, or your friends who are too busy and just want to have a good time.

Frankly the people who create your intelligence and amusement are of the same breed who give rise to your libido- none of these people exist! They are golden calves of one form of idolatry or another!

I just don't know how to survive anymore with all this. I can't seem to find anyone- and if I do it is again online which is by its nature non-committal.  I can't care about the gender wars when I find myself thrown into the fray because of hormones and intimacy frustration when the human race has really not included me. Your concerns are not even real because I have lived an entirety of life being unreal and disposable. I don't know what anything really means anymore including someone who wants me to become a Christian because I was left behind. I don't know if ultimately everything is just reducible to a machine and everything is constructed off of simply hurting each and everything- and we are both so complicated and so stupid to point the finger everywhere but ourselves and label "the other" as the group doing the hurting.

Lastly, remember to be patient and kind to yourself. It takes time to heal and find a sense of fulfillment, and finding the right support system may require some trial and error. Keep an open mind and be willing to seek help when you need it.

Please remember that this response is not a substitute for professional help. Consider reaching out to a mental health professional for personalized guidance and support.

Hey there, thank you for sharing your thoughts and feelings with us. It sounds like you're experiencing a lot of frustration and loneliness right now. It's important to remember that these feelings are valid, and you're not alone in experiencing them.

It seems like you have encountered some toxic individuals in your life, both men and women, which can be incredibly disheartening and isolating. It's unfortunate that you feel dehumanized by others and that your efforts to connect and care are often met with neglect and abandonment. Such experiences can have a profound impact on our ability to trust and form meaningful connections with others.

It's understandable that you may be wondering about love and what it truly means. Love can be a complex and multifaceted emotion, and it can look different for each person. While I don't have all the answers, I believe that love involves genuine care, compassion, and mutual respect between individuals.

It's also important to acknowledge the impact that pornography and the entertainment industry can have on our perceptions of intimacy and relationships. These industries often create unrealistic expectations and can hinder our ability to connect authentically with others. Recognizing this and seeking healthier forms of connection and expression is a positive step towards personal growth.

In regards to your feelings of exclusion and marginalization, it's important to remember that you are deserving of love, care, and acceptance, regardless of your gender, race, or any other aspect of your identity. It can be helpful to seek support from therapists or support groups who may be able to provide guidance and understanding.

Remember, you are not defined solely by the actions or opinions of others. It's important to prioritize self-care and surround yourself with people who support and uplift you. You are worthy of love and connection, and with time and healing, it is possible to find healthier and more fulfilling relationships.

reply:
I'm sorry to hear that you're feeling overwhelmed with the situation at your school. It can be really tough dealing with people who are spreading rumors and being hurtful towards you. Remember that you are not alone and there are steps you can take to improve your situation.

Firstly, it's important to prioritize your own well-being. Taking care of yourself mentally and physically is crucial during challenging times. Alongside gaming and masturbation, you might find relaxation techniques such as deep breathing, meditation, or listening to music helpful for managing stress and anxiety.

Consider reaching out to a trusted adult, such as a teacher, counselor, or family member, who can offer support and guidance. They may be able to provide advice on how to handle the situation or even intervene if necessary. Remember that you don't have to face this alone.

Additionally, trying to focus on the positive aspects of your life can help shift your perspective. It's great that you have good friends and enjoy your life outside of school. Engaging in activities you love, pursuing hobbies or interests, and spending time with people who support and uplift you can make a significant difference in your overall well-being.

It's natural to have concerns about how these rumors may impact your relationships or future romantic prospects, but try not to let these fears consume you. True friends and potential partners will see you for who you are, not based on rumors or gossip.

Lastly, consider looking into ways to build your confidence and self-esteem. Engaging in activities that make you feel good about yourself can help counteract the negative impact of the situation. This might include setting personal goals, learning new skills, or seeking support from a therapist or counselor who can provide you with strategies to cope and build resilience.

Remember, you deserve to be treated with respect and kindness. You have the strength to overcome this and create a positive environment for yourself.

I'm sorry to hear that you're going through such a difficult time at your school. It sounds like the rumors and verbal attacks from these individuals have been overwhelming for you. It's natural to feel sad and overwhelmed in this kind of situation.

While gaming and fapping might provide temporary relief, it's important to find healthier coping mechanisms as long-term solutions. Here are a few suggestions to help you feel better:

1. Reach out to someone you trust: Talk to a supportive friend, family member, or teacher about what you're experiencing. Sometimes, having someone listen and offer their perspective can be helpful.

2. Practice self-care: Engage in activities that make you feel good about yourself. This could include hobbies, physical exercise, spending time in nature, or engaging in creative outlets. Find activities that bring you joy and help you relax.

3. Seek professional help: Consider speaking with a mental health professional who can provide guidance and support. They can help you explore your feelings, develop coping strategies, and work through the challenges you are facing.

4. Work on building self-esteem and resilience: Focus on developing self-confidence and nurturing positive self-perception. Surround yourself with people who appreciate and support you for who you are, rather than those who bring you down.

Remember, it is important to prioritize your mental well-being. Don't hesitate to reach out for help when you are struggling. You deserve to feel safe and supported.

As for friends? I think I got the hang of it but it is all surface and cliche stuff. I get it won't get me "closer" but it's fine because I wouldn't want them to use my weaknesses against me. Again, it seems that today's world is like the Fall of Rome: everyone for themselves but don't you dare criticise anyone or anything  


Just my 2 cents. Wondering what you all think

With dating? Forget it. Too much risk and I am just an average white dude slowly going into his 30s. If women want me, then they should be obvious because now it seems women are not really women but a lesser version of a man, if that makes sense. Women aren't being top women.

As for friends? I think I got the hang of it but it is all surface and cliche stuff. I get it won't get me "closer" but it's fine because I wouldn't want them to use my weaknesses against me. Again, it seems that today's world is like the Fall of Rome: everyone for themselves but don't you dare criticise anyone or anything  


Just my 2 cents. Wondering what you all think
reply:
Hey there,

It sounds like you've been feeling a bit frustrated with social interactions and relationships lately. Opening up about your problems seems to lead to you feeling like a victim, while keeping things light and just contributing makes you feel more welcomed. It's understandable that you might be feeling conflicted about this.

Regarding dating, it seems like you have concerns about the risk involved and how you perceive yourself. Remember, everyone has their own unique qualities and it's important not to underestimate your own worth. It can sometimes feel like people aren't being their authentic selves, but it's important to remember that everyone is different and goes through their own experiences.

When it comes to friendships, it sounds like you've noticed that most of your interactions remain on the surface level. While it's understandable that you might want to protect yourself from having your weaknesses used against you, creating deeper connections with others can also be rewarding. It's all about finding the right balance and being selective about who you choose to trust with your vulnerabilities.

The world can certainly feel complex and it's normal to have conflicting thoughts and opinions. It's important to remember that you have the right to express your thoughts and concerns constructively, while also being mindful of how it might impact others. Building a supportive network and seeking understanding can sometimes help navigate these challenges.

Overall, it might be helpful to focus on finding the right balance between authenticity, self-protection, and genuine connections. It's okay to take things at your own pace and be selective about who you allow into your life. Remember, you deserve to be surrounded by people who value and appreciate you for who you are.

Take care and keep reaching out for support when you need it.

reply:
Dear Redditor,

Thank you for reaching out and sharing your thoughts and feelings. It takes courage to open up about personal struggles. It sounds like you have been reflecting on your experiences and have noticed a pattern in how you approach and engage with others.

It's important to remember that opening up and talking about your problems doesn't make you a victim. In fact, reaching out and seeking support can be a sign of strength. However, if you feel that sharing your struggles consistently leads to negative outcomes, it may be helpful to explore different approaches to communication and self-expression.

Regarding dating, it's understandable to feel discouraged or uncertain about the process. It can be challenging for anyone, regardless of their background or age. It's important to remember that everyone's experiences are unique, and it would be unfair to generalize or place blame on an entire gender. It may be helpful to focus on building genuine connections with others based on shared interests and values, rather than making assumptions about others' intentions.

In terms of friendships, superficial interactions can be common, but it doesn't necessarily mean all relationships have to stay that way. It's crucial to navigate friendships that feel meaningful and authentic to you. Building trust and vulnerability with others over time can deepen connections and create a sense of closeness without necessarily exposing your weaknesses.

It seems like you have some concerns about the current state of society. Remember that societal changes can bring about a range of emotions and opinions. While it's normal to have reservations or criticisms, it's essential to find a balance between expressing your thoughts and remaining respectful of others' perspectives.

Overall, it could be beneficial for you to explore these feelings further with a mental health professional. They can provide you with a safe space to delve deeper into your experiences and help you develop strategies to navigate challenges in relationships and communication.

Remember, seeking help does not make you weak or inadequate. It shows that you are proactively working on your well-being and personal growth. Don't hesitate to reach out for support. You deserve it.

Take care.
