post:
Well, here I am.

I've been bouting with anxiety and depression for a long time, but there is something I never really talked about to anyone. It's about my size. I know that according to stats it should be in perfect average (17 cm), but many of the women I've slept with off handedly remarked that that was no way the real average because they usually date larger man. Infact, turned out that the Italian average is quite a bit higher.

[https://oltreuomo.com/lunghezza-media-del-pene-italia-per-regione/](https://oltreuomo.com/lunghezza-media-del-pene-italia-per-regione/)

​

https://preview.redd.it/tr1i928ltama1.png?width=600&format=png&auto=webp&v=enabled&s=28894c3ce514b3e4418e619203211ec0ad614423

Anyway, since those instances I've started developing an intense anxiety about sex, something I already lived badly because of performance anxiety etc. In time I stopped dating altogether, I even stopped masturbating and finding other human beings attractive.For a short period I had this weird online thing with a girl from abroad, who probably had very similar insecurities as me. She never showed me her face and was extremely private about her appearance BUT she we were into one another she insisted at least sexting and sharing nudes with me.I tried to take pictures of myself but as I did I felt so ashamed because it looked so tiny that I stopped right there and quitted that relationship too. This is just to show you how deep you can fall if you don't take your mental health seriously. Talk to somebody, act on your issues, take medications if necessary, or you will end up old, alone and slave of twothousand fears, like me.
reply: Hey there, I can understand how tough it can be when dealing with anxiety and depression. Just remember, you are not alone in this. It's important to prioritize your mental health and seek support when needed. There are professionals who specialize in these areas and can help guide you through your journey. Taking care of yourself is the first step towards feeling better. Remember, you deserve happiness and fulfillment. Stay strong! üí™

post:
Hi. I am 21 and I have huge mental health problems that I can solve only by getting a job. I have a terrible relationship with my parents.
 
My mother tries to be a good mother, but she is a Soviet dummy from what was once a person. A lot of things hurt me, a lot of things that she personally did hurt me, but in conversation she will never admit it and will deny everything, if she does not start accusing me in the spirit of "how could I do otherwise? you didn't obey me?".

 My father showed practically no involvement in my upbringing. He was always there, but I don't feel warm looking at him, I don't have warm memories. He's a good man, you don't understand, just broken, broken by the Afghan war.He just don't know how to love, and too afraid to try. 

 My sister with two children and her husband is now in Russia, and my best friend is in Ukraine (he is safe in Ternopil. Air defense works well).
I want to go there, help people,volunteer , do something in life at least once at the call of my own heart, and not under the strict control of my mother to meet public expectations. 

All I have to do is study.  Studying by myself ,long and hard, but for half a year, by the end of the summer, I just have to get a job and leave. I understand that no one from the family will understand my action, they never idid. I tried to explain to them that what is happening is a horror. Sometimes they even agreed with me. But they are so hooked on the propaganda needle that every conversation starts from the same place every day. 
I live in constant stress and fear, very often I think about the moment of my death and how short life it's all so intense it's immobilizing. Sedatives don't help much. I just need something to help reduce stress, relax a little, and do what I have to. If you know any techniques or practices, please share!
reply: Hey there, sorry to hear you're going through a tough time. It can be really challenging when there are misunderstandings within the family. Remember, you're not alone in this. Have you tried exploring relaxation techniques such as deep breathing exercises or meditation? They can help reduce stress levels and bring a sense of calm. Additionally, reaching out to a therapist or counselor might be beneficial in finding coping strategies for your mental health. Hang in there, things can get better. Take care of yourself!

reply:
Hi there, sorry to hear that you're going through a difficult time right now. It sounds like you're dealing with a lot of emotional pain and stress, and your relationship with your parents is adding to the burden. It can be incredibly tough when the people we love and depend on don't understand or support our choices.

It's admirable that you want to go and help others, volunteer, and follow your heart's calling. Sometimes finding fulfillment in our own passions and interests can greatly contribute to our overall well-being. However, it's important to make sure that you're taking care of your mental health along the way.

In terms of reducing stress and finding relaxation techniques, different strategies work for different people. Here are a few ideas you could try:

1. Deep breathing exercises: Taking slow, deep breaths can help activate your body's relaxation response. Try inhaling deeply through your nose, counting to four, and then exhaling slowly through your mouth. Repeat this a few times, focusing on the sensation of your breath entering and leaving your body.

2. Mindfulness and meditation: Practices like mindfulness and meditation can help to bring a sense of calm and focus to your mind. You can start by setting aside a few minutes each day to sit quietly, focusing on your breath or using a guided meditation app.

3. Engaging in hobbies or activities you enjoy: Finding activities that bring you joy and help you relax can be incredibly beneficial. Whether it's reading, painting, exercising, or spending time in nature, make sure to carve out time each day to do something that brings you happiness.

4. Seeking support: Consider reaching out to a mental health professional, such as a therapist or counselor, who can provide a safe space for you to explore your emotions, cope with stress, and work through any unresolved issues from your past.

Remember, it's important to prioritize your mental health and well-being. Taking small steps towards self-care and finding healthy coping mechanisms can slowly make a positive impact on your overall outlook and ability to handle stress. Keep reaching out for support, and don't hesitate to ask for help when you need it. You're not alone, and there are people out there who can offer the assistance you need.

Hi there,

I want to acknowledge your bravery in reaching out and sharing your struggles. It sounds like you're carrying a heavy emotional burden, and I can hear that you're seeking ways to cope with your stress and find some relief.

First and foremost, it's important to recognize that seeking professional help can be beneficial. A mental health clinician can support you in addressing your mental health concerns and provide you with tools to manage stress and anxiety. I encourage you to consider reaching out to a professional who can offer guidance specific to your situation.

In the meantime, there are a few techniques and practices that you may find helpful in reducing stress. Deep breathing exercises, such as diaphragmatic breathing, can help calm the body and mind. Engaging in regular physical activity and finding time for relaxation practices, such as meditation or mindfulness, can also contribute to stress reduction and emotional well-being.

Creating a support network of friends or individuals who understand your experiences can provide a sense of community and validation. Consider seeking out local or online support groups where you can connect with others who may be going through similar challenges.

Remember, self-care is crucial. Engage in activities that bring you joy and provide a sense of fulfillment. Prioritize setting achievable goals that align with your personal values and aspirations. Additionally, finding healthy ways to express your feelings, such as through writing, art, or music, can be therapeutic.

Lastly, please remember that there is hope, and you do not have to face these difficulties alone. Reaching out for professional help and utilizing available resources can be important steps toward a healthier and more fulfilling life.

Take care, and please don't hesitate to reach out for support when you need it.

Hi there, I'm sorry to hear that you're going through such a challenging time. It sounds like you're dealing with a lot of emotional pain caused by your family dynamic, and I can understand how stressful and overwhelming that can be. It's great that you have a goal in mind - wanting to find a job and pursue your own path outside of your mother's control is a significant step towards your independence and personal growth.

As for techniques to reduce stress and relax, there are various practices that you can try. One approach that many people find helpful is mindfulness or meditation. It involves focusing your attention on the present moment and becoming aware of your thoughts and feelings without judgment. This practice can help you gain clarity, reduce anxiety, and manage stress. There are numerous guided meditation apps and videos available online that you might find beneficial.

In addition, engaging in physical activity can be another effective way to relieve stress. Exercise releases endorphins, which are natural mood boosters. You could try finding a physical activity that you enjoy, such as yoga, running, or dancing. Incorporating exercise into your routine can help you feel more relaxed and improve your overall well-being.

It's also important to connect with supportive individuals who can understand and empathize with what you're going through. Consider reaching out to local support groups or online communities focused on mental health and personal growth. Sharing your experiences with people who have gone through similar situations can provide a sense of validation and support.

Remember, seeking professional help from a therapist or counselor can also be incredibly valuable. They can provide you with guidance, coping strategies, and a safe space to process your emotions. If accessing therapy is difficult, there are online counseling platforms and helplines available that might be able to offer support.

Please take care of yourself and remember that you deserve to live a happy and fulfilling life. Keep working towards your goals, prioritize self-care, and don't hesitate to ask for help when you need it. You're not alone on this journey, and there are people who understand and want to support you every step of the way.

Hi there,

I'm really sorry to hear that you're going through such a difficult time. It's understandable that your relationship with your parents is causing you a lot of pain and stress. It's great that you have a desire to help others and pursue something meaningful in your life. 

Given the circumstances, it's important to prioritize your mental health and find coping mechanisms to reduce stress. I'm not a professional, but here are a few techniques that some people find helpful in managing stress and promoting relaxation:

1. Deep breathing exercises: Taking slow, deep breaths can help activate your body's relaxation response. Inhale deeply through your nose, hold for a few seconds, and exhale slowly through your mouth. Repeat this several times.

2. Mindfulness meditation: This technique involves focusing your attention on the present moment. You can find guided meditation videos or apps that can help you get started.

3. Physical activity: Engaging in regular exercise or any physical activity that you enjoy can be an effective way to relieve stress. It releases endorphins, which are natural mood-boosters.

4. Journaling: Writing down your thoughts and feelings can provide a sense of relief and help you gain clarity. You can try journaling as a way to express yourself and process your emotions.

Remember, these techniques might not completely solve your problems, but they might help you in managing stress and finding moments of relaxation. It can be beneficial to reach out to a mental health professional who can provide you with personalized support and guidance.

Take care of yourself, and I wish you all the best on your journey towards finding stability and happiness.

I‚Äôm so sick of going online every day and seeing all men get lumped together in derogatory statements. I have horrendous self esteem and self worth issues, and have all of my life. So every time I see one of these comments or memes about how men are useless, how we‚Äôre scum, how we mistreat women, etc., it kicks me down even further. It makes me feel like if there are so many people who would hate on me just for my sex/gender then what‚Äôs the point of living? So I can have my already low self worth smashed even flatter? And I can‚Äôt even speak up about stuff like this outside of places like this subreddit. The moment i do I‚Äôm met with ‚Äúthere is no misandry‚Äù and accusations of being an incel, as though voicing concern at having my psyche whipped everyday could somehow make me think women owe me sex or mistreat them. No. I just makes me think a lot of people out there hates me until they get to know me. It‚Äôs shit like this that makes me immense grateful (not proud) that I‚Äôm a straight, white, cismale, because I‚Äôd have offed myself a long time ago from the increased hate from others for being anything else.

Edit: It seems I need to clarify some stuff. I understand why people say these things. My ex wife was assaulted once as a child, my mother was multiple times, and so were my cousins. I understand some people‚Äôs reasoning behind distrust of men in general. I also don‚Äôt feel like they are addressing me personally when people say these things. My issue is that it makes me feel subhuman that it is socially acceptable to make derogatory blanket statements about men or to attack men when they express how such statements make them feel. And don‚Äôt even get me started on how much it hurts that there are people that would try to get others to fear me by default simple because of what‚Äôs between my legs. Just because I can understand it doesn‚Äôt mean it doesn‚Äôt hurt still.
reply: Hey there, just wanted to say that I hear you and I understand how hurtful it can be to see derogatory statements about men. It's tough when it feels like your self-esteem is being constantly knocked down. Remember that you are not alone in feeling this way and it's important to acknowledge and validate your own emotions. It's unfortunate that sometimes speaking up about these issues can be met with negativity, but know that seeking support in places like this subreddit is a step in the right direction. Hang in there, and remember that your worth is not determined by the opinions of others. Keep being you and surround yourself with positivity. Sending virtual support your way! üåü

I'm really sorry to hear that you're feeling this way. It must be incredibly difficult to constantly see derogatory comments and memes targeting men, especially when it reinforces your own self-esteem and self-worth issues. It's understandable that this constant negativity would make you question the value of your own existence.

It can be really challenging to navigate conversations about these types of issues, especially when your concerns are dismissed or misunderstood. It's important to remember that your feelings and experiences are valid, regardless of how others might respond. It's unfortunate that some people automatically associate voicing your concerns with being an incel or expecting women to owe you something. It's really tough to feel like there are so many people out there who would hate you simply because of your gender. These feelings of being disliked until people get to know you can be incredibly damaging to your sense of self-worth and overall well-being. It's understandable that you would feel immense frustration and sadness about it.

It's positive that you have this subreddit as a safe space to share your thoughts and experiences. Finding communities where you can express yourself and receive support is crucial. It's also important to consider seeking professional help if you haven't already. A mental health professional can provide you with guidance and strategies for coping with these negative emotions and developing a healthier self-image.

Remember, you are not alone in this struggle. It's unfortunate that gender-based derogatory statements are sometimes seen as socially acceptable, but it doesn't mean everyone feels that way. There are people out there who will listen, understand, and support you. Don't hesitate to reach out to them, whether it's through online communities or by seeking help from mental health professionals. Hang in there, and please take care of yourself.

While it's important to acknowledge the reasons behind some people's distrust of men due to personal experiences, it's also crucial to address these issues in a way that doesn't generalize or stereotype an entire gender. It's unfortunate that derogatory blanket statements are socially acceptable, and it's understandable that this can make you feel subhuman.

Remember that you are not defined by the negative perceptions of others. Focus on building your self-worth and finding strength within yourself. Seeking therapy or counseling with a mental health professional might also provide you with valuable tools and support to navigate these emotions. Surrounding yourself with positive influences and engaging in self-care activities that bring you joy and fulfillment can also help boost your self-esteem.

You matter, and your feelings are important. Keep reaching out for support, both online and in your personal life, and remember that there are people who care and want to help.

post:
I‚Äôm so sick of going online every day and seeing all men get lumped together in derogatory statements. I have horrendous self esteem and self worth issues, and have all of my life. So every time I see one of these comments or memes about how men are useless, how we‚Äôre scum, how we mistreat women, etc., it kicks me down even further. It makes me feel like if there are so many people who would hate on me just for my sex/gender then what‚Äôs the point of living? So I can have my already low self worth smashed even flatter? And I can‚Äôt even speak up about stuff like this outside of places like this subreddit. The moment i do I‚Äôm met with ‚Äúthere is no misandry‚Äù and accusations of being an incel, as though voicing concern at having my psyche whipped everyday could somehow make me think women owe me sex or mistreat them. No. I just makes me think a lot of people out there hates me until they get to know me. It‚Äôs shit like this that makes me immense grateful (not proud) that I‚Äôm a straight, white, cismale, because I‚Äôd have offed myself a long time ago from the increased hate from others for being anything else.

Edit: It seems I need to clarify some stuff. I understand why people say these things. My ex wife was assaulted once as a child, my mother was multiple times, and so were my cousins. I understand some people‚Äôs reasoning behind distrust of men in general. I also don‚Äôt feel like they are addressing me personally when people say these things. My issue is that it makes me feel subhuman that it is socially acceptable to make derogatory blanket statements about men or to attack men when they express how such statements make them feel. And don‚Äôt even get me started on how much it hurts that there are people that would try to get others to fear me by default simple because of what‚Äôs between my legs. Just because I can understand it doesn‚Äôt mean it doesn‚Äôt hurt still.
reply:
Hey there, it sounds like you're really struggling with the negativity and derogatory comments you see directed towards men online. It's understandable that these comments can have a significant impact on your self-esteem and self-worth, especially if you've been carrying these issues throughout your life.

Feeling like you're constantly being attacked or hated on solely based on your gender can be incredibly overwhelming and emotionally draining. It's unfortunate that expressing how these comments affect you can lead to dismissive responses or accusations of being an incel. Seeking support and understanding should never be interpreted as wanting to mistreat women or feeling entitled to anything.

It's important to remember that while negative comments and stereotypes exist, they don't define who you are as an individual. Your worth should never be determined by the opinions of others. It's completely valid to feel hurt and invalidated by these blanket statements. It's essential to find spaces, like this subreddit, where you can openly discuss your feelings without the fear of judgment or invalidation.

Also, acknowledging and understanding the experiences and struggles of others, such as survivors of assault, is commendable. Empathy doesn't negate the impact that derogatory statements can have on you as an individual. It's crucial to prioritize your own mental health and find coping mechanisms that work for you.

Remember, you're not alone in these feelings, and seeking support is a positive step towards healing and understanding. Consider connecting with a mental health professional who can provide guidance and strategies for managing these emotions. Take care of yourself and remember that your worth is not determined by others' opinions.

post:
I know it might sound bad, but when I was 20 I experienced a psychosis.  Over the course of fifteen years we finally got me stable on medicine and disability income, help from parents, and part time kitchen work.

If anyone has questions for me to clarify please ask.

I wanted to go to gradschool to study afro Caribbean music and religion.  I've been slowly learning those music's on the congas since I was 24.  As I was white, and crazy, so to speak, I burned many bridges with local musicians, who were black.

Anyway I like to continue drumming and continue learning Kung Fu while working for USPS, and I want to read the books in my area of interest.

Is this possible for my future?

I'm interested in Carl Jung and psychoanalysis, Karl Marx, comparative religion myth and folklore,  anthropology, African and Caribbean studies and literature.




I feel really really fucking bad that I can't do whatever the fuck I'd be able to do with a religion or folklore or ethnomusicology PhD.

I haven't had sex in fifteen years.

Things have been getting dark for me.

Ive been holding out for gradschool so I can move to Caribbean or something and learn the drums better.

It looks like that will probably never happen

But maybe getting stable with a USPS job is a good move
reply:
Hey there! It's amazing that you have taken the time to pursue your passion for Afro Caribbean music and religion. It's never too late to continue drumming and learning Kung Fu while working for USPS. Reading books on your areas of interest like Carl Jung, Karl Marx, comparative religion, myth and folklore, anthropology, African and Caribbean studies, and literature will surely enhance your knowledge.

Remember, your future is full of possibilities! While a PhD may not be feasible at the moment, focusing on getting stable with your USPS job is definitely a good move. Keep working towards your goals, and who knows, you might still find opportunities to explore your interests and live in the Caribbean. Stay positive and keep pushing forward! You got this.

reply:
Title: Seeking Advice for Rebuilding My Life and Pursuing Interests

Hey everyone,

I hope you're all doing well. I wanted to open up and seek some guidance from this supportive community. Over the past fifteen years, I have been managing a psychosis that started when I was 20. Thanks to medication, disability income, support from my parents, and part-time kitchen work, I have finally achieved some stability.

The reason I'm reaching out today is because I have a strong desire to pursue my passion for Afro Caribbean music and religion in grad school. Since I was 24, I have been slowly learning different musical techniques on the congas. However, due to my past struggles and misunderstandings, I ended up burning bridges with local musicians, many of whom are black. I deeply regret my actions and want to move forward positively.

Apart from music, I also wish to continue my journey in practicing Kung Fu while working for USPS. Additionally, I am eager to immerse myself in the literature related to Carl Jung and psychoanalysis, Karl Marx, comparative religion myth and folklore, anthropology, African and Caribbean studies, and literature.

However, I must admit that lately, I have been feeling extremely low. I have not been in a romantic relationship for fifteen years, and it has taken a toll on my mental health. The lack of progress in pursuing my dreams has also been weighing on me, and I fear that I may never be able to achieve them.

Nonetheless, I have considered the possibility of finding stability and satisfaction through a job at USPS. It could provide a sense of stability and financial security while allowing me to pursue my interests in my spare time. But at the same time, I can't shake off the longing to explore Caribbean cultures and develop my drumming skills further.

I apologize if my post seems scattered or filled with frustration. It's just that I have been feeling quite overwhelmed lately. I would be grateful if anyone could offer some guidance on how I can rebuild my life while still nourishing my passions. Perhaps some of you have been through similar struggles and have found ways to overcome them.

Thank you all for taking the time to read and understand my situation. I appreciate any advice or support you can provide.

post:
Hello Friends, let me tell you about a self-help technique called journaling. Journaling is the practice of writing every single day. You can practically write about anything you want. You can write about your emotions, you can plan out your day, you can philosophize about life. Journaling is an ancient technique, a perfect example of this is Marcus Aurelius's journal, his Meditations. The stoics used to have different practices and methods to make the most out of their journaling sessions, and they included different excersizes like writng about the finitude of life, writing about their values, and reflecting on their days and what they can do to be better the next day.

I have been experimenting with journaling for years and I wanted to share with you the outline I use to start and end my days and my weeks which keeps me sane, organized, focused, confident, and in harmony with my goals and motivations. Here it is:

\- Start by mentioning 5 things I like, appreciate, love, and admire about myself.

\- Then appreciate 3 things I am thankful for.

\- Write down my short term goals (1 month to 6 months).

\- Write down my medium term goals (6 months to 5 years).

\- Write down my long term goals (5years forward). The idea is that my there should be little fluctuation specially in my medium and long term goals.

\- Plan out my day in google calendar.

\- Space to write about personal things troubling me.

\- If Monday, plan my workload for the week. Once I make a plan, I cannot change it for the week.

\- If Sunday, analyze this weeks workload and think about changes and improvements for the following week.

\- Night

\- Write down 3 things I did right today.

\- Write down 3 things I could do better.

\- Write down 3 things I am thankful for.

\- Thank God.

I recommend you try my outline for a week or two and then tell me what you think about it! I would love to hear your experiences.

Good luck to you all,

Ivan Berezin

reply:
Hello Ivan Berezin,

Thank you for sharing your experience with journaling and providing an outline that has helped you stay organized and focused. Journaling can indeed be a helpful self-help technique for many people.

Incorporating a practice of self-appreciation and gratitude, as you've mentioned, can be powerful for boosting self-esteem and cultivating a positive mindset. It's great that you start your day by acknowledging five things you appreciate about yourself and three things you are thankful for. This sets a positive tone for the rest of the day.

Setting short-term, medium-term, and long-term goals is an excellent way to create clarity and direction in life. By having a clear vision of where you want to be in different timeframes, you can make focused decisions and take steps towards those goals.

Planning your day in advance using a tool like Google Calendar is a practical approach to staying organized and ensuring you have a clear schedule. Being able to track personal tasks and appointments alongside work obligations can improve overall productivity and reduce stress.

It's also a wise idea to create space in your journal to address any personal issues that might be troubling you. Writing about your thoughts and emotions can provide a release and clarity, enabling you to better understand yourself and work through challenges.

Reviewing your week's workload on Sundays and making changes for the upcoming week is a good practice to ensure continuous improvement and growth. By assessing what went well and what could be improved, you can make adjustments to enhance your productivity and overall well-being.

Ending the day with reflection is another valuable step. By acknowledging three things you did right, you reinforce positive behaviors and achievements. Identifying three areas for improvement allows you to develop self-awareness and create goals for personal growth.

Expressing gratitude, whether to a higher power or simply to the universe, is a beautiful way to cultivate appreciation for the positive aspects of your life.

Your comprehensive outline seems thoughtfully structured, and I appreciate you sharing it with the community. It offers a clear framework for aligning goals, finding gratitude, and maintaining focus. I encourage others to give it a try and share their experiences.

Thank you for your contribution and support, Ivan. Good luck to everyone who chooses to embark on this journaling journey!

Warm regards,

[Your Forum Username]

In ending your day with positive self-reflection, you reinforce the things you did right and identify areas for improvement. Expressing gratitude once again is a beautiful way to cultivate a sense of appreciation and contentment.

Overall, your journaling outline seems well-rounded and thoughtfully designed. I appreciate you sharing this technique, and I will definitely give it a try. It's always beneficial to learn from others and experiment with different practices.

Thank you again for sharing, and I wish you continued success with your journaling practice.

Best regards,

[Your username]

post:
Hello Friends, let me tell you about a self-help technique called journaling. Journaling is the practice of writing every single day. You can practically write about anything you want. You can write about your emotions, you can plan out your day, you can philosophize about life. Journaling is an ancient technique, a perfect example of this is Marcus Aurelius's journal, his Meditations. The stoics used to have different practices and methods to make the most out of their journaling sessions, and they included different excersizes like writng about the finitude of life, writing about their values, and reflecting on their days and what they can do to be better the next day.

I have been experimenting with journaling for years and I wanted to share with you the outline I use to start and end my days and my weeks which keeps me sane, organized, focused, confident, and in harmony with my goals and motivations. Here it is:

\- Start by mentioning 5 things I like, appreciate, love, and admire about myself.

\- Then appreciate 3 things I am thankful for.

\- Write down my short term goals (1 month to 6 months).

\- Write down my medium term goals (6 months to 5 years).

\- Write down my long term goals (5years forward). The idea is that my there should be little fluctuation specially in my medium and long term goals.

\- Plan out my day in google calendar.

\- Space to write about personal things troubling me.

\- If Monday, plan my workload for the week. Once I make a plan, I cannot change it for the week.

\- If Sunday, analyze this weeks workload and think about changes and improvements for the following week.

\- Night

\- Write down 3 things I did right today.

\- Write down 3 things I could do better.

\- Write down 3 things I am thankful for.

\- Thank God.

I recommend you try my outline for a week or two and then tell me what you think about it! I would love to hear your experiences.

Good luck to you all,

Ivan Berezin
reply:
Hello Ivan Berezin,

Thank you for sharing your journaling technique with us. It seems like you have found a structured way to incorporate reflection and goal-setting into your daily routine. Journaling can indeed be a helpful practice for maintaining mental well-being and personal growth.

However, it's important to note that while journaling can offer many benefits, it may not be a standalone solution for everyone struggling with mental health concerns. It's essential to seek professional help if you are experiencing persistent or severe symptoms.

That being said, your outlined approach appears thorough and comprehensive. It's great that you start each day by focusing on self-appreciation and gratitude. Acknowledging positive aspects of ourselves and expressing gratitude for what we have can enhance our overall well-being.

Additionally, setting short, medium, and long-term goals can give us direction and a sense of purpose in life. Breaking them down into manageable chunks (like you have done) helps prevent overwhelm and allows for better planning.

Organizing your day using Google Calendar is an effective way to stay focused and organized. By allocating specific time slots for different tasks, you can enhance productivity and reduce stress.

Providing space for personal reflections and addressing any troubling thoughts or feelings shows that you recognize the importance of emotional well-being. This can help in identifying patterns, triggers, and finding healthy ways to cope.

Sunday's reflection on the previous week and planning for the upcoming one allows for continuous growth and improvement. By analyzing your workload and making necessary adjustments, you can maintain balance and prevent burnout.

Ending each day by recognizing your achievements and areas for improvement helps foster self-awareness and continuous self-improvement.

Lastly, expressing gratitude towards a higher power can provide comfort and a sense of connection.

Thank you for sharing your journaling technique, Ivan. It's valuable to hear about different approaches that work for individuals. Remember, everyone's journey is unique, so it's essential to find what works best for you. It might be helpful to try this technique and customize it to suit your specific needs and preferences.

If anyone else has tried Ivan's journaling outline, we would love to hear about your experiences and any modifications you made to tailor it to your personal needs.

Take care, and best of luck to all!

[Please note that it is not recommended to provide race, age, and gender information when responding to someone seeking mental health support. Mental health concerns are not exclusive to any specific race, age, or gender, and it is more appropriate to focus on universal strategies for well-being.]

post:
I‚Äôm from a town of 12,000 inhabitants in southern Europe. During the ‚Äò90s, I suffered bullying from the age of 7 to 17.
Today, I ran into the person who bullied me the most during my adolescence while I was at a caf√© with my parents (my father is 75, and my mother is 67). He was with friends, his partner, and a newborn baby, and I didn‚Äôt want to do anything, but seeing so much normalcy and happiness for someone who caused so much pain wasn‚Äôt fair. It lasted for over 10 years.

After changing schools, the nightmare continued, but he was the one who started it all and relentlessly focused on me. He also became obsessed with my brother and my parents, and we felt powerless to do anything about it. The reason for his obsession was my overweight.

My parents feel that they didn‚Äôt do enough to protect me from that person. The bullying I endured because of them (him in particular) is impossible to put into words: all sorts of humiliations, threats, insults, and persecutions. I always felt defenseless against them, and they always seemed to win. My parents went to the school and the police, but no one paid attention; they dismissed it as kids‚Äô stuff. My father had been saying for a while that he didn‚Äôt want to die without confronting them. They even insulted my parents in public, calling us mentally unstable. For over 20 years, that person and their group of friends have been keeping tabs on me.

Today at the caf√©, I did something ridiculous. I wrote a note, and my father gave it to this bully. In the note, I expressed that I hope he takes good care of their child because he has already caused too much harm and left too many victims, and no matter how he tries to be a good person now, they have caused pain. 

He confronted my father, and I stood up to him, telling him what I felt inside: that he will always be the terrible person who tried to harm us for over a decade, that he‚Äôs now a teacher, and I will do everything possible to get him fired because people like him shouldn‚Äôt be educating teenagers. He said hurtful things about my family, and his partner even sent me to therapy, which I, of course, did, and he was a significant cause of many problems I faced.

I didn‚Äôt want to bring up the past, but I know my parents felt hurt because he caused us harm, even threatening them when they were heads of the family, and they couldn‚Äôt do anything. It saddened me as a child that a classmate would do that to my parents just because they hated me for being overweight. Another thing that hurt me deeply is knowing that, all these years, I have been a topic of conversation among his friends, and they‚Äôve been keeping tabs on me. One of his friends who works at a supermarket laughed at me, and I got fed up and called her a derogatory term. I know it‚Äôs not the right way to handle it, but I‚Äôm exhausted. 

After all this, I also feel quite sad for still living in the same town where there are people who take an interest in my life despite hating me so much, and I haven‚Äôt done anything to them.

All of this connects with my deepest wounds and the little girl who couldn‚Äôt defend herself, but now I can, and that‚Äôs why I spoke up today. In fact, to prevent further harm, I‚Äôm considering leaving a record with the police and explaining what happened. I‚Äôm not sure if it‚Äôs a good idea; what do you think? I would leave things as they are, but I‚Äôm afraid for my parents. What goes against me is that we acted foolishly with the note, but he escalated the situation, even though he was the one with a history of bullying.
reply:
I'm really sorry to hear about what you went through, and I understand how difficult it must have been to see your bully leading a seemingly happy life. It's understandable that you would feel frustrated and want to speak up about the pain they caused you and your family.

Leaving a record with the police could be a good step to ensure your safety and the safety of your parents. It's important to prioritize your well-being and take necessary measures to protect yourself. You deserve to feel safe and live without the fear of being targeted.

Remember that you are not alone in this. There are resources and support systems available to help you navigate through this difficult situation. Reach out to organizations, counselors, or support groups that specialize in handling bullying and its long-term effects. They can provide guidance and offer strategies to cope with the impact it has had on your life.

Stay strong and know that you have support in your journey towards healing and reclaiming your life.

I'm really sorry to hear about the pain and trauma you've experienced due to bullying. It's incredibly difficult to have to confront someone from your past who caused you so much harm, especially when they seem to be leading a seemingly normal and happy life now. It's understandable that seeing their happiness can feel unfair and bring up a lot of unresolved emotions and anger.

It's important to acknowledge that the effects of bullying can be long-lasting, and it's completely normal to still feel the pain and hurt even after so many years. The fact that this person and their friends have been keeping tabs on you for so long is concerning and can further exacerbate the wounds from your past. It's understandable that you feel exhausted and fed up with this ongoing situation.

Considering reporting the bullying incidents to the police may be a step worth considering. It may bring some feelings of validation and empowerment to have an official record of what you have endured. However, it's important to consider how this might impact your well-being and the well-being of your parents. It might be helpful to seek professional advice or counseling to help you navigate this decision and explore other options for dealing with this situation.

Remember, taking care of yourself and prioritizing your mental health is crucial. It's important to find healthy ways of processing and coping with the emotions that arise from this situation. This might include seeking therapy or support groups to work through the trauma and find healing. Additionally, practicing self-care activities such as exercise, meditation, journaling, or engaging in hobbies can help you manage your emotions during this challenging time.

Lastly, know that you are not alone, and there are resources available to provide support. Connecting with others who have experienced similar situations, whether it's through online forums or local support groups, can be beneficial in finding understanding and empathy. Remember to be gentle with yourself throughout this process and reach out for help when needed.
